title: China Exim bank loans $884 million to Kazakhstan Development Bank for reconstruction of Atyrau Refinery under restricted portion of master loan facility (linked to project #54797)
description: In August 2009, China Export-Import Bank permitted the DBK to draw up to $5 billion from a master facility agreement. This included an unrestricted $1.5 billion loan to Kazakhstan Development Bank and a restricted $3.5 billion. The agreement is for a period of up to 15 years. The agreement prohibits the DBK from incurring indebtedness exceeding 25% of its assets or disposing of over 25% of its assets. The restricted portion of the China Ex-im Bank Facility is aimed at the development of energy, transport and communication infrastructure and the funding of strategic projects in metallurgy, chemical and oil industries. The funds of this credit facility will be used for investment projects of Kazakhstan companies, including the exporting of industrial output, services and equipment to China. The facility's expansion was expected to be completed in 2015. Under the restricted portion of the China Ex-im Bank Facility, on 12 December 2009, DBK entered into an individual credit agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China for the amount of U.S.$884 million of which U.S.$874 million had been drawn as at 30 June 2017. This loan was granted for the purpose of providing financing for the reconstruction of the Atyrau Refinery and was amended on 19 December 2013, 8 May 2014 and 30 October 2014. This individual credit agreement matures on 21 July 2023. Principal and interest under this individual credit agreement is paid semi-annually. As at 30 June 2017, the principal amount outstanding under the restricted portion of the China Ex-im Bank Facility was U.S.$602 million. It is highly likely that this project was funded through the 3 billion USD restricted portion of a China Eximbank Master Loan Facility to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan, captured in #54797.
sources: http://kase.kz/files/emitters/BRKZ/brkzf4e6_2010_e.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://uc27e23b1ce40f2a8cf81e4d98b5.previews.dropboxusercontent.com/nativeprint?file=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dropbox.com%2Fs%2Fp22jt2pz5fawj2x%2FKazakhstan%25202012%2520Bond%2520Prospectus.pdf%3Fdisable_range%3D1%26from_native_print%3D1%26preview%3D1, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.reuters.com/article/oil-kazakhstan-china-idUSL5E8H667N20120606, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.ogj.com/articles/2014/05/kazakhstan-lets-contract-for-atyrau-refinery.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
implementing_agency: Kazakhstan Development Bank, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Kazakhstan Development Bank, Government Agency

title: China Exim Bank loans 1.1 Billion USD to Atyrau Refinery LLP for deeper oil refining complex (Linked to project #54797)
description: On June 6, 2012, Atyrau Refinery LLP entered into a U.S.$1.1 billion loan agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China for the construction of a deeper oil refining complex This loan is secured by China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (SINOSURE) and bears interest at a rate of six-month LIBOR plus 4.1% per annum and matures on 6 November 2025. The loan is guaranteed by the Company. As at 31 December 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was U.S.$1.1 million. It is highly likely that this project was funded through the 3 billion USD restricted portion of a China Eximbank Master Loan Facility to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan, captured in #54797.

title: Bank of China loans 120 million USD to expansion of Shalkiya zinc and lead mine
description: In December 2017, the Bank of China signed a loan syndicate agreement with EBRD to loan up to 120 million USD to JSC ShalkiyaZinc Ltd, a Kazakh mining company based in the Kyzylorda region, for a zinc and lead mine. This loan is part of an EBRD syndicated loan of 295 million USD that was offered in June 2017. The status and details of the loan are unknown. The NWF Samruk-Kazyna JSC signed an agreement with the EBRD at the The Trade Envoy of Great Britain for Kazakhstan to guarantee the loan.

title: China Development Bank loans Tajikistan gold mine venture 140 million USD for expansion
description: In 2013, China Development Bank and Zijin Mining Group signed a loan agreement with Tajikistan-based gold mining joint venture worth 140 million. The loan is to be used for expanding the production capacity of the mine. Other agreements signed at the meeting include two 20 million USD loans from China Development Bank and 33 million RMB to finance expansion of Tajikistan's agricultural sector.

title: US$74 million in supplier's credit for power grid rehabilitation
description: In 2000, China pledged US$74 million in supplier's credit via the China National Electric Import & Export Corporation (CNEIEC). The CNEIEC and Bangladesh Power Development Board (PDB) had earlier signed an agreement to rehabilitate substation and transmission portions of the Bangladeshi power grid - a project valued at 5.53 billion taka (US$106 million). 29 grid substations and 819 kilometers of 132-kilovolt transmission lines were to be rehabilitated in 36 months, increasing capacity from 1100 to 2000 megawatts. In May 2000, the loan agreement has been signed between CNEIEC and the Economic Relations Division (ERD) under the Bangladeshi Ministry of Finance. The China National Cable Engineering Corporation is the main contractor for this project, and they are responsible for the design, manufacturing, logistics and installations. Construction work started in October 2005. In February 2007, construction was successfully completed and handed over to the Bangladesh Power Development Board.

title: $129,825,916 China Eximbank loan for the rehabilitation of road section sin Jalal-Abad and Batken.
description: China Eximbank loaned $129,825,916 to Kyrgyzstan for the rehabilitation of road section sin Jalal-Abad and Batken. At present, earthworks and drainage works, as well as repairs with the broadening of 5 bridges, are almost completed. In addition, the laying of the bottom layer of asphalt concrete pavement over 19 km has been completed. The amount of implementation is more than $ 27.66 million or 30.24% of the contract value. The project is designed to significantly reduce trade barriers caused by the poor condition of the roads and help to increase the level of regional trade.

title: Bandaraniake Memorial International Conference Hall (BMCIH) Maintenance and Development
description: In 2007, China agreed to provide a USD 7.2 million grant for the maintenance and development of the Bandaranaike Memorial International Conference Hall (BMICH) (see page 353 of the 2007 Sri Lanka Ministry of Finance document). In June 2010, Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka Yang Xiuping visited the ongoing reconstruction project, and the completion ceremony for the maintenance project was held on 24 October 2013. Although the signing of an official financing agreement is not mentioned in any documents, the commitment year has been coded as 2007 because that is the earliest Sri Lanka Ministry of Finance Annual Report that mentions Chinese financing for the 'Maintenance Requirements at the BMICH'. The 2008 Annual Report from the Ministry of Finance refers to this funding as a loan, but all other documents, including the 2007 Annual Report, refer to the funding as a grant; and for this reason, the flow type has been coded as a grant. This project is related to project ID #33192, which captures the 2003 construction of the Sirimavo Bandaranaike Memorial Exhibition Centre in memory of Late Sirimavo Bandaranaike with a free grant provided by China.

title: Bank of China offers bank guarantee for the Bishek-Kara-Balta road in Kyrgyzstan
description: In 2017, the Hunan Branch of the Bank of China agreed to give a bank guarantee to renovate the section of road between Bishkek-Kara-Balta, however details of this arrangement are unclear. The Kyrgyz Ministry of Transport and Roads offered $70,239,899 to China Railway No. 5 Engineering Group Co. for three years to implement. The project was funded by the Asia Development Bank as part of a larger sum for the implementation of this road of $100 million ($65 million in loans and $35 million granted). As of March 8, 2019, the project was delayed but being implemented.

description: In June 2010, China Exim Bank and Uzpromstroybank signed a loan agreement for 70 million USD to modernize the gas distribution network in Uzbekistan during the state visit of the Chinese President Hu Jintao to Uzbekistan. title: China EXIMbank offers concessional loan of 216 million USD to upgrade telephone networks in Bangladesh
description: In September 2006, China pledged a concessional loan to Teletalk, of $211 milllion, but the deal expired without any payment in August 2008. In 2009, China pledged to renew the deal. The money was to be used to upgrade Bangladesh's telephone networks to 3G, via Teletalk. TeleTalk, Bangladesh, Ltd. was designated to implement the project under the supervision of the Ministry of Post and Telecommunication. The project will increase TeleTalk's capacity to provide service to 4.73 million new 3G subscribers and 4.77 million new 2. 5G GSM mobile subscribers. Planned completion was July 2010. In October 2012, Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina inaugurated the 3G network. China National Electric Import and Export Corporation would implement the project. According to Teletalk, the project has a loan amount of USD 211 Million with an annual interest rate of 2%, 4 years grace period, 20 year repayment. In December 2010 , Teletalk Bangladesh signed the agreement with CMEC to expand the 2.5G network and to construct the new 3G communications network. The agreement is worth a total of approximately 216 million USD and it will be provided for with concessional loans from the China Export-Import Bank . The contract was enforced on June 9, 2011 and construction works officially started on January 6, 2012.

title: China Exim Bank loans $208 million for Modernization of Power Transmission Lines in South of Kyrgyzstan (Linked to Project #39619)
description: On June 14, 2011, Kyrgyz Finance Minister Melis Mambetzhanov and President of Export-Import Bank of China Li Ruogu signed a concessional loan agreement for the modernization of power transmission lines in southern Kyrgyzstan for $208 million, according to the Finance Ministry's press service. The power lines are located in Batken, Jalal-Abad, and Osh. The Export-Import Bank of China extended the grace period from 5 to 7 years. The maturity period is 20 years and interest rate is 2%. The project will support construction of 500 kV Datka station in Jalal-Abad and construction of 220 kV power transmission line stretching for 256.5 km. On July 29, 2011, this project was contracted to TBEA on a ceremony held in Kyrgyzstan. According to AMP Kyrgyzstan, $197.5m of the committed amount has been disbursed as of 2018. This project is linked with #39619, an Eximbank loan for the construction of a power line from Datka to Kemin.

title: China Exim Bank loans $49m USD for Dushanbe-Dangara road reconstruction [Phase 1] (linked to ID #53750, #40440)
description: In 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China loaned Tajikistan 49 million USD for Phase I of the rehabilitation of the Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma road. This 154-km road between Dushanbe, Vakhdat, and Dangara is the first phase of the 1,100 km Tajikistan-China highway project. The total cost of this project is $51,578,000 with the remainder funded by the Tajik government. This section of the road is 57.8 km, and the project was implemented from 2009-2012. This project is linked to project ID #53750, an Exim bank loan for Phase II of the project, and #40440, an Exim bank loan for the Chormagzak tunnel as part of the Phase II project.
sources: http://www.amcu.gki.tj/eng/index.php?option=com_profile&task=show_agrinfo&agcode=101029, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.crbc.com/site/crbcEN/businessUpdate/info/2014/2442.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/linked-documents/41340-015-dc.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://open_jicareport.jica.go.jp/pdf/12246633.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/877071468303575509/pdf/891840NWP0P14700TJK0NOTE60final0web.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://minfin.tj/downloads/files/MTEFfinalTajikenglish.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/dl/gbdqzn/upload/tajikesitan.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Exim Bank provided USD259 million loan for Phase-I realignment of Karakoram Highway at Attabad Lake in Pakistan (linked to #35739)
description: In December 2010, Pakistan's National Highway Authority (NHA) has signed a contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) for the realignment of KKH. The project involves the realignment the portion of the highway that was submerged under water during the Attabad landslide in 2010. The cost of the project was US$275 million. It was based on 85% funding in foreign currency from China Exim Bank's concessional loan, and 15% in local currency by the Pakistan government. The project included the realignment of roads, construction of 5 tunnels with total length of 7.12 km, 78 culverts and 2 bridges. The application for the loan is under process with Economic Affair Division (EAD). Work would be completed in 2 years after commencement subject to availability and release of funds. The project was completed on Sept 14, 2015. The final year book report by the Pakistani government for 2016-2017 records a Preferential Buyer's Credit loan of USD259 million and that the project was completed on 30-06-2017. STAFF_NOTE: The KKH highway had been updated previous to the realignment by China. For details on this project, see #35739. Note that the previous upgrading and the realignment of the KKH highway are jointly called the Phase-I project of KKH Highway. STAFF_NOTE: There is a significant portion of contradicting information on the transaction in Pakistani finance ministry's Economic Affairs Division Year Book reports. Coder did not code these information and deferred to the report mentioned above as the more reliable source. See below for these contradicting reports. A Pakistani ministry of finance monthly project status report in August 2016 records the project as a loan of CNY259 million, which is slightly smaller than the amount recorded above. Moreover, the source suggested that part of the loan was fulfilled in August 2016, which contradicts the source above suggesting that the project was complete on September 14, 2015. A Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book in the fiscal year of 2016/17 confirms the amount of 259 million USD, and also suggests that by 30 June 2017, 253.3 million of the total amount has been disbursed. It is therefore unlikely that the project has been finished, changed the project status to implementation. Stage 2 confirmation is needed here. According to Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2015-2016, China is estimated to disburse 3,744.874 million Pakistani rupees to the project in 2014-2015, according to the revised budget estimate. In the Estimates for 2016-2017, the revised budget for 2015-2016 states that China likely loaned 7,288.920 million Pakistani rupees, or 54 million USD, for this project during the year. The Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2017-2018 initially estimated that 200 million Pakistani rupees would be loaned in 2016-2017, but the revised estimate states that 0 funds were likely to be disbursed during the year.

title: China Exim bank loans 143.9m USD for Dushanbe-Dangara road reconstruction [Phase 2] (linked to #40063, #40440)
description: In 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China loaned Tajikistan $143,925,000 for Phase II of the rehabilitation of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway, Dushanbe-Dangara section. The grace period is from 5 to 7 years. The remaining amount of the $151.5 million project was provided by the Tajik government. This section of the road is 50.5 km and includes the construction of the Chormagzak tunnel. The project was implemented between 2009 and 2013. This project is linked to project ID #40063 (49 million loan for Phase I), and project ID #40440 (loan for the Chormagzak tunnel).

title: China Eximbank loans $77 million for Kungrad Soda Ash Plant (linked to #39943)
description: In September 2012, China's Export Import Bank issued a loan of $77 million for the expansion of the Kungrad Soda Ash Plant in the Karakalpakstan region of Uzbekistan. The project expanded the plant's capacity from 100,000 to 200,000 tons per year. The loan has a maturity of 20 years, but the interest rate and grace period are unknown. The total project cost is 110 million, and financing was also provided by the Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan and state joint stock company Uzkimyosanoat. China's CITIC Co, Ltd. designed and supplied equipment for the project. The project took two years and was completed in 2016. This project is linked to #39943, an ICBC loan in 2003 for the construction of the plant.

title: China Eximbank provides loan for modernization of UE 'Cascade of Kadirin Hydroelectric Power Plant' (HPP-3)
description: In 2017, China Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for modernization of UE 'Cascade of Kadirin Hydroelectric Power Plant' (HPP-3) in Kibray district, Tashkent region (reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan). The total cost of the project is 27,600,000 USD, but the amount of the Eximbank loan is unknown. According to a UNECE report, the project is cofinanced by the IDB. The cascade consists of four HPPs. The project will increase the plant's power from 11.3 MW to 15.34 MW, and is expected to be implemented from 2017-2019. Project status is also unknown. STAFF_NOTE: Year is marked uncertain because some sources report the dates of the project as 2015-2017.

title: China Eximbank provides loan to Uzbekistan for modernization of Cascade Nijne-Bozsuv Hydroelectric Power Plant (HPP-14)
description: In 2017, China's Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for the modernization of Cascade Nijne-Bozsuv Hydroelectric Power Plant (HPP-14) in Zangiata district, Tashkent region (reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan). The total project cost is 31,600,000 USD, but the contribution of the Eximbank is unknown. The cascade consists of five HPPs. The project will increase the plant's power to by 2.8 MW to 16 MW and is expected to be implemented from 2017-2019. According to a MarketWatch article, implementation has begun. Loan details are unknown. STAFF_NOTE: Cascade also referred to as Lower Bozsu, and can be spelled Nije-Buzsuz or Nizhne-Bozsu.

title: China Eximbank provides loan to Uzbekistan for modernization of Cascade Tashkent Hydroelectric Power Plant (HPP-9)
description: In 2017, China Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for the modernization of Cascade Tashkent Hydropower Plant (HPP-9) in Yunusabad region, Tashkent district. The total cost of the project is $26,700,000, but the amount loaned by the Eximbank is unknown, so transaction amount has been left blank. Modernization of the hydropower plant will be carried out by the Power China company. The project will increase the plant's power to 16.6 MW and is expected to be implemented from 2017-2021.

title: China Provides $200M Loan to Kyrgyzstan for Bishkek‚ÄìNaryn‚ÄìTorugart Road Project
description: In 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China agreed to a $200M loan to Kyrgyzstan for the rehabilitation of Bishkek‚ÄìNaryn‚ÄìTorugart Road Project. China's EXIM Bank will fund section 1, which runs from km 9-272. The project is set to take from 2011-2014. As of recently, project is not yet completed but some parts are. Unclear if the 9-272 km section is completed. According to the Kyrgyz Republic AMP, the actual commitments were $199,999,703 USD and all of the committed funds have been dispersed as of 2014.

title: China assists in Rehabilitation of Bishkek roads (Asphalt paving)
description: In December 2017, the Chinese Ambassador to Kyrgyzstan signed letters of exchange with Kyrgyzstan's Minister of Economy for asphalting the pavement of 23 streets with a total length of 38km as well as carrying out road rehabilitation. Media reports note that the total project will cost 278.73 million yuan to execute. The project is implemented by China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) on a grant provided by the Chinese government. According to a press release by the implementing company, the project started construction May 25, 2018. According to a news report on August 26, 2018 by Xinhua News, a Chinese state media outlet, the project had been underway at that time and parts of the road network had been finished. The same report says that the project utilizes a grant from the Chinese government, and is scheduled to be finished by November 2019. STAFF_NOTE: This project should not be confused with project #52924, as CRBC reported #52924 in 2 phases, but reported this project as a stand-alone project.

title: China donates 1 million Rs and teaching equipment to Shree Chhorepatan Higher Secondary School in Nepal
description: In October 2011, China donated one million Nepalese Rs in cash to the Shree Chhorepatan Higher Secondary School for the construction of a science laboratory building, and also presented some teaching equipment including Lenovo computers to the school computer rooms.
sources: http://np.china-embassy.org/eng/Education/t873506.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Yang Houlan, Chinese Ambassador to Nepal

title: China donates 500,000 rupees to Sri Lankan Svillaga Blind Children's Home
description: In March 2016, the Chinese Embassy donated 500,000 Sri Lankan rupees to the Svillaga Blind Children's Home near Colombo. It also donated some life and study necessities. The money will be used to improve the drainage system. The drainage system removes the breeding ground for mosquitoes and greatly reduces the risk of dengue fever in children.
sources: http://lk.chineseembassy.org/chn/xwdt/t1347911.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: Chinese Embassy, Government Agency

title: China donates to two elementary school reconstruction in Paghman, Kabul, Afghanistan
description: The Embassy of China donated to Miba elementary school (Á±≥Â∑¥Â∞èÂ≠¶) and Tahgwa elementary school (Â°îÊ†ºÁì¶Â∞èÂ≠¶) in Paghman District, Kabul, Afghanistan for reconstruction. The amount of donation and duration of reconstruction is unknown from the original source. The reconstruction handover ceremony was held on September 17, 2016. There are nearly 4,000 students in a school in Tagawa, including 1,800 girls. Due to the poor school buildings, the limited number of classrooms can only accommodate students in batches. After the restoration project, the classroom windows of the two schools were equipped with glass, the roof was reinforced and rainproof, the school also built toilets and walls, and the new school building greatly improved the enthusiasm of local residents to send their children to school. STAFF_NOTE: The spelling of two elementary school cannot be found, so it's simply pinyin translation. The transaction amount is also unknown

title: China grants 214 million Rupees to Pakistan for Engineering Service Centre (linked to #38441)
description: China donated funds worth Rs. 214 million for upgrading the Tevta Light Engineering Service Centre at Gujranwala. The grant will install Hi-Tech Machinery, and provide facilities for Material Testing, advanced Welding & Fabrication, Hi-Frequency Heat Treatment, Machining of Dies & Moulds, Induction & Vacuum Hardening and Plasma Cutting machinery. The agreement was signed by Mohsin Syed, the Chairman of Tevta, and Zhou Zhencheng, the Economic & Commercial Counsellor of China. First Secretary of Chinese Embassy in Pakistan Yan Jianming, Zonal Manager (North) Group Capt E Muhammad Rashid, Manager Service Centers Akhtar Abbas Bharwana and Manager Public Relations Mustafa Kamal Pasha were also present. The project has not been completed within the planned duration (i.e. 2003-04 to 2005-06), due to the delayed documentation between the Government of the Punjab and China. Works started on 1 July 2007 and ended on 30 June 2009. STAFF_NOTE: According to the Punjab government, the total budget of the project was Rs. 165.880 Million in which Government of Punjab shared Rs.16.187 Millions and the remaining was provided by the Peoples Republic of China. This would put the transaction amount at 149,693,000 Rupees. There is also a discrepancy in the dates, with some sources listing 2006 and others listing 2008.

title: China grants Kyrgyz Opera and Ballet Theater 50 million RMB
description: The government of the Chinese People's Republic allocated 50 million yuans to the Kyrgyz Opera and Ballet Theater named after Abdylas Maldybaev. First Deputy Prime Minister of Kyrgyzstan Kurmanbek Osmonov, Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary Ambassador of China to Kyrgyzstan Hong Jiuyin attended the ceremony dedicated to this event. In his speech, K. Osmonov noted that 'this event testifies our ancient and lasting friendly relations with China'. Two years ago, Kyrgyzstan and China signed bilateral agreement to allocate by the Chinese government gratuitous aid worth 50 million yuans, he said. According to him, the aid aimed to modernize equipment and reconstruct the building of the Opera and Ballet Theater, which is the leading and unique cultural building of Kyrgyzstan.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KABNEW0020030514dz5e00007&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China grants Kyrgyzstan 70 million RMB for agricultural development and construction of schools
description: On June 12, 2006, China allocated Kyrgyzstan a grant of 70 million yuans to be directed for purchasing agricultural technique, construction of schools, reconstruction and construction of roads as well as acquiring technique for the state institutions. No further information can be found to confirm the grant, and the flow class is uncertain.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=OANA000020060612e26c0010b&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/b/g/200607/20060702743319.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China grants Pakistan $12.7 million USD for construction of Pakistani diplomatic missions (linked to ID #43973)
description: In 2000, China and Pakistan signed agreements in Islamabad for two Chinese-funded projects. China was to grant assistance for these projects totaling $12.7 million USD. The first of these projects was the construction of Pakistani missions in Beijing and Shanghai. As of 2001, construction of the missions was underway, but the current state of this project is unknown. The second project (ID #43973) aims to increase a highway's ability to operate year-round. STAFF_NOTE: The financial amount included two projects, one of which was coded under a different project #35739 and had been deactivated. Therefore, the specific amount for this project is still left to be determined.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcfe00020010804dw4c00dvc&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mofa.gov.pk/shanghai/content.php?pageID=introshang, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.asianresearch.org/articles/2528.html, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcfe00020010804dw4c00dvc&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=paprin0020010816dw5800a6j&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcapp0020010710dx1i001i1&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.cacianalyst.org/publications/analytical-articles/item/7097-analytical-articles-caci-analyst-2001-7-4-art-7097.html?tmpl=component&print=1, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/0163660X.2012.642294?journalCode=rwaq20#.VaXMZPntmko, Academic Journal Article

title: China grants Rs 425m for Gwadar Smart Port City Master Plan
description: Talking to a Pakistani news agency, Pakistani officials in Gwadar indicated that the 'master plan' would transform the existing city into a modern port of international standards and a smart, sustainable city that can drive local, national and regional growth in the coming decades. They said the development of Gwadar is a strategic priority for the Government of Pakistan. CPEC originally estimated cost at US$4 million.The project MoU was signed in Nov 2015. Chinese Fourth Harbour Design Institute has been nominated for Gwadar Smart City Plan. The project contract was signed in May 2017 alongside the Gwadar Eastbay Expressway project. As of 2019, the companies reportedly estimated a total cost of Rs 521 million. This includes a Chinese grant of Rs 425m, and an additional Rs91m provided by the government of Pakistan. According to a Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book in the fiscal year of 2016/17, LOE was signed on 09-09-2016. Implementation Minutes and Contract Agreement has been signed. (15th May 2017). The contract amount is 28.6 million CNY, which is roughly the equivalent of the total project cost Rs521m. The company began working on the project plan in 2017, and it was sent to the federal government for approval after completion in December 2018. In January 2019, a media source reported Chinese companies were frustrated over delays in the final approval of the plan by Pakistan's government, warning that costs due to these delays would be the responsibility of the government. A different CPEC website puts the project status as still undergoing contract negotiations. It is possible that this website is outdated. STAFF_NOTE: For now, coded recorded the project as commitment. The project status can be modified if update is found in the future. As the date of grant agreement signing could not be found, the project commitment date is coded as the signing date of the implementation contract in 2017.
sources: https://pakobserver.net/master-plan-gwadar-smart-port-city-finalized-soon/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://cpec.gov.pk/project-details/63, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.cpecinfo.com/gwadar-port-city, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.ead.gov.pk/userfiles1/file/EAD/2018/Final%20PCP%20Year%20Book%202016-17%20.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://tribune.com.pk/story/1892965/1-gwadar-master-plan-delay-upsets-chinese/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/pakistan/chinese-companies-warn-pakistan-against-delay-in-cpec-project/articleshow/67627895.cms, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://monitoring.bbc.co.uk/sample-search?searchText=Pakistan,%20China%20ink%20pacts%20to%20make%20Gwadar%20modern%20port%20city&minScore=0&sort=publication_time&sortDirection=DESC, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/dl/gbdqzn/upload/bajisitan.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ccccltd.cn/news/jcxw/jx/201705/t20170517_88667.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
implementing_agency: China Communications Construction Co., Ltd. (CCCC), State-Owned Company

title: China loans 386 million USD for modernization of Bishkek Thermal Power Plant
description: On Dec. 11, 2013, The Parliament of Kyrgyzstan passed the draft law ratifying a $386 million loan from the Export-Import Bank of China through the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, at 2% interest per annum for 20 years. Kyrgyzstan will pay only interest for the first 11 years of the term of the loan. Modernization of the Bishkek TPP will take three years, said its director Andrey Voropaev. Two turbines (unit 12, 13) will be installed with a capacity of 150 megawatts. As a result, capacity of the station will increase by 125 megawatts. Today, the annual output of electricity at the plant is one billion kWh. After upgrading, the production will reach 1.8 billion kWh. Heat production will increase from two million gigacalories to three million gigacalories per year. This is one of the projects in the joint construction of the economic zone of Silk Road. In 2014, the Chinese Ambassador attended the opening ceremony for the project. In August 2017, president of Kyrgyzstan, Almazbek Atambayev carried out the ceremonial opening of Bishkek‚Äôs rebuilt Combined Heat and Power plant (CHP). There were sources saying that Exim Bank picked the contractor and it would have been cheaper if CMEC has won the contract. There is a corruption accusation to this project. ' The power plant‚Äôs director Nurlan Omurkul uulu stated that the cause of the accident wasn‚Äôt any carelessness on the part of the specialists, but the siphoning off of funds allocated to the rebuilding project. According to Omurkul uulu, the real cost of the modernisation wasn‚Äôt $386 million, but $100 million less. ‚ÄúAbout 90% of the necessary materials and equipment were bought at an elevated price. '

title: China loans Bangladesh $87 million to fund paper mill modernisation
description: In May 2001, China committed supplier's credit to Bangladesh for the Balancing, Modernisation, Rehabilitation and Expansion (BMRE) of the Karnaphuli Paper Mills in Chittagong, via the China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC). The BMRE project was intended to expand production capacity, from 37500 metric tonnes to 85500 metric tonnes per year, as well as improve output paper quality of the mill. In 2005, China agreed to convert the supplier's credit into a concessional loan. After having been stalled, the project resumed in 2014, with the loan having been converted again, into a zero-interest preferential loan of $87 million. According to a 2017 Report on Suppliers' Credit from the Economic Relations Division of Bangladesh, none of the committed funding has been dispersed as of 2017.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=unibag0020010716dx57002ve&pp=1&fcpil=zhcn&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://bdnews24.com/business/2005/05/20/china-agrees-to-convert-suppliers-credit-into-concessionary-loan-for-bmre-of-kpm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.hawker.com.bd/news_details.php?news_id=390319&news_category_id=6&val_lan=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.observerbd.com/2014/12/20/61733.php, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://newsfrombangladesh.net/view.php?hidRecord=55320, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://erd.portal.gov.bd/sites/default/files/files/erd.portal.gov.bd/page/b09c0301_8d15_49e1_8af9_3231f08b8ad8/Tbl-7.3.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China loans Kyrgyzstan $75 million USD for Rehabilitation of Osh‚ÄìSarytash‚ÄìIrkeshtam Road
description: In November 2008, Chinese government announced a US$75 million soft loan through China Exim bank for rehabilitation of Osh-Sary-Tash-Irkeshtam road during an official visit (Nov.14 - Nov.16) of the delegation of Kyrgyzstan, Kyrgyz Foreign Minister Ednan Karabaev, to China. During this official visit, Chinese government also extended a grant of 50 million Yuan to Kyrgyzstan (Project #40358). The completed rehabilitation of the Osh‚ÄìSary-Tash‚ÄìIrkeshtam‚ÄìKaramyk corridor will facilitate regional trade and transport. To complement these investments and make them sustainable and efficient, ADB needs to help the government attract the private sector in road construction and maintenance, particularly at high altitudes and nder harsh winter conditions. In this respect, an enabling legal and regulatory framework for public-private partnership needs to be developed. On Feb 25, 2018, the first motor convoy with export cargo on the new established Tashkent-Andijan-Osh-Irkeshtam-Kashgar transport corridor. Staff_Note: Transaction amount edited due to Kyrgyz Republic AMP reporting amount committed as $75.29m
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=AKIPEN0020081117e4bh0008d&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.boxun.com/news/gb/pubvp/2010/05/201005180011.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-document/60573/36257-013-kgz-pcr.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.carecprogram.org/uploads/events/2010/9th-TSCC/Country-TTFS-Implementation-KGZ.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://amp.gov.kg, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://tashkenttimes.uz/national/2079-andijan-osh-irkeshtam-kashgar-transport-corridor-to-start-operating-as-of-feb-25, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://amp.gov.kg/aim/viewActivityPreview.do~public=true~pageId=2~activityId=1732, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/rlfylb6fbmzrlno/%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5%20%D0%BD%D0%B0%20%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%20%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8B%D0%BA%D0%B5.doc?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/linked-documents/42399-02-kgz-dc.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: China provides $3.6 million grant to Afghanistan for renovation of Kabul Jumhoriate hospital (Linked Project ID #34498)
description: In May 2002, China announced it would provide a $3.6 million grant to renovate Afghanistan's Jamhuriat (Jumhoriate - update in November 2018) Hospital in Kabul. The China United Engineering Corporation is an implementing organization and performed an inspection on the hospital. The project included reconstructing approximately 6,000-7,000 square meters of the hospital, installing medical examination facilities such as CT-scans and X-rays, providing electrocardiogram and blood test instruments, and installing an AC system. The hospital's building was completed in March 2006; operations resumed fully in January 2014.

title: China provides $8.8 million in financing for rehabilitation of the pump station 'Ulugnar' in Andijan oblast
description: The Chinese government provided $8.8 million in financing to Uzbekistan for the rehabilitation of the pump station 'Ulugnar' in Andijan oblast, as reported in Uzbekistan's 2008 IMF report. Current project status and loan details are unknown. STAFF_NOTE: Project was recorded in the 2008 IMF report but loan could have been committed earlier, so year is marked uncertain. This project could not be confirmed by any other sources.
sources: https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/CR/Issues/2016/12/31/Republic-of-Uzbekistan-Poverty-Reduction-Strategy-Paper-21636, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: China provides 60 million yuan grant to Nepal for stadium upgrade
description: In 2012, China provided a 60 million yuan grant to Nepal for the upgrading of Dashrath Stadium. The project consisted of technical support for the lighting system, sound system, display screen and other equipment, so the stadium could meet the international requirements to host events. A 500 KW generator was also installed in the stadium to upgrade the electrical system. The project handover ceremony was held on March 6, 2012. The Asian Football Confederation Challenge Cup in 2012‚Äîone of the major regional tournament in Asia‚Äîwas the first tournament played under the floodlights and upgraded stadium systems. STAFF_NOTE: No currency stated in any sources, assumed to be yuan.
sources: http://np2.mofcom.gov.cn/article/chinanews/201203/20120308004352.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://xinhuanepal.tumblr.com/post/37395953916/xinhua-gallery-china-aid-project-dashrath, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://np.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t911617.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://jjhzj.mofcom.gov.cn/article/y/201203/20120308046520.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Yang Houlan, Chinese Ambassador ; Sushil, Ministry Secretary of Youth and Sports of Nepal

title: China provides 80 million Yuan in Grant to Afghanistan for reconstruction after war
description: On 31 January 2006, at the London Conference on Afghanistan, Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing announced that China would provide 80 million Chinese Yuan in grant assistance to Afghanistan. The pledge was reaffirmed in a 'Joint Statement Between The People's Republic of China And The Islamic Republic of Afghanistan' on 20 June 2006 and again on 15 September 2006 Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao at the fifth prime ministers' meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO). In an overview report by China Economic and Commercial Counsellor's Office, Afghanistan, the grant was provided to Afghanistan in 2006. The grant will used for the implementation of different projects to aid the reconstruction of the country. According to the News of the Communist Party of China, the project is completed. STAFF_NOTE: This project is reactivated. This is not a duplicate for #38972. From the source detected, China actually provided 80 million Yuan to Afghanistan in 2006 (#34526) and another 80 million Yuan in 2007 (#38972), and another one in 2008.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020060201e2210020c&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://af.china-embassy.org/chn/zagx/ztgk/t1097558.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global-factiva-com.libproxy1.nus.edu.sg/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAPP0020060915e29f0048t&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinaconsulatesf.org/eng/xw/t259062.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chinaconsulatesf.org/eng/xw/t236145.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://news.sina.com.cn/c/2006-02-01/01478111473s.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.china-un.org/chn/zgylhg/jjalh/alhrd/yz/afh/t365864.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/zgzx/2007-08/21/content_7438659.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.cpc.people.com.cn/91788/91789/6240978.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://reliefweb.int/report/afghanistan/chinese-president-pledges-support-afghan-reconstruction, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/ttwe1lxhfyzo0c2/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20of%20Afghanistan%20DAD%20China%20Project%20Data.xlsx?dl=0, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/cu75mmi3ek8d6sc/Flat%20Export%20of%20Geocoded%20Afghanistan%20DAD%20from%202014.xlsx?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/39f0hlojgq163bu/DAD%20Afghanistan%20Project%20000368.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China provides USD327 million loan for Phase-I upgrading of Karakoram Highway, Pakistan (CPEC) (Linked to project #39030)
description: A loan agreement for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Upgrade Project between the government of Pakistan and Export-Import Bank of China was signed in Islamabad on January 18, 2008. Under the agreement China would provide a $327 million loan for the $491 million project. The agreement was signed by the Ambassador of Pakistan to China H.E. Mr. Salman Bashir and Mr. Xin Bin, Deputy General Manager Commercial Loan Project. The concessional loan has a 12 year maturity. The project is being executed jointly by China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) and the Pakistan National Highway Authority (NHA). National Engineering Services Pakistan (Nespak) is the consultant for the project. The expansion and upgradation of a 335-kilometre section of road from Raikot to Khunjerab was expected to be completed by 2011. The planned upgradation would widen KKH from 10 to 30 metres, making it suitable for heavy and long vehicles and allowing it to remain functional throughout the year. The upgrading project also includes the construction of 32 new bridges and rehabilitate 27 existing bridges. A ground-breaking ceremony was held on February 16, 2008. The construction completed on Nov 30, 2013. According to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates for Foreign Assistance for 2015-2016, in the revised budget estimate for 2014-2015 for the project, 3,544.874 million Pakistani rupees are expected to be disbursed by China in that year. STAFF_NOTE: Some ancillary works are currently in progress by the Contractor (CRBC) to realign the highway due to a landslide that happened in 2010. The final inspection was carried out by NHA Inspection Wing, and the subsequent expected completion date is September 2015. For details on the realignment work on the highway, see project #39030. Note that the upgrading and realignment works on the road are jointly called the Phase-I project of KKH Highway.

title: China provides funding for Parwan Irrigation Project (Linked to #34498)
description: The Parwan Water Project is located 40-85 km north of Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan. The northern plain of the project is the main producing area of ‚Äã‚ÄãAfghan agricultural products and is the granary of Afghanistan. The water conservancy irrigation project was assisted by the Chinese government and contracted by our company. It was officially started on December 31, 1968 and completed on December 31, 1976. The total length of the main canal is 85.578km, and the designed irrigated area is 24,800 hectares (372,000 acres). However, due to natural aging, disrepair and war damage, the entire Parwan water conservancy project was severely damaged, the water channel was unable to supply water properly. In order to help the Afghan people rebuild their homes, the Chinese government reached an agreement with the Arab side in May 2003 to decide to help the Parwan water conservancy project free of charge. The restoration project was divided into two phases: Phase-1: On 3 March 2004, at the Chinese Embassy in Kabul, Chinese ambassador to Afghanistan, Sun Yuxi and Afghan Irrigation, Water Resources and Environment Minister Mohammad Yusuf Nooristani signed an agreement under which China would help rehabilitate irrigation canal in Parwan Province. The construction was implemented by the Jiangxi Province Water and Hydropower Co. Ltd. starting in March 2004, and the China International Water and Electric Corp. carried out the acceptance testing in June 2005. The project was officially completed and transferred in October 2006. The first phase of the project has a total price of $11.5 million, according to the information platform by the Shanghai Commerce Council. A news article published by People's Daily Online on 3 March 2004 mentioned that the first phase of the project would cost US$10 million. Phase-2: The second phase started at the end of December 2006 and ended at the end of December 2007. The same companies respectively carried out the construction and acceptance testing. It was also reported that China National Electric Equipment Corporation (CNEEC) and Beifang Investigation ,Design & Research CO. LTD (BIDR) were involved in the rehabilitation project. Phase-2 Addition project: This was also undertaken by Jiangxi Water and Hydropower Construction Co., Ltd., which was started on December 31, 2010 and completed on June 15, 2012. Based on the ADB report, the total cost for the project is US$15 million, which would be funded by China. In another news article published by the Chinese Embassy Website, the funding for the project was drawn from the US$150 million that China has pledged in 2002 and is a sub-umbrella project of #34498 instead of a duplicate. STAFF_NOTE: The financial breakdown of the phases is not yet clear, so it is captured under the same project for now. If more specific information is found in the future, the project should be separated into linked projects.

title: China provides two Urban Infrastructure Development Packages worth of USD300 million to AJK region in Pakistan
description: According to a Pakistan Finance Ministry Monthly Disbursement report from Aug 2016, China provided two Urban Infrastructure Development Packages to the AJK region in Pakistan, respectively worth of USD143.90 million and 156.20 million, in the form of Public Buyer's Credit. Only an extremely small proportion of these amounts were actually disbursed that month. The source also records the start date as 18.06.2009 and the end date 31.12.2016. Project should have been completed but no relevant information is found in stage 1. STAFF_NOTE: NOV 19 2018 South and Central Asia Scrape According to a Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book in the fiscal year of 2016/17, the project is listed in the category of completed projects with a transaction amount of USD300 million. Changed the project status to completion. STAFF_NOTE: NOV 19 2018 South and Central Asia Scrape The Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book in the fiscal year of 2015/16 records the project with a combined committed amount of USD300 million and a fulfilled part of 206.5 million. STAFF_NOTE: NOV 27 2018 South and Central Asia Scrape The Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimate of Foreign Assistance for 2015-2016 states the revised budget estimate halfway through the fiscal year for the project in 2014-2015 is 3,566.450 million Pakistani rupees in addition to 3,859.500 million Pakistani rupees for the same project. The Estimate for 2016-2017 predicts the revised budget estimate for Chinese loans to the project to be 3,048.850 million Pakistani rupees for 2015-2016. The Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2017-2018 records the revised budget estimate for the two packages in FY 2016/17 to be 6,394.08 rupees, or 90.22 million USD, approximately the remainder of the funds. The budget estimate for FY 17/18 is 0.

description: In 2008, China provided a $15 million government loan to Uzbekistan for the reconstruction and expansion of the sewage treatment plants of Namangan. Total investments for the project were $15.8 million. Current project status and loan details are unknown. STAFF_NOTE: Project was recorded in Uzbekistan's 2008 IMF report but loan could have been committed earlier, so year is marked uncertain. This project could not be confirmed with any additional sources.

title: Chinese grant for Rehabilitation and Reconstruction of Bishkek Road Network Project Phase II
description: In September 2016, Chinese state-owned company China Road and Bridge Corporation signed a commercial contract to handle the newly-named Bishkek Municipal Road Network Improvement Project in the Republic of Kyrgyzstan. Under CRBC management, the project was shortened to 95.33km in length, and 49 sections of individual road repair. The project is currently underway, with an expected completion date in 2019. It was reported that the Chinese government granted 481 million yuan to this project. The first phase of the Rehabilitation of the Bishkek Road Network Project involved a road that was 7.47km in length, committed and finished in 2015. STAFF_NOTE: This project should not be confused with project #54376, as CRBC reported this project in 2 phases, but reported #54376 as a stand-alone project

title: EXIM Bank loan for Upper Trishuli 3A - Kathmandu 220kV Transmission Line and 132kV Line Bay Extension Works Project (linked to #53716)
description: In May 2011, a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on the Transmission Line and Bay Extension for the Upper Trishuli 3A Hydroelectric Project was signed between the Nepal and the Export-Bank of China. On August 17, 2011, a loan agreement was signed between China Eximbank and Nepal's government for the provision of a soft loan for the expansion of the 10 km, 220 KV Upper Trishuli transmission line from Manakamana of Nuwakot to Matatirtha of Kathmandu. The project was completed on April 30, 2019. The transmission line is being built to evacuate power generated by a dozen of hydropower projects including Upper Trishuli 3A (see project #53716). If the transmission line is not built in time, energy generated by these projects will be wasted.The implementing organization for this project would be China Gezhouba Group Company. The expected completion date for this project would be March 27, 2012, or 30 months after construction began. However, construction is delayed due to obstruction by the locals. The company must complete transmission line works by April 30, 2016. According to the Aid Management Platform, the total commitment from China is 24335542 USD.

title: EXIM Bank loans $166mil for A9 highway renovation
description: On February 7th, 2011 the refurbishment of a section of the A9 Highway which stretched from Galkulama junction in the Anuradhapura district to Jaffna was funded by the EXIM bank through a loan of $166 m.The government contracted the Aviation Industry Corporation of China to build the road. The road was officially opened on 15th June 2013 by President Rakapaksa of Sri Lanka. The loan has a interest rate of 2.4%, a grace period of 3 years, and will mature in 15 years. STAFF_NOTE: Confirmed by Director- China and AIIB Division, External Resources Department, Ministry of National Policies and Economic Affairs, Sri Lanka

title: Export Import Bank of China Loans US $165.6 million for Angren Thermal Plant Project in Uzbekistan
description: On September 9, 2011, the EXIM Bank of China and the Industrial and Construction Bank of Uzbekistam (Uzpromstroybank) signed an agreement for a 165.6 million USD loan to modernize the Angren thermal power plant in the Tashkent region. The funds are to be repaid over 20 years with a 5 year grace period and the project will have a capacity of 130-150 MW. The total cost of the project is 242.6 million USD, with Uzbekenergo funding the final 75.1 million USD. It is unclear which organization eventually cofinanced the project because it seems that Uzbekistan also requested funding from ADB in 2014. In 2017, the information from the Harbin Electric website indicated that the project is in progress. STAFF_NOTE: An original official source indicated funding was estimated at US$150 million, but later official sources indicate the funding was US$166 million or US$165.6 million. Defaulted to the source that stated US$165.6 million, as it states the funding organization was specifically the EXIM bank, while other sources stated government of China. Since interest rate could not be found, Flow class was coded Vague Official Finance.

title: Export-Import Bank of China funds Conversion of Units 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 of Novo‚ÄêAngren TPP (Phase 1) in Uzbekistan
description: Between 2010 and 2012, Uzbekistan secured financing of US$273 million from the Export-Import Bank of China to fund the conversion of Units 1, 2, 3, 4, & 5 of Novo-Angren Thermal Power Plants to the all year coal firing (phase 1). The Thermal Power Plant is located in Dzhuma Angren. The capacity of the project was reported to be 7 bln kWh p.a. by the World Bank Report, and is expected to shift to burning coal by 2013. The other two units of the plant are expected to be converted by 2016. STAFF_NOTE: this project was amended October 30th, 2018 to spell out TPP as Thermal Power Plants

title: Grant to widen Kathmandu Ring Road (Phase 1)
description: In 2011, China agreed to provide the grant assistance worth US$40 million for the first phase in upgrading and widening the Kathmandu Ring Road. China will provide assistance to widen the entire 27-kilometer four-lane two-way roads around Kathmandu to eight lanes with a two-way bicycle lane and a pedestrian pathway, bus station, parking lots, maintenance of the main road stream bridges, construction of the new relief road stream bridge, construction of one simple urban flyover and three pedestrian overpasses. The road is being upgraded in three separate phases, with the first stage being the 9km Kalanki-Koteshowre section and the building of a new interchange. The improvement of Ring Road is expected to ease traffic congestion in Nepal's capital city, which is home to 3.5 million people. It will take 42 months to complete the construction, according to a design by the Third Railway Survey and Design Institute Group Corporation, a Chinese engineering consultant company. According to the AMP website, the total disbursement amount was 33,154,069.

title: HSBC contributes US$44.1 million for runway overlay & associated works at Bandaranaike International Airport in Sri Lanka
description: In a 2017 Performance Report by Sri Lanka's Department of External Resources, it was reported that the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation (HSBC China) was contributing US$44.1 million to Sri Lanka's runway overlay & associated works at Bandaranaike International Airport Katunayake. Observation for work to be done was completed from 6th January 2017 to 5th April 2017 with 8 hours of runway closure.China National Aero Technology International Engineering Corporation (CATIC) was the Design and Build Contractor for Runway Overlay Project. Work commenced in Sept. 2016 and total contract period was 12 months. The scope of work for the 30-year-old runway overlay project included the delivery and commissioning of the complete light-emitting diode (LED) airfield ground lighting (AGL), signs, an airfield lighting control and monitoring system (ALCMS), and power management solutions. The project also included the construction of an additional apron area to increase the number of parking bays, including 45 for mixed aircraft configurations. STAFF_NOTE: Original source is unclear whether this is a loan or grant.

title: Maldives Ministry of Foreign Affairs 2005 building renovation (Linked to #54157)
description: In 2005, China committed a grant of 25.4 million MVR to Maldives' Ministry of Foreign Affairs for building renovation, according to the Maldives' 2007 and 2008 Government Budget reports. 24.7 million MVR was disbursed in 2005, and 0.7 million MVR was disbursed in 2006. Shanghai Construction Group was contracted for this project. This is linked to a 2018 Chinese financed renovation of the Maldives' Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Project #54157).

title: Northern Road Rehabilitation Project
description: On 9 September 2010, EXIM Bank of China signed a 424 million USD loan agreement with Sri Lanka to finance the the Northern Road Rehabilitation Project. The loan has an interest rate of LIBOR 06 Month for US$ + 2.40% margin and a maturity of 15 years including 3 years of grace period (see 'Global Partnership' document from Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in September 2010 was 0.478%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.478% + 2.40%, or 2.878%. According to the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources, this project was completed on 9 September 2013. On 6 December 2009, The Sunday Times of Sri Lanka reported that the contract to rehabilitate (widen and improve) all adjunct roads in the North of Sri Lanka had been given to four different Chinese companies in 13 different packages. The four Chinese companies, China National Aero Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC), China Harbour, China Railway No 5 Engineering Group Co. Ltd. and Synohydro Corporation will share the deals between them. Based on Sri Lanka's Department of External Resources (ERD) the project has 7 packages, which corroborated with the 'Development Performance Year End Review 2014' report by Sri Lanka's Ministry of Finance and Planning and the summary report by Ministry of Highways, Higher Education and Investment Promotion. The 7 contract packages are: 1) C1A - 63 km of Kandy- Jaffna road (From Galkulama to 230th km). Contractor: CATIC 2) C1B- 90 km of Kandy- Jaffna road (From 230th km to Jaffna). Contractor: CATIC 3) C11A - 42.4km of Mullaitivu- Kokkilai- Pulmoddai road. 4) C11B - 52.6 km of Oddusuddan- Nedunkerny road and Mullaitivu- Puliyankulam road. 5) C2 - 67 km of Navatkuli- Karaitivu- Mannar road (completed in 2015). Contractor: China Harbour Engineering Corporation 6) C3 - 113 km of Puttalam- Marichchikade- Mannar road (completed in 2015). Contractor: China Harbour Engineering Corporation 7) C7 - 84 km of Jaffna- Kankesanthurai road, Jaffna- Palali road, Jaffna- Point Pedro Road and Puttur - Meesalai road. Contractor: China Railway No. 5 Engineering Group C7 stretches for 84km and itself comprises of 3 sub-projects 1)Jaffna-Kankesanthurai road (Route No. AB16), 2) Jaffna-Palali road, Jaffna-Point Pedro Road (Route No. AB18 and AB20 respectively) and 3) Puttur-Meesalai road (Route No. AB32 ) . The project was jointly funded by the Exim Bank of China & the Government of Sri Lanka. The Project was valued at Rs. 3,662 Million. Construction began on Feb 11, 2011 and was completed on Oct 13, 2013. One source stated that the projects would be executed under 5 civil works contracts, and that 5 loans were signed by Exim bank on 09.09.2010 to satisfy these contracts. This was the only source to break down the projects in this way. STAFF_NOTE: The ERD Performance Report of 2010 reported the loan to be US$302 million, but their current website sites the loan as worth US$424 million. Because both are official sources but it is likely that their site is a more recent source, this project records the amount of US$424 million. A 2015 report lists the value at Rs.59632 Mn.

title: Relocation and Development of Institute of Technology, University of Moratuwa
description: In November¬†2011,¬†the¬†Sri Lankan Ministry¬†of¬†Higher¬†Education entered into a¬†contract¬†with the China National¬†Aero Technology¬†Import¬†and¬†Export¬†Corporation¬†(CATIC) to¬†carry¬†out¬†the project for the relocation and development of the Institute of Technology of the University of Moratuwa.¬†EXIM Bank of China provided Sri Lanka a loan of $76.1175 million USD for relocation and development of the Institute of Technology, University of Moratuwa. The total cost of the new complex for the Institute of Technology of the University of Moratuwa (ITUM) at Diyagama, Homagama, is US$ 89.55 million (Rs 11.7 billion). Exim Bank China will loan 85% of the funding required, while the balance 15% will come from Sri Lanka. (China's contribution = $89.55 million * 0.85 = $76.1175 million). The loan maturity is 15 years including a 3-year grade period. Chinese firm CATIC has undertaken the construction of the project. The project will help increase present student intake from 1050 to 3000 students annually and help middle level skilled technicians. The IET will be relocated to Diyagama, Homagama. Lecture rooms, laboratories, workshops, libraries, administrative complexes, medical rooms, hostel facilities, and playgrounds are among the sections which will be developed. Under the project, the institute will be provided with the required equipment, computers and machinery, along with training of the staff. The project was completed in 2017.

title: Supreme Court Complex Repair and Refurbishment
description: In 2013, the Chinese government agreed to undertake a project to repair and refurbish the Supreme Court Complex with Chinese aid. In a 2016 report by Sri Lanka's Department of External Resources, it was reported that in April of that year Sri Lanka and China signed a grant agreement for RMB Yuan 500 million for a comprehensive refurbishment of the Superior Courts Complex.The Chinese-funded refurbishment of Sri Lanka‚Äôs Supreme Court complex has been completed on time by China‚Äôs Jiang Xi Province Construction Company. Sri Lanka‚Äôs Supreme Court complex was constructed in 1989 with Chinese government assistance. The roofs and the auditorium of the complex were completely renovated recently on the request of the Sri Lankan government. The inner roofs of the Supreme Court‚Äôs ceremonial hall were refurbished, as well as the fire extinguisher pipe system and its electric lifts, and the Ministry of Justice building.

title: China EXIM Bank loans $35 million to Tajikistan for rehabilitation of Regar substation (linked to ID #40481)
description: In 2013, China EXIM Bank loaned $35,043,320 to the Tajik Ministry of Finance for the rehabilitation of the 500 kV Regar substation for the reconstruction, as reported in the May 2018 flat export of Tajkistan's AIMS. The total cost of the project is $36.9 million. Loan details are unknown, but media reports state that it is a concessional loan. The project is currently under implementation.

title: China grants 1,223,241 USD for repair of Shar-Shar (Liberty) tunnel access road (linked to #40406)
description: In 2013, the Chinese Government granted 1,223,241 USD for the repair of the access road to the Shar Shar (now Ozodi or Liberty/Freedom) Tunnel. The May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS reports the grant assistance as $1,223,241 and recorded the project ID as TJK/112262. The project was implemented from 2013-2014. This is linked to project ID #40406, a Chinese loan for the construction of the tunnel in 2006. title: $89.5 million China Eximbank loan for modernization of Baisun and Shargun coal deposits in Surkhandarya region
description: In 2014, China Exim Bank provided a loan of 89.5 million USD to Uzbekistan fund the modernization of Baisun and Shargun coal deposits through the project ‚ÄúModernization of JSC ‚ÄúShargunkumir‚Äù. In April 2014, the China Coal Technology & Engineering Group (CCTEG) signed a contract with Uzbekcoal JSC to replace the existing technologies and production at Baisun and Shargun coal deposits and bring project capacity to 900 thousand tons of coal per year. In particular, the CCTEG will deliver two mechanized complexes with production capacity of 450,000 tons per year each on a turnkey basis. The project also provides for modernization of the system of coal transportation. The total cost of the project is $101.3 million, with the remainder financed through equity funds of the Uzbek side - $11.8 million. The project began as a result of a tender won by the China Coal Technology & Engineering Group to modernize coal mining in southern Uzbekistan. As of September 12, 2017, China Coal Technology & Engineering Group Corp., and China Railway Tunnel Group Co., Ltd., have started the preparatory work of the modernization project. According to the project official, it is expected to be finished by the first quarter of 2020.

title: China Development Bank loan to United Chemical Company LLP
description: The 13th National Report On the implementation of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative in the Republic of Kazakhstan for 2017 reported that United Chemical Company LLP received a loan from the State Development Bank of China in the amount of 409 million US dollars (equivalent to 134.970 million tenge at the exchange rate on the date of receipt). This may be related to the agreement signed between China Development Bank and United Chemical Company LLP in June 2017 on the implementation of investment projects for the production of methanol and ammonia in the National Industrial Petrochemical Technopark Special Economic Zone (SEZ), in the Atyrau region, as well as the production of caustic soda in the Chemical Park Taraz SEZ, in the Zhambyl region. The signed project is being implemented as part of the development of Kazakhstan's first agrochemical cluster. No other loan information can be found.
sources: http://lenta.inform.kz/en/kazakhstan-china-business-council-starts-in-kazakhstan_a3034112, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://sk.kz/press-centre/media/19444/?lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://eiti.org/sites/default/files/documents/english_2017_eiti_report_kazakhstan.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: China Development Bank loans Uzbekistan 220 million USD for thermal plant rehabilitation
description: On October 22, 2012, Uzbekenergo State Joint Stock Company (SJSC) secured a loan from China Development Bank worth 220 million USD to co-finance a project to update Tashkent's Thermal Power Plant. The loan is under government guarantee for 15 years with a 3 year grace period. The interest rate was equal to six month LIBOR rate plus 3.6% APR (with an average six month LIBOR rate of .687 % for the year of 2012). A 370 MW steam-gas installation will be built. The total project is for 511.8 million USD, and will also be financed by Uzbekistan's Reconstruction and Development Fund (76.2 million USD), a business loan from Synecta a.s. (68.9 million USD), Uzbekenergo (117.7 million USD), an Uzpromstroybank credit (26.9 million USD), and a credit from Japan International Cooperation Agency (2.037 million USD).

title: China EXIM Bank loans Uzbekistan 113 million USD for mine modernization
description: On Wednesday June 9, 2010, the China Exim Bank agreed to loan Uzbekistani commercial bank, Uzpromstroybank. The Uzpromstroybank will use the loan specifically to modernize the Angren coal mine in Tashkent. The loan is part of a larger 154 million USD economic cooperation agreement between China and Uzbekistan. The loan terms are unknown

title: China EXIM Bank provides 129.8 million USD export credit for Rehabilitation of Osh-Batken-Isfana 127km section and Bishkek-Balykchy 25km section
description: On April 1, 2013, the Kyrgyz Parliament approved China EXIM Bank's preferential buyer's credit for the renovation of two roads in Kyrgyzstan. The agreement was signed December 4, 2012 and was worth 129.8 million USD, with a 20 year maturity, an interest rate of 2%, and a grace period of 9 years. The funds would help the renovation of the 127 km of the Osh-Batken-Isfana road and 25 km of the Kuaka-Balykchy road (assumed to be the same as Bishkek-Balykchy road). In 2015, the Kuaka-Balykchy road renovation was finished. China Road and Bridge Corporation commenced construction of the project in July 2013. They reported on their website that the length of the Osh-Batken-Isfana road being rehabilitated is 123.06km, and the length of the Bishkek-Balykchy road being rehabilitated is 23.66km. They also reported that this project is the third China Eximbank financed project in Kyrgyzstan that they undertook. According to the AMP of Kyrgyzstan, $32 million of the total pledged value was distributed in November 2013 and the same amount was distributed December 2014. $64.9 million USD has let to be undispersed.

implementing_agency: China Road & Bridge Corporation (CRBC), State-Owned Company

title: China Eximbank loan for the reconstruction of the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) segment of the Almaty-Oskemen road project
description: In May 2016, China CITIC Corporation signed a EPC agreement with KazAvtoZhol for reconstructing the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) segment of the Almaty-Oskemen road project (1003 km). The road also passes through Kalbatau. This road reconstruction project is also part of Kazakhstan's State Program of Infrastructure Development ‚ÄúNurly Zhol‚Äù for 2015-2019, through which the Ministry for Investments and Development of Kazakhstan implements projects on the development of roads, transport, civil aviation and modernization of heat, water and sanitation networks. According to the official website of the Prime Minister of Kazakhstan, the Taldykorgan ‚Äì Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) section will be reconstructed with a loan from Exim Bank of China. CITIC website confirms that China Exim bank provided preferential buyer credits for the project. The project implementation started in 2017. According to Germany Trade and Invest, a financing contract for this project was signed with Export-Import Bank of China in November 2016 for a loan of 796 million USD. No other loan information can be found for now. STAFF_NOTE: Note that Ust-Kamenogorsk is also referred to as Oskemen, some reports have referred to this road as Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-√ñskemen. title: Export credits for Gwadar Port Channel Deepening Project, Pakistan
description: On March 24, 2006, Pakistan and China signed a $22.3 million credit agreement for additional dredging of the Gwadar port, to 14.5 metres. It was signed by Pakistan‚Äôs ambassador to China, Salman Bashir, and Liang Xiang, assistant president of China Export-Import Bank. It is reported that China financed the project from the remaining preferential buyers' credit of 500 million USD extended to Pakistan. The government of Pakistan gave approval in February for extra dredging to enable 50000 DWT vessels to use the port. he project is an extension to Gwadar Port Project Phase I, which comprises three multi-purposes berths of 602-metre total length, which will also accommodate roll-on roll-off vessels, a 100-metre service berth, 4.25-kilometre approach channel dredged to 11.5 metre-12.5 metre and demarcated with buoys and turning lights. The channel was deepened to 14.5m in February 2007.

title: Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2) (link to projects ID #46971, #33402 and #39002)
description: On 31 March 2011, China Development Bank signed a USD 500 million loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2). This loan covers 90% of the total project cost, and it has an interest rate of LIBOR 06 Months for US$ + 2.90% margin and a maturity of 15 years including a 4 year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2017 Annual Performance Report). The interest rate is coded based on the 6 Month LIBOR at time of signing of the agreement. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in March 2011 was 0.461%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.461% + 2.90%, or 3.361%. According to the 2017 Government of Sri Lanka Bond Prospectus, the total cost of the project was USD 556 million, and the 10% of funds (56 million USD) not covered by the USD 500 million CDB loan were provided by the Government of Sri Lanka. This project was completed on 31 December 2018 (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization'). The three contractors for this project were Xi'an Dagang Road Machinery Co. Ltd., China National Aero Technology International Engineering Corporation, and Hunan Construction Engineering Corporation. The objective of this project was to provide necessary connectivity and linkages to the road network in order to accelerate the Government road construction program, as well as to improve priority road sections covering all Island connecting all electorates. The scope of this project includes the rehabilitation and improvement of 581 km in 20 roads including 95 km of provincial roads in Nuwara Eliya district, construction of two flyovers and reconstruction and widening of 22 bridges under two components (see Development Performance Report Year End Review 2015 from the Sri Lanka Department of Project Management). The 24 project components listed below include the 20 road sections, the 2 flyovers, and the 2 bridge components. This project included the following components in the Southern Zone (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization'): 1. Horawela-Pelawatte-Pitigala Road: 0.0 - 17.50 km 2. Horana-Anguruwatota-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 3. Horawela-Pelawatta-Pitigala Road: 17.5 - 25.74 km (total length of 8.24 km) 4. Construction of a flyover at Mattala airport access road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 5. Construction of a flyover at 100 feet road and bypass road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 6. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Tiruwanaketiya-Agalawatta Road: 33.45 - 67.80 km (total length of 34.35 km) 7. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Horana-Anguruwayoya-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 8. Thihagoda-Kamburupitiya-Mawarala-Kotapola Road: 23.0 - 67.0 km (total length of 44.0 km) 9. Hungama-Middeniya Road: 0.0 - 30.0 km 10. Nagoda-Kalawellawa-Bellapitiya Road: 27.0 - 57.0 km (total length of 30.0 km) This project included the following components in the Northern Zone (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization'): 11. Kandy-Mahiyangana-Padiyathalawa Road: 93.15 - 102.28 km (total length of 9.13 km) 12. Badulla-Karamatiya-Andaulpotha Road: 0.0 - 48 km 13. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Daukkane Road: 0.0 - 24.10 km 14. Bibile-Uraniya-Mahiyangana Road: 22.0 - 39.58 km (total length of 17.58 km) 15. Galkulama-Anuradhapura Road: 0.0 - 15.0 km & 16.0 - 16.64 km (total length of 15.64 km) 16. Kadahapoka-Rambawewa Road: 0.0 - 18.71 km 17. Kurunegala-Narammala-Madampe Road: 0.0 - 22.36 km 18. Galagedara-Rambukkana Road: 0.0 - 18.5 km 19. Tennekumbura-Rikillagaskada-Ragala Road: 20.2 - 73.64 km (total length of 53.44 km) 20. Uswetakeiyawa-Epamulla-Pamunugama Road: 0.0 - 8.05 km 21. Palaviya-Kalpitiya Road: 14.0 - 40.60 km (total length of 26.60 km) 22. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Dalukkane Road: 24.10 - 72.8 km (total length of 48.7 km) 23. Manampitiya-Aralaganwila-Maduru Oya Road: 0.0 - 3.0 km 24. Provincial Roads in Nuwaraeliya District: 85.01 km For other priority road projects, see projects ID #46971 (PRP1), #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1), and #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.
