title: Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 3 - Phase I (PRP3-I) (link to projects ID #46971, #39001 and #39002)
description: On 11 March 2014, the China Development Bank signed a 300 million USD loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Improvement and Rehabilitation of Priority Road Project 3 (Phase I), which was a follow-up on a May 2013 pledge from CDB for the same amount. According to the 2017 Sri Lanka Government Bond Prospectus, the estimated total cost of the project was 357.69 million USD. The Government of Sri Lanka would provide the remaining funds for the project. The 300 million USD CDB loan has an interest rate of LIBOR 06 Months for US$ + 2.95% margin and a repayment period of 15 years including a 3 year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2014 Annual Performance Report). The interest rate is coded based on the 6 Month LIBOR at time of signing of the agreement. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in March 2014 was 0.331%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.331% + 2.95%, or 3.281%. This project commenced on 11 March 2014 and was completed on 11 March 2019 (see 'Resource Mobilization' from Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). The objective of this project was to rehabilitate and improve 270 km of priority road sections to ensure the connectivity among already improved road sections. Areas of the project include: Southern, Eastern, Uva, Western and Sabaragamuwa Provinces. The Sri Lanka Department of External Resources divides Priority Road Project 3 (PRP3) Phase I into two parts, A and B. The contractors for PRP3-Phase I (A) were China National Aero-Technology International Engineering (CATIC - ENG) and Xi'an Dagang Machinery Co. Ltd., although it is unclear which specific roads each company worked on. The contractors for PRP3-Phase I (B) were CATIC and Hunan Construction Engineering Group Corporation (Hunan), and the specific contractor for each road is listed in the relevant section below. Under PRP3- Phase I (A) the following 6 roads were rehabilitated (see Ministry of Highways and Investment 'Ongoing Projects'): 1. Ratnapura - Palawela - Karawita Road: 00.00km - 21.28 km 2. Veyangoda -Ruwanwella Road: 12.4 km - 32.2 km (19.8 km total length). This section also included the rehabilitation of a bridge. 3. Meegahajandura-Kumaragama Road: 0.00 km - 8.8 km 4. Galle-Udugama Road: 0.00 km - 35.35 km 5. Hiniduma-Opatha-Pitabaddara Road: 0.00 km - 31.5 km. This section also included the rehabilitation of a bridge. 6. Mawanella-Hemmathagama-Gampola Road: 0.00 km - 26.00 km Under PRP3 - Phase I (B) the following 6 roads were rehabilitated (see Ministry of Highways and Investment 'Ongoing Projects'): 7. Kiriella-Nedurana-Eheliyagoda Road: 0.00 km - 14.75 km. Contractor: CATIC 8. Ratnapura-Wewelwatte Road: 0.00 km - 27.50 km. Contractor: CATIC 9. Kandy-Jaffna Road: 1.65 km - 3.9 km (2.25 km total length). Contractor: Hunan 10. Marawila-Udubaddawa Road: 0.00 km - 19.55 km. Contractor: Hunan 11. Rambukkana-Katupitiya Road (0.00 km - 9.81 km) and Dambokka-Katupitiya Road (0.00 km - 8.75 km). These two roads were rehabilitated at the same time and are considered the same project by the Sri Lanka Ministry of Highways and Investment. Contractor: Hunan 12. Ayagama-Egaloya Road: 0.00 km - 23.00 km. Contractor: CATIC For other priority road projects, see projects ID #46971 (PRP1), #39001 (PRP2), and #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.

title: Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 3 - Phase II (PRP3-II) (link to projects ID #46971, #39001 and #33402)
description: On 24 November 2014, China Development Bank Corporation (CDB) signed a 100 million USD loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the 'Improvement and Rehabilitation of Priority Road Project 3 (Phase II)' (PRP-3 II). According to the 2017 Government of Sri Lanka Bond Prospectus, the estimated total cost of the project was 117.66 million USD. The Government of Sri Lanka would provide the remaining funds for the project. The 100 million USD CDB loan has an interest rate of LIBOR 06 Months for US$ + 2.95% margin, a 0.5% management fee, and a maturity of 15 years including 3 years of grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2014 Annual Performance Report). The interest rate is coded based on the 6 Month LIBOR at time of signing of the agreement. The average 6 Month LIBOR in November 2014 was 0.327%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.327% + 2.95%, or 3.277%. The project commenced in March 2016 according to the Sri Lanka Ministry of Highways and Investment and was expected to be completed in June 2018 (see 'Ongoing Projects'). According to the Department of External Resources, the project has not yet been completed (see 'Resource Mobilization'). The objective of the project is to improve and rehabilitate priority road sections in Sabaragamuwa and Central Province, as well as to ensure the connectivity among already improved road sections. The following 20 roads are being rehabilitated under the Priority Road Project 3 (Phase II) (see Ministry of Highways and Investment 'Ongoing Projects'): 1. Katugastota-Medawala Road: 10 km (Kandy District) 2. From Thibbutta Junction to Demaralaawa-Penanetipola-Battagalla Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 3. Hapugahayatatenna-Watadeniya Road: 8 km (Kandy District) 4. Naranwita-Udadeniya-Wewatenna-Niyangama Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 5. Heennarandeniya Junction-Udiwita Elpitiya Road and Elipitiya River-Weligalla Junction: 5 km (Kandy District) 6. From Nilamba Gurukale Junction to Godawala (Doluwa Road) Starting from Kandy Galaha Main Road: 6 km (Kandy District) 7. Kotaligoda-Thismada Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 8. Eramuduliyadda-Kolugala-Thismada Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 9. Nawalapitiya-Nagaswella Road: 11 km (Kandy District) 10. From Wahugapitiya-Nuwara Eliya Road to Doragala Via Chappiliyawatta: 2 km (Kandy District) 11. Yatirawana-Balapola Road: 2 km (Kandy District) 12. A.C.S Hameed Mawatha: 0.9 km (Kandy District) 13. Mahanuwara Aruppola Mawatha No.5 (From Bakery Junction to Aruppola Junction): 0.5 km (Kandy District) 14. Rambukkana-Mawanella Road: 11.79 km (Kegalle District) 15. Bulugolla-Dombemada-Wahauwa Road: 7.65 km (Kegalle District) 16. Mawanella-Aranayaka-Horewela Road: 14.43 km (Kegalle District) 17. Gevilipitiya-Hettimulla Road: 14 km (Kegalle District) 18. Kegalle-Bulathkohupitiya-Karawanella Road: 10.35 km (Kegalle District) 19. Kegalle-Siyabalapitiya-Dewalagema Road: 2.63 km (Kegalle District) 20. Mabopitiya-Degalathiriya Road: 1.75 km (Kegalle District) For other priority road projects, see projects ID #46971 (PRP1), #39001 (PRP2), and #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1) for more details.

title: Bank of China loans $232 million USD for proposed road bitumens production plant at the plastics plant in Aktau
description: In September 2010, Bank of China Ltd. agreed to loan $232 million to the joint venture Caspi Bitum, between Kazakhstan‚Äôs JSC KazMunayGas Refining and Marketing and Chinese Citic Group to build a bitumen (asphalt) plant in Aktau as part of the 'Production of Road Asphalt at the Aktau Plastics Plant' project. The project was planned for completion by the first quarter of 2012 at a minimum capacity of 400 tons. The plant capable of processing 1 million tons of oil and producing about 400 tons of high-quality bitumen officially opened in Aktau on Dec. 20, 2014. The project is part of Kazakhstan‚Äôs Petrochemical Industry Development Program for 2008-2013. According to KMG, the total cost of the project is $290 million. CITIC Group is a strategic partner of KMG and the investor of the project. JV Caspi Bitum LLP was organized in 2009 on a parity basis by JSC Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries (subsidiary of KMG) and CITIC KAZAKHSTAN LLP (a subsidiary of CITIC Group). JSC NSCC KazStroyService and China's CITIC Construction are contractors of the project.

title: Broadlands Hydropower Project
description: China National Electric Equipment Corporation will be constructing the 35 MW Broadlands Hydro Power Project over the Kelani River at Kithulgala. The total cost of the project is $82 million, and was partially financed by a $69.7 million loan from the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, and insurance coverage from the China Export and Credit Insurance Corporation. The loan agreement was signed on 16 January 2013 and has a grace period of 3 years and a maturity of 15 years (see 'Resource Mobilization' from Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). The remaining funding will be supplied by the Hatton National Bank of Sri Lanka. The Broadlands project is the last plant in the so-called Laxapana cascade power station complex on the Kelani River system which was started 50 years ago. The project was due to be complete and connected to the grid by 2014, however construction only began in July 2013. As of August 2015, around 10 per cent of the project was complete. The project was expected to be completed in 2020, consisting of two dams, and a power station further downstream. However, official source (Department of External Resources) reports indicate that the project was completed on January 16, 2018. The project was implemented by the Ceylon Electricity Board, the largest electricity company in Sri Lanka. The completed project had a 24m high & 144m long main dam, a 19m high & 48m long diversion dam, a 2.7m diameter & 850m long diversion tunnel, a 5.4m diameter & 3Km long main tunnel, a 35MW surface power station (2 units of 17.5MW), a switch yard, and a 4Km long transmission line.

title: CDB gives $200 million USD buyers credit to India for Lanco Amarkantak Thermal Power Units 3&4
description: In 2010, the China Development Bank gave $200 million USD Buyers‚Äô Credit to India for units 3 & 4 of the Lanco Amarkantak Thermal Power Project. Unit 3 is the 1320 MW Babandh power station and unit 4 is the 1320 MW Vidarbha thermal power station being developed by Lanco Infratech. As of November 2012, the project had been categorized as 'fast tracked' and construction had begun. As of March 2018, the project remains on hold.

title: CPEP Phase I Stage II - South Container Terminal One: Debt Component (link to projects ID #54211 and #54212)
description: On 23 September 2011, a consortium led by China Merchants and Sri Lankan conglomerate Aitken Spence PLC signed a deal with the Sri Lankan government worth 500 million USD to build and operate the 'Colombo South Container Terminal' . The total length of quay is 1200 meters, with a designed throughput of 2.4 million TEUs, and can accommodate the world's largest container vessels at 18,000 TEUs. Based on information from IJGlobal Project Finance & Infrastructure Journal, the project's debt-equity ratio is 60:40, with China Development Bank funding the debt portion amounting to 300 million USD. China Merchants Port Holdings, Aitken Spence PLC and Sri Lanka Port Authority provided the 40% equity funding amounting to 200 million USD. The breakdown of the equity funds are as follows: 110 million USD (55%) from China Merchants Port Holdings, 60 million USD (30%) from Aitken Spence PLC, and 30 million USD (15%) from Sri Lanka Port Authority. As described in the attached document from China Merchants Port Holdings, in January 2012 China Merchants Port Holdings acquired Aitken Spence's entire 30% interest, bringing its total equity interest to 85%. China Merchants Port Holdings obtained financing from China Development Bank in respect of this acquisition. For the purpose of this project, only the 300 million USD of funding from CDB has been recorded. For details on the equity portion, please see the linked project #54211, and for details on the purchase of Aitken Spence's 30% interest made by China Merchants Port Holdings, please see linked project #54212. Colombo International Container Terminals Ltd (CICT) is a joint venture between China Merchants Holdings (International) Co. Ltd. of Hong Kong, Aitken Spence PLC of Sri Lanka and Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA). CICT was awarded the tender to construct and operate the Colombo South Container Terminal for a period of 35 years, after which the terminal would be handed over to the Sri Lanka Ports Authority. CMHI initially held 55% interests in CICT while Aitken Spence Plc held 30% and SLPA held 15%. In January 2012, China Merchants acquired Aitken Spence's entire 30% interest in CICT, bringing its total equity interest to 85%. The construction work of the South Container Terminal commenced on 1st December 2011 with the terminal being ceremonially opened for traffic on 8 August 2013. Phase II (Entire Terminal) was completed in April 2014; in April 2014, the completion ceremony of the Colombo South Container Terminal was held.

title: China Development Bank Aktogay copper deposit RMB Facility (Linked to Project ID #41941)
description: In December 2011, CDB signed two bilateral agreements with Kazakh Copper Company (Originally called Kazykhmys PLC, now called KazMinerals) to set up loan facilities worth $ 1.5 billion to for copper mine development projects in Aktobe. Aktobe maintains a volume of 5 million tons of copper. The money was used to construct Aktogay mine. First copper cathode production from oxide ore occurred in December 2015, whilst first copper in concentrate output from sulphide ore began in February 2017. The main sulphide concentrator was constructed by Nonferrous China (NFC). The project capital cost is expected to be in the region of $2.1 billion. The mine is expected to produce up to 100,000 tons of copper concentrate annually in 2015. On February 16, 2012 the loan was finalized and signed as two transactions one for RMB 1 billion (158 million), the other for 1.34 billion USD. It is being developed as an open-pit mine including an on-site concentrator and construction work started in the first half of 2013. The Facility has a final maturity of 15 years from the date of first drawing. The total Aktogay Facility of approximately $1.5 billion is comprised of two separate agreements, a USD agreement for up to $1.34 billion and an RMB agreement for up to RMB 1.0 billion (approx $158 million). Both agreements are reportedly on essentially similar terms and conditions, except that proceeds drawn under the RMB agreement can only be applied towards payments to Chinese suppliers for equipment, materials and services sourced from China. The interest rate on the USD agreement is set with reference to USD LIBOR, while the RMB agreement is at the applicable benchmark rate published by the People's Bank of China (PBoC). The maturity period for the loan is 15 years, and the grace period is 3 years. In the KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016, the interest rate is stated to be 5.12%.

title: China Development Bank loans $50 million USD to Uzbekistan for high tech park
description: In November 2011, the State Development Bank of China and National Bank of Uzbekistan for Foreign Economic Activity signed a loan agreement for $50 million USD to create a high tech park in the Jizzakh region of Uzbekistan. Deputy Minister for Foreign Economic Relations, Investments and Trade of Uzbekistan Shavkat Tulyaganov confirmed this at the Uzbek-Chinese Business Forum in Tashkent on March 31, 2012 and stated that construction would begin in the first half of 2013. The projects will be financed by both China Development Bank's loan and by Uzbek partners, although it is unclear whether the Uzbek funding is part of or in addition to the $50 million USD loan.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=UZBDAY0020120331e83v0002y&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gutenberg.us/articles/Economic_development_zones#Jizzakh_high-tech_industrial_park, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency

title: China Development Bank loans US$1.2 billion to Uzbekneftegaz for synthetic liquid fuel production plant
description: In 2017, China Development Bank (CBD) provided a loan of US$1.2 billion to Uzbekneftegaz for the the production of synthetic liquid fuels based on purified methane from Shurtan Gas Chemical Complex. A gas to liquid processing plant will be constructed at the Shurtan petrochemical complex in Guzar district, Qashgadaryo Region of Uzbekistan.The total cost of the plant is US$3.7 billion. The remaining financing will be obtained from Uzbekneftegaz and international financing institutions; the consortium includes Export-Import Bank of Korea, Korea Trade Insurance Corporation K-SURE, Gazprombank, Russian export credit agency EXIAR, Credit Suisse, and Japanese banks MUFG, SMBC and Mizuho. Uzbekistan GTL LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Uzbekneftegaz, is the operator of the project, while a South Korean consortium led by Hyundai Engineering & Construction company is the general contractor. The project began construction in January of 2017, and is expected to have a capacity capacity of 743,500 tons of diesel fuel, 311,000 tons of aviation kerosene, 431,100 tons of naphtha and 20,900 tons of liquefied gas per year. Shurtan Gas Chemical Complex will supply the plant with 3.6 billion cubic meters of methane per year. The plant is scheduled to begin service in 2020. STAFF_NOTE: Region also spelled as Kashkadarya Region. Year marked uncertain because implementation dates are 2015-2020, but CDB loan appears to have been provided in 2017.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/vults7c3kv89j45/BU_PITCH_ENGLISH_2018.xlsx?dl=0, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=TREOGE0020170531ed5v0001t&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.azernews.az/region/142796.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.constructionboxscore.com/project-news/uzbekistan-raises-$23-billion-to-build-gtl-plant.aspx, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/oil-and-gas/uzbekistan-borrows-2-3-billion-for-gas-to-liquids-plant-project/67111971, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://invest.gov.uz/en/invest-projects-taxonomy/realizuemye-investitsionnye-proekty/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://invest.gov.uz/en/invest-projects-taxonomy/realizuemye-investitsionnye-proekty/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.gtai.de/GTAI/Navigation/DE/Trade/Maerkte/suche,t=usbekistan-errichtet-neue-petrochemie-und-gaskomplexe,did=1842842.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.ogj.com/articles/2017/06/uzbekistan-lets-contract-for-ethylene-expansion.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://as.ucpress.edu/content/ucpas/58/4/747.full.pdf, Academic Journal Article

title: China EXIM Bank and CDB USD denominated loan to Appolo Solar Development Pakistan Limited 100 MW solar power project (Linked to Project #50939, #53985) (CPEC, IPP)
description: Appolo Solar Development Pakistan Limited (ASDPL) is a 100 MW Solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, District Bahawalpur in the Province of Punjab. On June 27 2015 ASDPL signed Engineering, Procurement, Construction contracts with China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd and with MCC Ruba International Construction Company (Pvt) Ltd to build, own and operate a 100 MW AC Solar powered electric generation facility to be located at Bahawalpur, Punjab. On October 16, 2015 the company signed a Term Facility Agreement (TFA) with the Export-Import bank of China ('EXIM bank') and China Development Bank. The Company achieved Financial Closing on November 6, 2015. The Commercial Operation Date of the project was May 31, 2016. Total project cost is 149.154 USD Million, with a Debt-Equity ratio 79:21. China Development Bank and the Export Import Bank of China provided 2 syndicated loans, one worth 400 Million RMB which is equivalent to 62.93 USD Million (interest rate 2.65%), and a loan denominated in USD which amounts to 62.6 USD Million (interest rate 4.96%). These loans make up the 79% debt component. This project records the USD denominated loan. It is unclear how the equity component was financed.
sources: https://nepra.org.pk/Tariff/IPPs/002%20Solar%20IPPs/Appolo%20Solar%20Development%20Pakistan%20Limited/TRF-316%20ASDPL%20COD%2018869-71%2016-11-2017.PDF, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency; China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency

title: China EXIM Bank provides 945,551,000 CNY export credit for construction of IV Tier National Data Center in Kaliakoir
description: On April 15, 2016, Bangladesh announced plans to build a flagship Tier IV Data Center at Kaliakoir in Gazipur to store and process large amount of official data. The project cost totals US $153 million. According to an IJ Global report and the 2017 Commitment, Disbursement and Repayment of External (ODA) Loans (active) Report from Bangladesh‚Äôs Economic Relations Division, the Chinese EXIM provided 945,551,000 CNY worth of Export Credits. The same ERD report states that China had disbursed 189,110,000 CNY of the Export Credits, and Bangladesh had not repaid any of its debt. The transaction occurred in yuan. This project has a 2% interest rate, 5 year grace period, and 15-year maturity. The project was implemented by the Chinese-based ZTE Corp and overseen by the Bangladesh Computer Council. Media articles indicate that the data center has been constructed as of 2017, but the operational status of the data center was delayed by US sanctions on ZTE. In October 2018, the data center was undergoing operation tests.

title: China Finances Development of Three Gas-Condensate Fields in Uzbekistan for 377.5 million USD (Linked to #54069, #39659, and #39658)
description: In 2017, the Chinese National Petroleum Company (CNPC) and Uzbekneftegaz began developing three gas condensate fields in the Bukhara-Khiva region of Uzbekistan (Dengizkul, Kojadavlat, and Sharky Alat) for 377.5 million USD. The project is funded by a loan agreement with the Bank of China, under the guarantee of the CNPC. When the three fields are developed, they will produce 869.6 million cubic meters of natural gas for exportation and 6,400 tons of gas condensate for domestic markets annually. The project was scheduled to begin in 2014, but construction began on May 30th, 2017. The project will be implemented by three CNPC subsidiary companies: China Petroleum Engineering & Construction Corporation (CPECC) will develop the fields, designs, logistics, construction, and commissioning of facilities for the project; XIBU Drilling Engineering Company Ltd. will drill 10 production wells; and China National Logging Corporation will repair 6 wells and test production wells. In December 2017, the New Silk Road Oil and Gas Company Ltd (NSROG) founded as a joint venture by the CNPC and Uzbekneftegaz to oversee the project, started gas production in the Dengizkul field after the drilling of 2 new wells and repairing of 3 wells. NSROG announced that the Kojadavlat and Sharky Alat, specifically the 8 new wells and 3 damaged wells within these fields, were still under construction. A projected end date for the project has not been announced; however, construction was still occurring in September 2018. Leading up to the 2017 development of these fields, the China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development (CNODC), a subsidiary of CNPC, conducted a 5 year geologic oil survey for 359 million USD in 2006 (#54069), drilled 13 exploratory wells worth 260.2 million USD in 2011 (#39659), and 14.9 million USD for further oil exploration in 2012 (#39658). STAFF_NOTE: Spelling was a little different in each source for site names, specifically Sharky Alat vs. Sharqiy Alat and Dengizkul vs. Khojasayat (the name of the overall region). Role of the JV unclear as Chinese companies both funded and implemented the project. Terms of the loan are unclear.

title: China loan syndicate funds the development, construction and operation of the Bozoi-Shymkent part of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline (link to #40362)
description: The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline is a 1454 Kilometers long gas pipeline that will run through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. Construction of the pipeline was split into two stages. The first stage of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline, which comprises all sections of the Bozoi-Shymkent part, was completed in 2015, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 6 bcm per year. Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. In December 2016, a second stage of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline project, comprising a linear part of the pipeline with a total length of 311.0 km, was completed. In November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, which increased the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. ICA has announced that, by the end of 2019, it expects the construction of repair and maintenance sites, shift camps and the Beineu gas measuring station, as well as the telecommunications and the highway system will be completed. Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP, a joint venture between JSC KazTransGas and China National Petroleum Corporation (each with 50% interest) was established on January 18, 2011 to construct and operate the gas pipeline. KTG is a transportation company, which owns a 100% interest in several domestic regional gas distribution companies and a 100% interest in ICA, which in turn operates the largest natural gas pipeline network in Kazakhstan. In December 2012, the joint venture entered into a $1.8 billion syndicated loan facility with China Development Bank and Bank of China. The loan was to finance the development, construction and operation of the Bozoi-Shymkent part of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline. In February 2016, certain amendments to this facility were signed. Amounts due under this loan facility bear interest at a rate of three-month LIBOR plus 2.7% per annum until 30 December 2019 and, thereafter, at a rate of three-month LIBOR plus 3.2% per annum. For this project, 3M LIBOR + 2.7% is taken to be the interest rate. The loan is repayable in installments starting December 2017 and matures on 11 March 2028. The loan is secured by corporate guarantees from the Company and CNPC. As at 31 December 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.0 billion (KZT 341 billion). Construction of the Bozoi-Shymkent part started in September 2011. The construction of the Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent pipeline was first confirmed under the 'Agreement on cooperation in the construction and operation of the Kazakhstan-China gas pipeline', signed between the Governments of the Afghanistan and China on August 18, 2007. The agreement was then later amended on October 14, 2009. The Agreement on the Main Principles of Construction and Operation of the Kazakhstan-Chinese Gas Pipeline (AMP) was signed within the frame of the official visit of President Hu Jintao to Kazakhstan on June 12, 2010. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas deliveries to China pursuant to a contract concluded between KTG and PetroChina for the supply of 5 bcm of natural gas during the period from 15 October 2017 until 14 October 2018. The total estimated consideration under this agreement is U.S.$889.7 million. The price of gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement is linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. Negotiations are ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between KTG and PetroChina. BSGP and the Company expect the transportation of gas to China to increase in the coming years and, in order to facilitate such transportation, plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 (at an estimated cost of KZT 109.2 billion). See ‚ÄúManagement‚Äôs Discussion and Analysis of Results of Operations and Financial Performance‚ÄîCapital Expenditures‚Äù. In the year ended 31 December 2017, the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline transported 3.4 bcm of gas.

title: China offers hard loan of $224 million to Bangladesh for 3rd phase of expansion to Barapukuria power station (Linked to #33957)
description: In January 2014, ICBC offered Bangladesh a hard loan of $224 million to increase the capacity of the 250MW Barapukuria coal-fired thermal power station by 275 MW, the third phase of the expansions. The remainder of the estimated cost of the $330.52 million project was to be funded by the Bangladeshi government. The loan comes with an interest rate of 3.98 percent, a management fee of 1.5 percent, an insurance premium of 6.62 percent and commitment fee of 1 percent. Repayment period of the loan would be set at 13 years. On February 16, 2015 ICBC extended the loan to be valid beyond June 30, 2016. As of August 2, 2016, 40 percent of the power plant project is complete. Harbin Electric International and CCC contracting firm are implementing the project. The expected completion date is June 2018. STAFF_NOTE: The transaction value is set at 203,571,200 USD to reflect the 9.12% of the $224 million that are withheld in fees.

title: China provides $10m USD Supplier's Credit for Digital Telephone Exchange
description: In June 2004 China agreed to provide $10m USD in Supplier Credit to Bangladesh for the establishment of the Chittagong Hill Tracts Digital Radio Link and Telephone Exchange. A joint communique by the Chinese and Bangladesh governments in 2005 suggests that China had agreed to provide concessional loan for the project by 2005. According to a report from the Economic Relations Division of the Bangladeshi Government, 0.372 million of the pledged amount has been dispersed as of 2017.

title: China supports construction of Chukurbulak mudflow check dam on the Khorgos River
description: In June 2017, China and Kazakhstan signed an agreement on the construction of the Chukurbulak dam on the Khorgos River worth 11.7 billion tenge (34.4M USD) during the official visit of Chinese President Xi Jinping to Kazakhstan and was ratified by the Kazakh Senate on June 8 2018. The project is being co-financed by both parties. 3.8 billion tenge of the 2018-2020 Kazakh national budget is allocated for 2018. The construction of the dam includes a central reinforced concrete part (including the necessary metal structures), the ground part of the dam, the control and measuring system, the temporary bridge and drainage channel for passing water during the construction period, as well as the shore protection structures (dams) under the dam. The dam will halt approximately 10 million cubic meters of mudflow and will also protect people in the lower basin of the river. The dam will be built five kilometers upstream from the Dostyk Kazakh-Chinese hydraulic power system. Experts from both countries designed and estimated the cost of the project and a Kazakh-China committee will be established to manage the construction process. The operation and management will be determined by another agreement. The project began construction in April 2019 and is to be completed in 2021. STAFF_NOTE: No transaction amount recorded as financing allocation is unclear.

title: Chinese Banks loan 1.41 billion USD for 870 MW Suki Kinari Hydropower Project in Pakistan (Linked to #54309 and #54319) (CPEC, IPP)
description: The 870 MW Suki Kinari hydropower project developed by Suki Kinari Hydro (Private) Limited will be located on River Kunhar, District Mansehra, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. The project achieved financial close on January 9, 2017. The EPC Contractor is China Gezhouba group Company Ltd. On April 20, 2015, ICBC Chairman Jiang Jianqing signed power project financing agreements for four energy power projects in the presence of Chinese President Xi Jinping and Pakistani Prime Minister Sharif. The four energy power projects include Suki Kinari hydropower project, Dawood wind power project, Sahiwal coal-fired power plant, and Thar coal-power integrated project. According to the World Bank, the total project cost is 1.8 billion USD, financed through a debt equity ratio of 75:25. China Exim Bank and ICBC each provided a loan of 708.1 Million USD. A Tariff Determination Petition document in 2014 puts the interest rate of the loan at 4.91%, the repayment period at 12 years, and the grace period at 5 years. The construction activities at the site of the project had already commenced and the project was expected to start injecting 3,081GWh million clean reliable and affordable units of electricity each year to the national grid by 2022. The equity financing of the project was to be arranged by the shareholders of Suki Kinari Hydro (Private) Limited, and according to IJGlobal, China Gezhouba Group Corporation, Al Jomaih and Eden each invested 160.09 Million USD. Update: The first Sahiwal coal-fired power plant was reported as successfully completed and inaugurated May 2017 by the Prime Minister of Pakistan. The second plant is scheduled to begin energy production in June 2017. Project also received a No Objection Certificate (NoC) from Pakistan's Environment Protection Department.

title: Chinese EXIM Bank Concessionally Loans 1.75 billion USD for RPCL-NORINCO Intl. Power Ltd.'s Debt Portion of Patuakhali 1320 (2 x 600) MW Coal Fired Thermal Power Plant (linked to projects # # # # # #)
description: In 2017, the Chinese EXIM loaned approximately 1.75 to RPCL-NORINCO Intl. Power Ltd. (RNPL) for the construction of the Patuakhali 1320 (2 x 600) MW Coal Fired Thermal Power Plant. RNPL is a joint venture between Rural Power Company Ltd. (RPCL) and NORINCO Intl. formed in 2017 for the construction of this power plant. RPCL is a Bangladeshi state-owned electrification enterprise and NORINCO Intl. is a Chinese state-owned arms manufacturing company. The two state-owned enterprises registered their venture, RPCL-NORINCO Intl. Power Ltd. (RNPL) with the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies and Firms on December 27, 2017. The total project will cost around 2.5 billion USD. The project will be constructed with a 70:30 debt:equity ratio. RPCL and NORINCO each hold 50% of the equity. At the time of creation, RNPL had 200,000,000 BDT, with a maximum authorized capital of 400,000,000 BDT. The value of the Chinese equity funding is unclear. At the time of creation, RNPL had 200,000,000 BDT, with a maximum authorized capital of 400,000,000 BDT. Since NORINCO held 50% of RNPL‚Äôs equity, the NORINCO funding could be equal to 100,000,000 BDT (approximately 1.2 million USD in December 2017). However, since the total project cost is 2.5 billion USD, and NORINCO provided half of the 30% equity funding, the NORINCO funding could be valued at 15% of 2.5 billion USD, or 375 million USD. To avoid inaccurately representing the value of this investment, no transaction amount is recorded. The Chinese EXIM Bank will provide a loan for the debt portion. RPCL Managing Director M Abdus Sabur said that the Chinese EXIM bank loan will have a 4% interest rate, a 5 year grace period, and a 20 year maturity. This project only tracks the debt funding that came from the Chinese EXIM Bank loan. The value of this loan is not explicitly stated. However, RNPL stated that the total project cost is 2.5 billion USD, and that 70% of the funding would come from the Chinese EXIM Bank loan. RNPL will construct a coal jetty, coal import-handling facilities, coal storage, the power plant, transmission facilities, roads, and the town surrounding the plant. The project will process 12273 tons of coal per day and sell power to the Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB). This power plant will operate on 915.74 acres of land. The plant will displace 350 families, so RPCL will set up a village with schools, shops, community centers, and mosques. Hoda Vasi Chowdhury & Co is auditing RNPL. [INCLUDE DISCLAIMER ABOUT ALL THE LINKED PROJECTS; sources; contacts] STAFF_NOTE: The exact commitment date of this loan is unclear. However, the RPCL Managing Director announced the loan terms in November 2017, the same month the two firms signed the joint venture agreement, making November 2017 likely the time of the commitment.
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: Rural Power Company Ltd. (RPCL), State-Owned Company; Norinco, State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: Rural Power Company Ltd. (RPCL), State-Owned Company

title: Chinese EXIM Bank and ICBC provide 129,264,152.64 worth of export credits for construction of 150 MW Kodda Power Plant
description: In 2013, China EXIM Bank and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China agreed to provide 129,264,152.64 USD worth of export credits to BR Powergen to build the Kodda 150MW power plant in the Gazipur District of Dhaka. The China National Electric Import & Export Corporation, Jiangsu Construction Engineering Company, and Fujian Electric Power Engineering Company formed a syndicate to construct the power plant. BR Powergen signed their engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contract with the aforementioned companies on January 3, 2013. BR Powergen signed the loan agreement for the export credits on July 2, 2013. BR Powergen signed their Power Purchase Agreement with the Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB) on November 3, 2013. BR Powergen signed their fuel supply agreement on December 5, 2013. Construction on the Kodda Power Plant on January 28 2014 and finished on August 15, 2015. The plant runs on two fuel sources: heavy fuel oil and gas. According to B-R Powergen's 2017-2018 Annual Report, the EPC contract with the construction syndicate is worth 155,842,358.61 USD. The project had an additional cost of 8,224,274.00 USD for insurance, which BR Powergen paid to the Ministry of Finance of Bangladesh. BR Powergen and the Ministry of Finance signed their agreement on October 23, 2013. This project has a debt:equity ratio of 85:15. The debt has a two year grace period, a 12 year maturity, with an interest rate set at the 6-month LIBOR rate + 3.19%, leading to an interest rate of 3.593% at the time of signing. Payments are sent every 6 months, with the first payment made in July 2016. At the start of 2017, BR Powergen still owed 9,988,130,809 BDT. During 2017, they paid 1,024,418,309 BDT, but the outstanding debt increased by 76,589,003 BDT to adjust for foreign exchange risk. During 2018, BR Powergen paid 1,066,105,994 BDT to reduce their outstanding debt to 7,974,195,509 BDT. MAN Diesel & Turbo SE, Germany manufactured the plant's engine. STAFF_NOTE: The LIBOR rate was not identified in any of the attached reports, so this project uses the average 6 Month LIBOR rate from July 2013 (when the financing agreement was signed) of 0.403% for the interest rate calculation. The total interest rate is 0.403% + 3.19% = 3.593%

title: Chinese EXIM Bank provides $64 million in preferential buyer's credit to build Padma Water Plant in Bangladesh (linked to #38967)
description: In 2013, China committed to provide Bangladesh with $291 million to build the Padma (Josholdia) Water Treatment Plant, as a water treatment and sanitisation facility. China lent $227 million under a concessional loan from the EXIM Bank (reflected in #38967) and $64 million under the Preferential Buyer's Credit. The terms of both are 2% interest with a repayment period of 20 years (with a grace period of 5 years), with management and commitment fees at the rate of 0.2 per cent. The Dhaka Water and Sewage Authority contracted the Chinese SOE, CAMC Engineering Co. to construct the plant. Construction started in January 2013, and is expected to be completed by June 2016. As of 2018, the Bangladesh Bridge Authority reported significant delays, resulting in the project being overdue.

title: Chinese bank syndicate loaned 200 million USD to Thar Coal Block II Mine (linked to #35127, #53968)
description: Sindh Engro Coal Mining Company (SECMC) is developing a coal mine of 3.8 million tonnes per annum capacity which will supply coal to a 2 X 330 (660MW) mine mouth Circulating Fluidized Bed Technology Coal-Based Power Plant at Thar Block II, 25 KM from city of Islamkot, near village of Singharo-Bitra, District Tharparkar, Sindh. Sindh Engro Coal Mining Company Limited (SECMC) is a joint venture between Government of Sindh (54.7%), Engro Powergen Limited (EPL) (11.9%) and its Affiliate Engro Powergen Thar Limited (EPTL) (11.9%), Habib Bank Limited (9.5%), Hub Power Company Ltd (8%), China Machinery Engineering Corporation (4%). Thar Block II is a 95.5 square kilometer (km2) area of the Thar coalfield, which has total lignite reserves of 175 Billion tons which can be utilized to produce 100,000 Megawatt (MW) for over 200 years. The coal mine project will cost 911 Million USD, and the EPC contractor is CMEC. Commercial Operation Date for Phase 1 of both Projects is expected to be in mid ‚Äì 2019. The debt-equity ratio is 75:25. According to IJGlobal, a consortium of local banks will provide 500 Million USD and a consortium of Chinese banks will provide 200 Million USD to finance the debt component of the project. The Chinese banks include ICBC, China Construction Bank and China Development Bank, and the local banks include Habib Bank, United Bank, Bank Alfalah, Askari Bank, Meezan Bank, the Bank of Punjab, Nib Bank, Soneri Bank, Sinduh Bank, National Bank of Pakistan and Faysal Bank. The exact loan terms are not known. This project records the debt financing. The equity financing details can be found in Project #53968. The project achieved financial closure in April 2016. In September 2017, it was reported project was in the process of dewatering three of the aquifers in the mine, with all challenges being addressed in a timely manner. The water drained from the three aquifers would recycled later for the That Coal Block-II power projects operational work. In December 2017, it was reported that half of the work on That Coal Block-II was completed and that the project is to be completed and functioning by August of 2019 and have a capacity of 1.32 gigawatts but divided into four mine-mouth power plants and mining 7.6 million tonnes of coal per year.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/q5lthzouc1lftfi/IJGlobal%20-%20Thar%20Coal%20Block%20II%20Mine%20-%20Pakistan.pdf?dl=0, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASMESG0020170911ed990000h&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), State-Owned Company; China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency; China Construction Bank Corporation (CCB), State-Owned Company

title: Chinese bank syndicate loaned 621 million to 2 X 330 MW Engro Thar Block II coal power project project (Linked to Project #54316, #54315) (CPEC, IPP)
description: Engro Powergen Thar Limited (EPTL) will establish a 2 X 330 (660MW) mine mouth Circulating Fluidized Bed Technology Coal-Based Power Plant at Thar Block II, 25 KM from city of Islamkot, near village of Singharo-Bitra, District Tharparkar, Sindh. EPTL is a Joint Venture Company of Engro Powergen China Machinery and Engineering Company(CMEC), Habib Bank Limited and Liberty Mills Limited. Thar Block II is a 95.5 square kilometer (km2) area of the Thar coalfield, which has total lignite reserves of 175 Billion tons which can be utilized to produce 100,000 Megawatt (MW) for over 200 years. The project will be fueled by coal supplied by Sindh Engro Coal Mining Company (SECMC), which is developing a coal mine of 3.8 million tonnes per annum capacity beside the project. The coal mine project will cost 845,000 USD, and the EPC contractor is CMEC. Commercial Operation Date for Phase 1 of both Projects is expected to be in mid ‚Äì 2019. In December 2014, ICBC Karachi Branch submitted an expression of interest for debt arrangement of 825 million USD for the coal-based power project. According to the letter, the total project cost is expected to be approximately 1100 Million USD which will be funded in debt-equity ratio of 75:25. Accordingly, total equity requirement will be 275 Million USD. The majority of the equity investment for the project was expected to be from EPTL and its affiliates. According to EPTL's website, in 2015, financing agreements were signed in Beijing for both the power plant project and the mining project. Under these agreements, a syndicate of local banks committed to provide around USD 500 million for the mining and around 240 million USD for power plant. The local syndicate is led by Habib Bank Limited, United Bank Limited, Bank Alfalah Limited, National Bank Pakistan and Faysal Bank Limited. In addition, a syndicate of Chinese Banks consisting of China Development Bank, Construction Bank of China and ICBC are providing loans amounting to around 820 million USD for both projects. The World Bank's Private Participation in Infrastructure database reports that for the coal power plant, the 3 Chinese banks will each pay 207 million USD, with Sinosure providing a loan guarantee of 621 Million USD. According to a March 2015 NEPRA document, the interest rate of the loan is 4.95%. For determination of the upfront tariff, the repayment period was assumed to be 10 years, and the grace period was assumed to be the same as the construction period, which is 40 months. This project has thus recorded the loan details as such. In September 2017, it was reported project was in the process of dewatering three of the aquifers in the mine, with all challenges being addressed in a timely manner. The water drained from the three aquifers would recycled later for the That Coal Block-II power projects operational work. In December 2017, it was reported that half of the work on That Coal Block-II was completed and that the project is to be completed and functioning by August of 2019 and have a capacity of 1.32 gigawatts but divided into four mine-mouth power plants and mining 7.6 million tonnes of coal per year.

title: Colombo Port City Project - Phase 1: China Development Bank Loan (link to project ID #55528)
description: On 16 September 2014, China Communications Construction (CCC) signed the Colombo Port City Franchise Agreement with the Sri Lanka Ports Authority, outlining an investment for the Colombo Port City Project (now known as the Colombo International Financial City). On this same day, China Development Bank signed an 805 million USD commercial loan financing agreement with CCC for this project (see attached 2014 article CDB). The 805 million USD loan from China Development Bank for the Colombo Port City Project is captured in this project. For details regarding the equity investment from CCC, see linked project ID #55528. The Colombo Port City Project is divided into two phases. The main components of the first phase are land reclamation of about 269 Ha (91 will be designated for public use such as recreational parks), a canal with a length of 2,000 meters and a width of about 70 meters, a breakwater with a total length of 3,245 meters (with sandbanks on both sides) and 10 Ha of beach, the construction and maintenance of the infrastructure, road sales and development of roads, green spaces, water supply and drainage, power supply, communications and other pipelines in the first phase of the planning area. The main components of the second phase are infrastructure construction of roads, green spaces, water supply and drainage, power supply, communications and other pipelines in the planned area of ‚Äã‚Äãthe second phase. According to the project company website, the key objectives of reclaiming 269 Ha of land are to create a regional business hub, with high quality public spaces and infrastructure facilities, to create a tourism hub with attractions such as shopping, culture and entertainment, to foster integrated living to provide high quality resident facilities and amenities such as parks, water sports, schools, hospitals, etc., and to generate investment in real estate development and service sector jobs (see 'FAQ' section of CHEC Port City Colombo website). The total investment for the project (phases I & II) is about 1.396 billion USD. The first phase investment is 1.15 billion USD, and the second phase investment is 246 million USD (see attached resource from CPPPC). The debt:equity ratio for the first phase of the project is 70:30. The debt component of the first phase of the Colombo Port City Project is financed by the 805 million USD China Development Bank loan (see September 2018 article from CCC), and the loan has a maturity of 10 years, including a 3 year grace period (see CPPPC article). This loan was provided by the Guangxi Branch of China Development Bank, and as of May 2017 CDB had disbursed 938 million RMB of the total loan amount (see July 2018 article from Guangxi Regional Government Office). CCC contributed to the equity component of the project, but the specific investment is unclear. The 2017 Government of Sri Lanka Bond Prospectus indicates that the total Chinese funding committed for the Colombo Port City Project was 1.337 billion USD, so it seems likely that the total investment from CCC for both phases of the project is 532 million USD. It is still unclear how phase two of the project will be financed, but the debt:equity ratio will again be 70:30. According to the 2017 Government of Sri Lanka Bond Prospectus, the Sri Lanka Ministry of Megapolis and Western Development has allocated approximately Rs. 94 million in 2017 to develop the infrastructure facilities of the proposed port city development project. Construction of the Colombo Port City project was launched on 17 September 2014 by Sri-Lankan President Mahinda Rajapaska and the Chinese President Xi Jinping, with 39 months planned for the completion of the project (see September 2014 articles from CHEC). Project construction was halted in January 2015 to receive proper permits and approvals. According to the CHEC website, a comprehensive back-to-work order was issued to the contractor on 13 September 2016, and the reclamation work formally began on 29 September 2016 (see October 2016 article from CHEC). Upon recommencement, the project was now known as the Colombo Financial City, instead of the Colombo Port City Project (see 2017 Government of Sri Lanka Bond Prospectus). On 16 January 2019 the completion ceremony of the 269 Ha land reclamation work was held, which was two months ahead of schedule (see January 2019 CHEC article). As of April 2019, the overall progress of the project was at 95% completion according to the project company website. The land reclamation progress was at 100% completion, the ground progress at 86% completion, and the breakwater progress at 91% completion (see CHEC Port City Colombo 'Master Plan'). To undertake this project, China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC) set up the investment company CHEC Port City Colombo (Pvt) Ltd. This investment company is a 100% owned subsidiary of CHEC, and CCC is the parent company of CHEC (see 'About' and 'FAQ' pages of CHEC Port City Colombo website). All lands reclaimed by the Project Company will be owned by the Urban Development Authority of Sri Lanka. The Project Company would be allocated 116 Ha of the total saleable/marketable land, and the Government of Sri Lanka would be allocated 62 Ha of this land. The remaining 91 Ha is common land owned by the Government of Sri Lanka, which roads and parks. The Project Company will therefore enjoy commercial benefits from only 43% of the reclaimed land. The Government of Sri Lanka will lease the 116 Ha of marketable land to the Project Company for 99 years, after which time fresh 99 year leases may be granted to third party developers.

title: HDC Hulhumale Development Phase II - 7000 housing units
description: On August 14th, 2017, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) loaned 368.9 million USD (5,681,060,000 MVR) to the Housing Development Corporation (HDC) for the construction of 7,000 apartments in Hulhumale, which falls under the Maldives Housing Development Corporation's plan to build 15,000 housing units in Hulhumale (Hulhumale Development Phase II). The total project cost for the 7,000 housing unit development is 434 million USD, and Credit Suisse will provide the remaining 65.1 million USD. ICBC granted the loan to be paid within 15 years, with an interest less than four percent. At the end of September 2018, the disbursed outstanding debt was 209,076,877 USD. The project is being implemented by Maldives' state owned HDC and state owned China State Construction Engineering Corp. The total construction area is 451,900 square meters and the project includes 16 high-rise (25 story) buildings. The 7,000 social housing flats will measure 550 square feet each, featuring two bedrooms and two bathrooms. All construction materials such as steel and cement will be transported from China. As of November 20, 2017, the contractor had started the construction. The project is slated to be completed in 2019. The main difference between this project and another 2500 unit housing project in Hulhumale Phase II (see project ID #54276) is that the proposed buildings for the 2500 housing unit project are all 15-17 stories high, while this 7000 housing unit project includes buildings of 25 stories high (see p. 4 of EIA document).

title: HVDC project from Matiari To Lahore in Pakistan Debt component (Linked to project #53695) [CPEC]
description: The ¬±660kV HVDC Project from Matiari to Lahore is planned to be completed and put into operation around 2021 with a capacity of 4000MW. The line extends about 878km from Matiari of Sindh Province to Lahore of Punjab Province. The Transmission Line Project will evacuate power generated from coal based plants located at Thar, Port Qasim and Hub. According to financial proposals submitted by Pak Matiari-Lahore Transmission Company (Private) Limited in 2017, the total project cost of USD1.658 billion will be financed through a debt to equity structure of 80 : 20. Overseas investment company of State Grid of China, State Grid International Engineering Limited, will provide about USD332 million as the equity through 2 Special Purpose Vehicles. CDB will provide a loan of 1.326 billion USD (linked to project #54013). This is a CPEC project. The interest rate is calculated using 6 Months LIBOR Rate as of March 2017 (when the financial proposal is submitted), 1.426% + 4.5% = 5.926%, grace period of 27 months, provided by the NEPRA Tariff Determination document, and maturity period of 12.25 years. This is the first HVDC transmission project in Pakistan. It will be constructed by State Grid Corporation of China using a BOOT model and have a commercial operation period of 25 year.

title: ICBC Loans $166.67 million USD for the Tiroda Thermal Power Project in India (Linked to #53783)
description: On April 22nd, 2013, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) loaned $166,670,000 USD for the construction of the 3300 MW Tiroda Thermal Power Project, which comprises 5x660 MW units. The Tiroda Thermal Power is also called the Gondia Coal-Fired Project. The loan has a maturity of ten years. The project was constructed by the Adani Power Maharashtra Ltd (APML). The first unit of the plant was commissioned on 28th August 2012 and subsequently, other units were commissioned. The project was commissioned on October 11th, 2014. The Tiroda Thermal Power Project was also funded by a $166.67 million USD loan by the CDB (project #53783) and a $166.66 million USD loan by the Standard Chartered Bank, both under the same loan conditions.

title: ICBC and China EXIM Bank loan 231.3 million USD for BPDB's Shahjibazar power project
description: In June 2014, the Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB) signed a 13-year $257 million export credit deal in support of the 330 megawatt Shahjibazar power project, located in Habiganj, Sylhet, Northeast of Bangladesh. The Guangdong Power Engineering Corporation (GPEC) and the Guangdong Electric Power Design Institute (GEDI) of China Energy Engineering Group signed a May 2013 agreement for an Engineering, Procurement, and Construction (EPC) project. The British-based HSBC, Chinese EXIM Bank, and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) formed a consortium to fund 95% of the project. The ICBC covered 55% of the cost, the Chinese EXIM Bank covered 35% of the cost, and HSBC covered 10% of the cost. This project only reports the 90% of the $257 million ($231.3 million) that came from Chinese financiers. Both Sinosure and the Ministry of Finance of Bangladesh insured this transaction. Commencement ceremony took place in August 20, 2014. On December 26, 2016, the plant was put into commercial operation. The maturity of this project is 13 years, but the interest rate and grace period are unknown.

title: Katana Water Supply Project
description: The China Development Bank provided a loan of US$54.8 million to Sri Lanka for the Katana water supply project, which was signed on August 21, 2017. The goal of the project is to provide safe drinking water via pipes to all 45 Grama Niladdhari divisions in Katana Divisional Secretariat, which covers 50% of the population in that area. This involves the construction of three towers at Bambukuliya, Ewariwatta and Thibirigaskatuwa, and the laying of transmission and distribution mains and supplying and supplying and installation of pumps. The project is expected to take three years and cost a total of US$64.5 million. The remaining US$9.7 million is provided by the Bank of Ceylon (state-owned, commercial, Sri Lankan Bank). The Sri Lanka National Water Supply & Drainage Board is implementing this project, and as of the end of 2017, the project is still under implementation. This project is one of the four water supply projects under implementation in Sri Lanka funded by the China Development Bank. The other three projects are: 54435 (Gampaha, Attanagalla and Minuwangoda Integrated Water Supply Scheme), 53567 (Thambuttegama water supply), and 53568 (Valachchenai Water Supply Project and Banadarawela, Diyathalawa and Haputhale Water Supply Project).
sources: http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/Publications/ERDReport2017/ERDReport2017-English.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=97:recently-signed-water-projects-china-division&catid=30&lang=en&Itemid=225, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline (Kenkiyak-Kumkol) (linked to #39605 and #54523)
description: JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed joint venture Limited Liability Partnership Kazakhstan-China Pipeline (KCP) on July 6, 2004, to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, comprising two of three pipeline systems forming the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstan oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owns 50% of the joint venture. The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network comprises three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are currently operational. The Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured in #39605. As at 31 December 2017, the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline had a total length of 962 km of pipe with diameters between 0.5 m and 1.8 m. In the year ended 31 December 2017, the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline transported 12.3 million tonnes of crude oil. The Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline was completed in October 2009 with a total of 794 km of pipe with diameter of 813mm, and as at 31 December 2017, the length of the pipeline was 794.0 km and had a throughput capacity of 9.2 million tonnes of crude oil per year. In the year ended 31 December 2017, the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline transported 5.2 million tonnes of crude oil. Pursuant to an agreement between the Company and CNODC, the capacity of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline increased to 20 million tonnes of crude oil in 2015, which is expected to enable the Company to accommodate the expected increased production at the Tengiz Field, as well as production at the Kashagan Field when commercial production achieves its expected potential. Ten companies supply oil to the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. This project records the financing to the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. On 12 August 2008, KCP entered into a U.S.$1.18 billion credit facility with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited and ING Bank N.V. with a term of ten years, subject to extension for up to five additional years. This credit facility was entered into for the purpose of financing construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. KCP had the right to draw down the loan in four tranches, three of which were drawn down during 2008 in an aggregate principal amount of U.S.$1.0 billion. The availability period for this credit facility expired at the end of 2011. Amounts borrowed under the facility accrued interest at a rate of six-month LIBOR plus 2% per annum until February 2013 and six-month LIBOR plus 4% per annum thereafter and are guaranteed by CNPC. As at 31 December 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this facility was U.S.$403.9 million (including the capitalised interest) (KZT 134.3 billion). Based on the information above, the interest rate is recorded as 6 Month Libor in August 2008 (3.108%) + 2%, which is 5.108%. Maturity period is 10 years and grace period is 0. STAFF_NOTE: As the loan financiers include a non-Chinese financier - ING Bank N.V., and the breakdown of loan amounts between the 2 financiers are not known, a transaction amount has not been recorded for this project. However, IJ Global reported that there are 6 financiers - ING Bank, ICBC, CDB, China Exim Bank, Bank of China, Bank of Communications, and that each one contributed 196.67 Million USD. CRS sector 32262 (oil and gas).
sources: http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/projects/project1?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/company/about?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
funding_agency: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), State-Owned Company
implementing_agency: China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC), State-Owned Company

title: Kazakhstan-China Pipeline refinanced notes issued in 2005 through facility agreement with ICBC (linked to #40833)
description: JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed joint venture Limited Liability Partnership Kazakhstan-China Pipeline (KCP) on July 6, 2004, to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, comprising two of three pipeline systems forming the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstan oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owns 50% of the joint venture. The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network comprises three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are currently operational. In August 2013, KCP entered into a U.S.$300.0 million facility agreement with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited and ICBC Almaty for the purpose of refinancing its notes issued in 2005. Loans drawn down under this facility bear interest at a rate of six-month LIBOR plus 3.75% per annum. As at 31 December 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was U.S.$180.0 million (KZT 59.8 billion). Based on this information, interest rate is recorded as 6M LIBOR in August 2013 (0.395%) + 3.75% = 4.145%

title: Line C of Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, Uzbekistan section (linked to #40833)
description: Uzbekneftegaz National Holding Company and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) created a joint venture named Asia Trans Gas in April 2008 for construction of the Uzbekistan section of the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline (also known as Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline) Line C. Line C is 1830 km in length, 529km of which is within Uzbekistan. With a designed capacity of 25 billion cubic meters per annum, Line C‚Äôs pipe diameter is 1,219mm, 152mm larger than Line A/B. Line C starts at Turkmenistan-Uzbekistan border and ends at Horgos, in the Xinjiang region of China. According to CNPC, construction of Line C was started in September 2012, and the overall welding work of the pipeline was completed at the end of 2013. Line C became operational in May 2014. The total project cost of Line C Uzbekistan segment was 2.2 billion USD. China Development Bank provided a loan of 1.2 billion USD to Asia Trans Gas to this project. The exact commitment year is unknown, and the year which CNPC and Uzbekneftegaz signed an agreement on construction and operation of Line C of the Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline (September 21, 2011), is taken as the commitment year. STAFF_NOTES: No loan details were found regarding this project.
sources: http://www.cnpc.com.cn/en/FlowofnaturalgasfromCentralAsia/FlowofnaturalgasfromCentralAsia2.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://uz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/tupxw/200912/20091206674970.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pfie.com/Journals/2014/02/12/o/l/l/PFILeagueTables2013.pdf, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.agp.com.kz/?p=1605, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: Part II: China's financial package loan includes buyer credit of $2.250 billion USD to Pakistan for Karachi Nuclear Power Plant's K-2/K-3 (Linked to Project ID #41916 and #41918)
description: On January 14, 2014 China Exim Bank agreed to a mixed credit of $6.5 billion USD to finance Pakistan's Karachi Nuclear Power Plant's K-2/K-3 projects. The inter-government framework agreement went through various stages of approval until February 18, 2014. The groundbreaking ceremony of the 2000 MW energy plants, took place in November 2013. The project is being jointly financed by China Export-Import Bank in the form of a 'mixed credit' at a ratio 81.97 [$6.5 bn] with Pakistan financing 18.03 percent (the Pakistani government will have to mark up against this loan at a rate of 3.20 %). The terms of the financial package are as follows:(i) Government concessional loan of RMB 2.647bn (with interest @ 1pc per annum)[approved FEb 18, 2014]; (ii) preferential buyer credit of $4.001bn (with interest @ 2pc per annum); and (iii) buyer credit of $2.250bn (with interest @ 6pc per annum) China developed the ACP-1000 reactor, which cost about $5 billion each to build, bringing the total cost of the project up to US$10 billion.The construction is being managed by China National Nuclear Corporation, using Hualon One technology (the CNNC's third-generation nuclear reactor design). STAFF_NOTE: NOV 18 2018 South and Central Asia Scrape A Pakistani ministry of finance monthly project status report in May 2015-16 records the project as a loan of USD2,050.00 million, which is slightly lower than the source above. Stage 2 needed.
sources: http://www.brecorder.com/fuel-a-energy/193:pakistan/1157769:two-nuclear-power-plants-exim-bank-agrees-to-extend-65-billion-credit/?date=2015-03-05, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/10-billion-pak-nuclear-power-plant-to-be-built-by-china/article7561473.ece, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2015/03/26/business/exim-bank-to-facilitate-construction-of-nuclear-power-plant/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.financialexpress.com/article/world-news/pakistan-to-begin-work-on-third-unit-of-karachi-nuclear-plant-soon/270852/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.world-nuclear.org/information-library/country-profiles/countries-o-s/pakistan.aspx, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.dawn.com/news/1143822, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.dawn.com/news/1167800, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/kyodo-news-international/130613/pakistan-start-work-chinese-aided-nuclear-power-plant, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sbp.org.pk/reports/quarterly/fy15/Second/Chap-4.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/press_releases.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/releases_mar_15.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.theanalystworld.com/chinese-investment-in-pakistan-rhetoric-or-reality/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ead.gov.pk/frmDetails.aspx, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Part III: China's financial package loan includes preferential buyer credit of $4.001 billion USD to Pakistan for Karachi Nuclear Power Plant's K-2/K-3 (Project ID linked to #41916 and #41917)
description: On January 14, 2014 China Exim Bank agreed to a mixed credit of $6.5 billion USD to finance Pakistan's Karachi Nuclear Power Plant's K-2/K-3 projects. The inter-government framework agreement went through various stages of approval until February 18, 2014. The groundbreaking ceremony of the 2000 MW energy plants, took place in November 2013. The project is being jointly financed by China Export-Import Bank in the form of a 'mixed credit' at a ratio 81.97 [$6.5 bn] with Pakistan financing 18.03 percent (the Pakistani government will have to mark up against this loan at a rate of 3.20 %). The terms of the financial package are as follows:(i) Government concessional loan of RMB 2.647bn (with interest @ 1pc per annum)[approved FEb 18, 2014]; (ii) preferential buyer credit of $4.001bn (with interest @ 2pc per annum); and (iii) buyer credit of $2.250bn (with interest @ 6pc per annum) China developed the ACP-1000 reactor, which cost about $5 billion each to build, bringing the total cost of the project up to US$10 billion.The construction is being managed by China National Nuclear Corporation, using Hualon One technology (the CNNC's third-generation nuclear reactor design). STAFF_NOTE: NOV 18 2018 South and Central Asia Scrape A Pakistani ministry of finance monthly project status report in May 2015-16 records the project as a loan of the same amount.
sources: http://www.brecorder.com/fuel-a-energy/193:pakistan/1157769:two-nuclear-power-plants-exim-bank-agrees-to-extend-65-billion-credit/?date=2015-03-05, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/10-billion-pak-nuclear-power-plant-to-be-built-by-china/article7561473.ece, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2015/03/26/business/exim-bank-to-facilitate-construction-of-nuclear-power-plant/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.financialexpress.com/article/world-news/pakistan-to-begin-work-on-third-unit-of-karachi-nuclear-plant-soon/270852/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.world-nuclear.org/information-library/country-profiles/countries-o-s/pakistan.aspx, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.dawn.com/news/1143822, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.dawn.com/news/1167800, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/kyodo-news-international/130613/pakistan-start-work-chinese-aided-nuclear-power-plant, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sbp.org.pk/reports/quarterly/fy15/Second/Chap-4.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/press_releases.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/releases_mar_15.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.theanalystworld.com/chinese-investment-in-pakistan-rhetoric-or-reality/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Shahjalal Fertilizer Factory: China Exim Bank Preferential Buyer's Credit (link to project ID #34230)
description: In December 2011, the Chinese Government signed an agreement for China Exim Bank to provide a USD 325 million Preferential Buyer's Credit to Bangladesh Chemical Industries Corporation for the construction of the Shahjalal Fertiliser Factory. Construction began in January 2012 by China National Complete Plant Import and Export Corporation Ltd and the plant was handed over on 29 February 2016, although it was planned for completion in June 2015. The factory has an annual production capacity of 580,800 MTPY. Based on a document from the Shahjalal Fertilizer Company Limited (SFCL) website, the project's debt-equity ratio is about 80:20, with the Chinese Government and China Exim Bank funding the debt portion amounting to USD 560 million. The breakdown of the debt portion is as follows: 1.60 billion RMB Yuan (about USD 235 million) from a Chinese Government concessional loan, and about USD 325 million preferential buyer's credit from Exim Bank of China. For the purpose of this project, only the USD 325 million buyer's credit from China Exim Bank is recorded. For details on the 1.60 billion RMB Yuan loan from the Chinese Government, please see linked project ID #34230. STAFF_NOTE: In the document from the Shahjalal Fertilizer Company Limited (SFCL) website, the public assistance is listed as USD 560 million from China, or 39,860,800,000 Taka. Therefore, the exchange rate used was 1 USD = 71.18 Taka. Using this exchange rate, the funding listed from Government of Bangladesh in the document (8,883,672,000 Taka) would equal about USD 124.8 million.

title: Supplier Credit for Barapukuria Power Plant (Linked to #34237)
description: In June 2001, China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC) and the Bangladeshi government signed an agreement that four Chinese companies (China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation, Shanghai Electric Corporation, China and Shenzhen Energy Engineering Corporation, and Consortium of the People's Republic of China) would provide Taka 1073.36 crore, equivalent to 188.10 million US dollars under supplier's credit to to implement two 125 MW coal power plants in Dinajpur. CMC was awarded the contract by the Bangladesh Power Development Board for the construction of Barapukuria 2X125 megawatts Coal-Fired Power Plant Project in July 2001. In 2002, China and Bangladesh signed an MoU to construct the Barapukuria (Dinajpur) coal fired power plant, consisting of two 125 MW units, implemented and constructed by the China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC). After three years of construction since November 2002, the first unit was successfully put into operation in mid November 2005, and the second in 2006. According to the Suppliers' Credit report from the Economic Relations Division (ERD) of the Bangladeshi Government, 124.126 million of the loan has been repaid as of June 30, 2017.

title: Tire Plant in 'Angren' Special Economic Zone
description: In August 2014, China Poly Group signed a contract with Uzbekistan National Chemical Company to oversee the engineering, procurement and construction of a USD 213.9 million tire plant in Special Economic Zone 'Angren', which would be partially funded by a USD 156.37 million loan from the Export-Import Bank of China. Construction began on August 28th, 2014 and was expected to last 34 months. The first tire was produced on trial on September 1st, 2017, and production gradually increased during the end of 2017. The project was officially completed on 25 July 2018. The plant's initial production capacity is 3 million car tires, 200,000 agricultural tires and 100,000 linear meters of conveyor belts for cleaning equipment per year. All production equipment and processes were sourced from China. Based on information provided from various sources including Tire Industry Research and Asaka Bank, the project's debt-equity ratio is about 70:30, with China Exim Bank funding the debt portion amounting to USD 156.37 million. The Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan, O'zimyosanoat, O'zavtosanoat, the Navoi Mining and Smelting Plant, and Almalyk Mining and Smelting Plant are funding the equity portion, although the breakdown of the USD 57.53 million equity portion is unclear. For the purpose of this project, only the USD 156.37 million loan from China Exim Bank has been recorded.
