title: Ustyurt Natural Gas and Petrochemicals Complex at Surgil Gas Field
description: In May 2012, a consortium of banks including the China Development Bank signed a $2.54 billion finance deal with Uzbekneftegaz for the Ustiurt gas-chemical complex (Ustyurt gas-chemical complex), which was completed in September of 2015 (ahead of schedule). The project will have a total value of $4 billion and the mega-project will be based in the Surgil Gas field. The complex will consist of a gas separation plant, units producing 400,000 tonnes per year of high-density polyethylene, 100,000 tonnes of polypropylene, and 110,000 tonnes of pryolised gasoline beginning in 2016. Uz-Kor Gas, the project SPV, is a joint venture between Uzbekneftegaz and Kor-Uz, a consortium of Korean firms. Based on information from IJGlobal Project Finance & Infrastructure Journal, the project's debt-equity ratio is about 65:35, with the debt portion amounting to USD 2.539 billion. China Development Bank is providing about 10% of the debt portion at a value of USD 250 million with a maturity of 16 years. For the purpose of this project, only the USD 250 million loan from CDB has been recorded. The breakdown of the remaining 90% of the debt portion is as follows: 1. USD 700 million (28%) from Export-Import Bank of Korea 2. USD 125 million (5%) from Asian Development Bank 3. USD 800 million (31%) from a KSure covered tranche loan. Under this tranche loan, USD 500 million came from Korea Finance Corporation, USD 225 million from Korea Development Bank, USD 25 million from ING Group, and USD 50 million from Credit Suisse. 4. USD 100 million (4%) from National Bank of Uzbekistan 5. USD 300 million (12%) from a Kexim covered tranche loan. Under this tranche loan, USD 75 million came from Korea Development Bank, USD 75 million from ING Group, USD 25 million from Credit Suisse, USD 75 million from Siemens Financial Services, USD 10 million from BayernLB, and USD 40 million from SEK. 6. USD 140 million (6%) from an EKN covered tranche loan. Under this tranche loan, USD 60 million came from Nordea, USD 60 million from ING Group, and USD 20 million from SEK. 7. USD 124 million (5%) from a Hermes covered tranche loan. Under this tranche loan, USD 64 million came from KfW and USD 60 million from BayernLB. The equity portion of this project's financing amounts to USD 1.4 billion, and the investors are as follows: Uzbekneftegaz (50%), Lotte Chemical Corporation (17.5%), Korea Gas Corporation (17.5%), SK Group (5%), STX (5%) and LG Corporation (5%).
sources: https://www.oxfordenergy.org/wpcms/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/NG_69.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.aucconline.com/news.php?news_id=567, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.reuters.com/article/gas-uzbekistan-loan/uzbekistan-gets-2-54-bln-in-loans-for-gas-project-idUSL5E8GL2JQ20120521, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.uz-kor.com/index.php/en/about, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFL4N11M27W20150916, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://ijglobal.com/Articles/77873, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://www.dropbox.com/sh/hospffehxhlnbr4/AACqO6vuNw0ylFmRHN675S_6a?dl=0&preview=IJGlobal+-+Surgil+Petrochemical+and+Natural+Gas+Complex+financing+-+Uzbekistan.pdf, Academic Journal Article; http://parliamentrk.gov.uz/ru/news/234/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Valachchenai Water Supply Project and Banadarawela, Diyathalawa and Haputhale Water Supply Project
description: The China Development Bank provided a loan of US$242.66 million, as signed on 30 August 2017, for the Valachchenai Water Supply Project and the Bandarawela, Diyathalawa, and Haputhale Water Supply Project. According to the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources Performance Report 2017, this loan covers 100% of the estimated project cost (see page 70 of document). This project is expected to be completed in 3 years according to the attached 'Resource Mobilization' source. The goal of this project is to provide safe drinking water to Bandarawela, Diyathalawa, Haputhale and Valachchenai through the Valachchenai Water Supply Project and the Bandarawela, Diyathalawa, Haputhale Water Supply Project. This project is being implemented by the Sri Lanka National Water Supply and Drainage Board. As of the end of 2017, the project is still under implementation. This project is one of the four water supply projects under implementation in Sri Lanka funded by the China Development Bank. The other three projects are: 54435 (Gampaha, Attanagalla and Minuwangoda Integrated Water Supply Scheme), 53566 (Katana water supply), and 53567 (Thambuttegama water supply). It is worth noting that the Katana Water Supply Project (USD 54.8 million), the Thambuttegama Water Supply project (USD 102.5 million), and the Valachchenai Water Supply Project and Bandarawela, Diyathalawa and Haputhale Water Supply Project (USD 242.66 million) loan agreements with CDB were all signed in August 2017 with a total balance of about USD 400 million combined. In Sri Lanka government documents, the Valachchenai Water Supply Project and Bandarawela, Diyathalawa and Haputhale Water Supply Project are together referred to as 'Balance of 400 million facility for priority Water Supply Projects', because they account for the final allocation of the August 2017 USD 400 million from CDB for water supply projects.
sources: http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/Publications/ERDReport2017/ERDReport2017-English.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=97:recently-signed-water-projects-china-division&catid=30&lang=en&Itemid=225, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: $1.02 billion China Eximbank-financed Expansion and Strengthening of Power System Network Project under the Dhaka Power Distribution Company
description: On June 1 2014, Chinese company TBEA Co., Ltd. signed a Memorandum of Understanding with Dhaka Power Distribution Company (DPDC) for the expansion and strengthening of power system network in DPDC area under a Chinese Concessional Loan (G to G ). The Executive Committee of the National Economic Council approved the project on December 6 2016. According to media reports, on August 11, 2017, China agreed to assist in the project of expanding and strengthening of the power system network Dhaka Power Distribution Company (DPDC) area project in South Dhaka. China EXIM Bank will provide a Preferential Buyer Credit loan worth $1021.77 million. The project begun in January 2019 and is expected to be completed by 2021; no additional information on project status could be found. According to media reports, 15 per cent of project financing will come from the Bangladesh government and 85 per cent of project financing comes from the Exim Bank of China.

title: $300 million CDB loan for oil refinery
description: This refinery is a major industrial undertaking in Kara-Balta, Kyrgyzstan, and will play a key role in promoting local economic development, increasing fiscal income to the government, and improving local employment. The construction has a total investment of USD431 million and the Bank had disbursed USD 300 million in loans by the end of 2015. The project is implemented by a Chinese company, Zhongda. The oil refinery is expected to produce 800,000 tons of fuel annually.

title: $35 million grant for construction of Civil Service Hospital
description: In May 2001, China and Nepal signed six agreements, including one to construct a hospital for civil servants in Kathmandu which cost an estimated 35 million USD, funded by a Chinese grant. Construction was carried out by China Tiesiju Civil Engineering Group Co Ltd and began in September 2006. The hospital, built on a 27,650 square meter area, will have 22 buildings for both outpatient and inpatient needs. It began providing services in April 2009 but was officially inaugurated the following month by Nepali Prime Minister Madhav Kumar Nepal. The hospital originally contained 132 beds with the capacity to hold 500 and will offer free to subsidized treatment to about 90,000 civil servants and their families. China also provided the hospital with the latest technological equipment and continued providing assistance to the hospital.

title: $6.58 million grant for construction of Banepa Polytechnic Institute
description: In 2001, China and Indonesia signed six agreements including one to construct a polytechnic institute in Banepa. On August 5, 2005, China granted 4.79 million USD for construction on the Nepal Banepa Polytechnic Institute, and granted an additional 1.79 million USD that December for a retaining wall, land leveling, and sewage draining at the construction site. Construction was initially expected to be completed in November 2005, however the polytechnic institute was formally given to the Nepalese government in April 2008. On 16 July 2012, the signing of the transfer certificate took place in Kathmandu. The institute will offer enrollment for 220 full-time students in long term courses and 300 students in short term training courses. Areas of study include tourism, hotel management, electronics, information technology, cosmetology, and computer engineering.

title: 1,000-unit housing development in Hulhumale
description: The governments of Maldives and China reportedly signed an agreement in August 2010 to build a 1,000-unit housing development in Hulhumale with a 'grant loan' of 481 million RMB funded by China's Export-Import Bank. The development includes 56 four-story buildings built on 39,600 square meters. Chinese company CMEC is the implementing organization and was contracted for $76 million USD. The groundbreaking ceremony was held in November 2010. The video resource attached shows completion of the project at the end of 2012. In October 2018, the loan was still being repaid. Disbursements (in MVR) from China Exim Bank per year for this project, according to the Maldives Government Budget in Statistics Financial Year 2014: -2010: 471,937,626 MVR -2011: 93,678,432 MVR

title: 150 million RMB to Afghanistan Ministry of Finance
description: On 8 June 2012, at the annual summit of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), China announced its plan to provide 150 million Chinese Yuan in grant to the Afghan Ministry of Finance. Based on an interview with Chinese Deputy Foreign Minister Fu Yings, this was the second 150 million CNY-grant that was offered by China. The agreement to provide the first 150 million CNY worth of grant was signed on 31 December 2011 (See Project ID#34601). Minister Fu Yings also said that China and Afghanistan would identify projects that could use the grant. STAFF_NOTE: This project was initially coded as being a duplicate of ID #34601, however, according to information published on the website of China's ECCO in Kabul, 150 million CNY assistance packages were pledged consecutively in 2011 and 2012. Furthermore, it was mentioned in the CSIS report that China's grant to Afghanistan from 2002 to 2010 is about US$205.3 million while the report by the 'Diplomat' has mentioned that the total amount of grant from 2002 to 2011 is about US$250 million. The reports show that there is at least 150 million CNY that was provided to Afghanistan in 2011, and the 150 million CNY that was offer in 2012 is referring to a separate pledge made by China. Last, the article by Reuters suggest that China's offer of 150 million CNY was part of the strategic partnership agreement signed in 2012, thus further distinguishing this offer of 150 million CNY in aid in 2012 from the one made in 2011. A Joint Declaration between The People's Republic of China and The Islamic Republic of Afghanistan on Establishing Strategic and Cooperative Partnership was then released on June 16 2012 which stated that both sides will "continually strengthen the pragmatic cooperation in such fields as resources and energy development, infrastructure development, engineering and agriculture". It was also suggested that the grant will be going to "peaceful reconstruction process.

title: 200 million RMB in preferential loan for di-ammonia phosphate fertiliser plant (linked to #33929)
description: In 2000, China offered $53.29 million to Bangladesh to build a $59.21 million 800 tonne/day di-ammonia phosphate fertiliser plant in Chittagong, via Exim Bank of China. The Bangladeshi government would supply the remaining $5 million. Under the contract signed between China National Complete Plant Import and Export Corporation Limited (COMPLANT) and Bangladesh Chemical Industries Corporation, the Chinese government would provide an interest-subsidized preferential loan of 200m renminbi yuan (24.18m US dollars), and the COMPLANT would provide 29.11m dollars on seller's export credit (see project ID#33929). Bangladesh will pay 10% of the contract amount in deposit. Construction for the di-ammonium phosphate fertilizer plant was expected to begin at the end of 2000 and projected to commence operations in 30 months.The project began proper in Apr 2004 and was completed in Jun 2006 by TTCL Public Company Limited (TTCL).

title: 200 million yuan grant for economic and technical assistance as part of a 750 million grant (linked to project #34429)
description: In 2012, China signed an agreement to provide an annual grant assistance of 200 million RMB to Nepal as part of a 750 million RMB three years grant assistance under their Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement. According to the export of AMP report in December 2018, the actual amount committed is 31,480,199 USD. The project is part of a larger cooperation grant agreement, linked to project #34429.

title: China provides 50 million RMB in aid for reconstruction efforts
description: On 30 December 2008, Chinese Ambassador to Afghanistan Yang Houlan and Afghan Foreign Minister Rangin Dafar Spanta signed an agreement under which China would provide 50 million Chinese Yuan to Afghanistan for consultative projects between the two countries. Details regarding which project would benefit from the grant are yet to be found. title: 60 million RMB grant for the 6th Bangladesh-China Friendship Bridge (linked to #39022 and #41981)
description: In January 2002, China committed 110 million RMB (1.29 billion BDT) in grants and loans to build the 6th Bangladesh-China friendship bridge (Muktarpur Bridge) over the Dhaleswari river. Of this funding, 60 million RMB will be provided for as a grant and 50 million RMB as an interest free loan. The bridge is 1,521 meters in length, and 10 meters in width, with one lane for each direction. China Road and Bridge Corporation undertook the construction of the bridge, and the Jamuna Multi-Purpose Bridge Authority was accountable for the project. A groundbreaking ceremony was held on January 27, 2005 and attended by Bangladeshi Prime Minister Khaleda Zia and Chinese Ambassador to Bangladesh Chai Xi. Construction works started on April 28, 2005, and the bridge was completed in January 2008, 7 months ahead of schedule, and inaugurated in February 2008.

title: Alternative North-South Road Project Section Aral-Kazarman RMB Loan (Linked to Project ID #40491, #53585)
description: On June 15 2015, the Kyrgyz government signed an agreement with China on the allocation of a government interest-subsidized concessional loan for the Alternative North-South Road Project Section Aral-Kazarman. The Ministry of Transport and Communications of the Kyrgyz Republic and China Road and Bridge Corporation entered into a Commercial Contract on May 4 2014 for the purpose of implementing the project. The aim of this international transport corridor North-South is to provide cooperation of the North European countries and Russia with the countries of the Persian Gulf, the Indian Ocean and South-East Asia through Iran. The international transport corridor North-South, which is an alternative to the sea route through the Suez Canal, primarily deals with container cargo traffic. The loan details for this project are as follow: 25 Year Maturity, 11 Year Grace Period, 1.5% Interest Rate Kyrgyzstan's 'North-South' highway will have a total length of 433 km and require $850 million in capital. The project is being implemented in three parts: Phase I (2014): Alternative North-South Road Project Section Kazarman-Jalal Abad (km291-km433) and Section Balykchy-Aral (km183+500-195+486); US $399,989,041 Preferential Buyers Credits financed by the Export-Import Bank of China [Project 40491] Phase II (2015): Alternative North-South Road Project Section Aral-Kazarman (KM 195-KM 291); US $185,254,119 export buyer's credit from EXIM Bank [Project 53585] & RMB 697,562,608 concessional loan from EXIM Bank [Project 46350] Phase III (planned): 'Balekchi-Kezeldez' (0-183km) [Total: 183km]

title: CDB Loans $100 millions USD for coal-based power plant at Jhajjar, Haryana (Linked to #54343)
description: On November 17th, 2010, China Development Bank loaned $100 million USD for the debt financing of the coal-based power plant at Jhajjar, Haryana. The coal-based power project was developed by CLP India Private Limited, a subsidiary of CLP Group. Construction began in January 2009. Stage one involved installing 660 MW capacity and that was commissioned March 2012. Stage two involved installing 660 MW capacity and was commissioned July, 2012. The loan has a duration of 13 years and 6 months, making the maturity date May 17th, 2024. The loan is described as a Sinosure-covered tranche. The loan is replacing a part of the Rs39 billion of the 15 year debt from a 2009 loan by IDBI. This project is co-financed by an $88 million USD by China's Export-Import Bank with the same terms (project #54343). This loan agreement is part of a larger syndicated loan for $288 million. The 5 institutions involved in the loan are the China Development Bank, the China Ex-Im Bank, The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, The Standard Chartered Bank, and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ.

title: CDB Loans $462 million USD to finance the capital expenditures of the 2G, 3G and BWA services of Aircel and its three subsidiaries in India
description: On March 19th, 2015, China Development Bank loaned $462 million USD to finance the capital expenditures of the 2G, 3G and BWA services of Aircel and its three subsidiaries in India. The loan has a duration of 10 years and is a part of a $651 million USD syndicated loan from SEK and the Nordic Investment Bank. STAFF_NOTE: Couldn't find additional sources that specifically cited the CDB loan of $462 million. In 2018, Aircel went bankrupt. Multiple creditors are bringing Aircel to court in order to recover funds, including the CDB.

funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency

title: CDB contributes $120 million USD to Shelek wind power plant
description: On August 31 2015, Kazakhstan Development Bank signed a framework agreement on the organization of funding between ‚ÄúSamruk-Energo‚Äù JSC and the China Development Bank for the project of ‚ÄúEnergy of Semirechye, construction of wind power plant (WPP)‚Äù LLP with a capacity from 60 MW up to 300 MW in Shelek corridor of Enbekshikazakh district of Almaty region for a total amount of 120 million USD. China Development Bank will provide $120 million USD for the project, while Kazakhstan Development Bank will provide $35 million USD.

title: CDB provides $300 million loan for Aktogay mine in Kazakhstan (linked to #39557 and #41941)
description: In 2016, the China Development Bank provided a $300 million loan to the Kazakhstan Development Bank, for the third phase of the construction of a sulphide ore processing plant at the Aktogay deposit in East-Kazakhstan region. The DBK is expected to sign an agreement with the KAZ Minerals to finance a line of credit for $300 million on December 14, 2016. The debt extends for 8.5 years until final maturity in June 2025. The KAZ Minerals facility with the DBK bears an interest rate of US dollar LIBOR +4.50%. KAZ Minerals loan facilities with the China Development Bank are based on a ratio of total liabilities to total assets, with adjustments to mitigate the translation impact of movements in the US dollar/tenge exchange rate. In 2014, Nonferrous China (NFC) was granted the contract to construct the sulphide concentrator. The main sulphide concentrator was commissioned on 6 December 2016. Production began in February 2017. This loan is liked to two previous loans for the Aktogay mine. In 2011, the China Development Bank committed two loans of a total of $1.5 billion. $1.34 billion and 1 billion RMB was committed to develop the Aktogay mine for copper cathode production. The first copper cathode production from oxide ore occurred in December 2015 and is expected to produce 100,000 tons of copper concentrate annually (project #41941 and #39557).
sources: https://www.kdb.kz/upload/iblock/1c6/BRK_AR_2016_EN_electric.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chinatoday.com.cn/english/spc/2017-02/28/content_739337.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.kazminerals.com/repository/news-container/news/2016/new-300-million-credit-facility-with-development-bank-of-kazakhstan-and-pxf-update/, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.halykfinance.kz/en/site/index/research/news:104355, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.nederlandwereldwijd.nl/binaries/nederlandwereldwijd/documenten/publicaties/2016/08/08/economic-newsletter-on-kazakhstan/newsletterjuly2016.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

implementing_agency: Kazakhstan Development Bank, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Kazakhstan Development Bank, Government Agency

title: CPEC Project Wangu Hills - Khuzdar (M-8) Construction
description: According to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance, in 2013 the Pakistan NHA and CPEC began a project to build on the Ratodero - Gwadar Motorway (M-8) section at Wangu Hills, Khuzdar to improve East-West connectivity. The section is 113 km and is part of the Eastern alignment. A source about CPEC route details found in March of 2019 during Stage 2 research lists this section as complete.
sources: http://www.finance.gov.pk/survey/chapters_18/13-Transport_and_Communications.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://sites.google.com/site/pakinfodata/cpec/cpecroute, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Pakistan National Highway Authority, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Pakistan National Highway Authority, Government Agency

title: CPEC project - Karachi Circular Railway
description: The 6th Joint Coordination Committee (JCC) agreed in principal for inclusion of Mass Transit System as part of CPEC component. Transport Working Group has been asked to work on the projects based further studies and consultation. Feasibility of Karachi Circular Railways completed in May 2017. Groundbreaking is expected in 2018. As of April 2019, no update on this project has been found. Earlier, the project was to be financed by Japanese development agency, JICA, and was scheduled to be completed in 10 years but under the special directives of former prime minister Nawaz Sharif, it was decided the project would be included in CPEC and would be completed within a period of three years. The total cost of the project is estimated at Rs 270.547 billion. But contribution from the Chinese side is unclear. The project would be undertaken by government of Sindh and China, while ministry of planning would oversee the matter. The 43.2 kilometer standard gauge double railway track (14.94 km at surface and 28.18 km elevated) would be constructed with allied structures on the existing land reserved for KCR. The corridor will have total 24 stations with an average station spacing of 1.8 km.
sources: http://cpec.gov.pk/project-details/43, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.finance.gov.pk/survey/chapters_18/13-Transport_and_Communications.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karachi_Circular_Railway, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.samaa.tv/economy/2017/08/karachi-circular-railway-to-be-completed-by-sept-2020/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/dl/gbdqzn/upload/bajisitan.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Agreed to Grant RMB 470,000 for Nepal's Oil Exploration
description: On March 21, 2016, China signed Exchange of Letters to provide the grant assistance of RMB 470,000 for the oil and gas exploration project of Nepal. The agreement was under the commercial deal on the supply of petroleum products between the two countries. China also agreed to build oil storage facilities and send exports to carry out the research on oil exploration for Nepal. On February 22, 2018, Nepal's Department of Mines and Geology informed that a Chinese expert team from China National Petroleum Corporation will visit Nepal to conduct the feasibility study, but the actual date was not determined. It is not clear whether the grants assistance has been disbursed. STAFF_NOTE: Limited information on the status of the grant assistance.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020160323ec3n007kf&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://mofa.gov.np/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/MOFA_REPORT_Nepal-Foreign-Affairs_2016.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://mofa.gov.np/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/MOFA_REPORT_Nepal-Foreign-Affairs_2016.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://thehimalayantimes.com/business/chinese-experts-study-fuel-exploration-extraction-prospects/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2019-01-18/china-roped-in-for-oil-and-gas-drilling.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: China Geological Survey, National NGO; China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), State-Owned Company

title: China Aided Agriculture Irrigation Project
description: On September 11 2015, Qi Dayu, the ambassador to Kyrgyzstan, attended the signing ceremony for the exchange of documents of the Chinese government aided Kyrgyz agricultural irrigation project, and signed an exchange of letters with the Minister of Agriculture of the Ministry of Agriculture, Aidalyliev, on behalf of the two governments.The Chinese government will provide free aid for the construction and improvement of the nationwide irrigation facilities in Kyrgyzstan. The two sides exchanged views on deepening agricultural cooperation between the two countries. On May 2018, the construction for this project begins. The project is expected to bring benefits to more than 50 thousand people. Power Construction Corporation of China is responsible for the project.
sources: https://www.fmprc.gov.cn/web/gjhdq_676201/gj_676203/yz_676205/1206_676548/1206x2_676568/t1296126.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.powerchina.cn/art/2018/5/4/art_19_281328.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://wenhui.whb.cn/zhuzhan/huanqiu/20180505/197057.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Power Construction Corporation of China Ltd

title: China Aided Kyrgyz Republic for a New Hospital Building
description: On July 2, 2013, Qi Dayu, the ambassador to Kyrgyzstan, attended the completion ceremony of the new medical building in the National Hospital of the Kyrgyz Republic. The construction of the medical building was aided by China and covered ‚Äã‚Äã1,100 square meters, with a construction area of ‚Äã‚Äã5,550 square meters and 150 beds. The director of the Kyrgyz government office, Momunariyev, and the Minister of Health, Sagan Baeva, and the Deputy Foreign Minister of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Adam Kulova, attended the ceremony. According to the Kyrgyzstan Health Secretary, this project was the first aid project Kyrgyzstan received from China
sources: http://kg.china-embassy.org/chn/dssghd/t1055517.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ztwj.cn/ArtcleDetail.aspx?ID=236&cid=34, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
implementing_agency: China Railway No.5 Engineering Group, State-Owned Company

title: China Builds Integrated Teaching Complex and Auditorium in Kabul University, Afghanistan (Linked to #54009, #53640, and #53999)
description: On May 16th, 2016, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang and Afghan Chief Executive Officer Abdullah Abdullah signed six bilateral cooperation documents, including an exchange note on the construction grant of two buildings at Kabul University. On October 10, 2017, China began construction on the Integrated Teaching Complex and and an auditorium for Kabul University, Afghanistan. The construction project includes an academic lecture hall with 40 classrooms and an auditorium with a capacity of 500 people. The project is estimated to cost 60 million USD and is being granted by China. The construction project is expected to be finished within 27 months. Other documents signed on May 16th, 2016 include: an agreement to grant 500 million yuan (#54009), a trade agreement for saffron, a Memorandum of Understanding on the nature of the One Belt One Road Initiative, an exchange note on a grant of 50 million yuan for non-emergency humanitarian aid (#53640), and an exchange note on China creating a survey for the construction of affordable housing for civil service employees in Kabul (#53999). For another project Chinese government provide for Kabul University, see #53632 for details. As of 2018 the project is still in implementation phase.
sources: http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-10/10/c_136670303.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://af.china-embassy.org/chn/zagx/wxzl/t1392473.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=HNASNI0020160517ec5h000ry&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=HNASNI0020160517ec5h000ry&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020160518ec5i00899&cat=a&ep=ASE , Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://prod.tolonews.com/afghanistan/afghanistan-china-sign-six-cooperation-agreements, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://ceo.gov.af/en/news/joint-statement-between-the-peoples-republic-of-china-and-the-islamic-republic-of-afghanistan, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ceo.gov.af/en/news/370079, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.fmprc.gov.cn/web/zwbd_673032/jghd_673046/t1498584.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://19mcc.com.cn/newsinfo.aspx?t=19&ContentId=62831&page=3, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://drive.google.com/file/d/1JA_tQGeFTrBShggIR369sqBo_k94MI_k/view?usp=sharing, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lgsGDad3zAjXNJDeXLZITcaX5R0E_TZY/view?usp=sharing, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://af.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/201501/20150100879514.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://af.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/201811/20181102811158.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Commits 60M RMB to Construction of Bridge (linked to ID #43295)
description: Bangladesh received a grant of about 60 million yuan and an interest-free loan of 100 million yuan (Project ID #43295) from China, for one of the bridges which connects the northern and southern parts of Bangladesh. No year was stated in the article, and several bridges have been constructed in Bangladesh with Chinese grants, so specific details are uncertain.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BSNLNE0020101115e6bg0001m&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.eastasiaforum.org/2010/02/05/chinas-growing-presence-in-indias-neighbourhood/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China Constructs School in Bishkek
description: In 2017, the construction of a general school was completed in Bishkek after the China Ministry of Commerce funded the school. The mayor of Bishkek met with Minister Czen Huacheng to thank him for completing the construction of the school. STAFF_NOTE: It is unknown when the two parties agreed to construct the school.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=CEASEN0020170731ed7v000jh&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: China Ministry of Commerce, Government Agency

title: China Development Bank Loans $166.67 million USD for the Tiroda Thermal Power Project in India (Linked to #54345)
description: On April 22nd, 2013, the China Development Bank loaned $166,670,000 USD for the construction of the 3300 MW Tiroda Thermal Power Project of 5x660 MW units. The Tiroda Thermal Power is also called the Gondia Coal-Fired Project. The loan has a maturity of ten years. The project was constructed by the Adani Power Maharashtra Ltd (APML). The first unit of the plant was commissioned on 28th August 2012 and subsequently, other units were commissioned. The project was commissioned on October 11th, 2014. The Tiroda Thermal Power Project was also funded by a $166.67 million USD loan by the ICBC (project #54345) and a $166.66 million USD loan by the Standard Chartered Bank, both under the same loan conditions.
sources: http://www.adanipower.com/businesses/operational-power-plants/tiroda, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.hindustantimes.com/india/three-units-of-adani-power-plant-in-maharashtra-operational/story-K2mSQn9VFB4xHva0Ma47tI.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/adani-power-set-to-commission-third-unit-in-tiroda-this-month/articleshow/19397774.cms, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.bv.com/Projects/Adani-Power-Maharashtra-Limited, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/adani-power-commissions-third-unit-of-660-mw-at-tiroda-113062000369_1.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/vipk6unz6vz2z49/IJGlobal%20-%20Gondia%20Coal-Fired%20Project%20Additional%20Facility%20%283300MW%29%20-%20India.pdf?dl=0, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.pp.u-tokyo.ac.jp/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/GraSPP-DP-E-14-003-SOM.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://www.dropbox.com/s/vults7c3kv89j45/BU_PITCH_ENGLISH_2018.xlsx?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Development Bank finances Ekibastuz GRES-2 Power Plant
description: In 2013, the China Development Bank provided a $400 million loan to Kazakhstan for the construction of the third unit of Ekibastuz GRES-2 coal power plant in Ekibastuz. The loan was jointly funded by China and Russia's Vnesheconombank. Vladimir Dmitriev and Governor of the China Development Bank Chen Yuan signed the credit agreement. Kazakhstan and Russia signed the agreement on the project in January 2011. According to its project website, 'Ekibastuz GRES-2' JSC is Kazakh-Russian joint energy company located in the Republic of Kazakhstan with installed capacity of 1000 MW. Global Trade Review states that the VEB secured $400M from the CBD to fund the project. The power plant has an expected output of 3,600 MW. According to Carnegie Moscow Center, Russia‚Äôs Vnesheconombank (VEB) was to extend loans for the construction of the third unit of the Ekibastuz GRES-2 power station. However, in 2013 the bank, which by that time had used up its resources for financing the construction of Olympic facilities in Sochi, reached an agreement with the China Development Bank to use its funds for the project.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/vults7c3kv89j45/BU_PITCH_ENGLISH_2018.xlsx?dl=0, Academic Journal Article; https://chinaperspectives.revues.org/4053, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://en.tengrinews.kz/finance/China-and-Russia-to-spend-400-million-on-Kazakhstan-power-23474/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://eabr.org/en/projects/in-process/ekibastuzskaya-gres/, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; file:///Users/paigejacobson/Downloads/20160302%20Tang%20-%20China_Central%20Asian%20Republics.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.gtreview.com/news/asia/veb-inks-series-of-china-loans/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://carnegie.ru/2015/03/19/taming-dragon-how-can-russia-benefit-from-china-s-financial-ambitions-in-sco-pub-59445, Academic Journal Article; https://www.samruk-energy.kz/en/se/jsc-ekibastuz-sdps-2, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: China Development Bank provides $60m USD loan for fiber-optic laying
description: In 2008, China Development Bank gave a commercial loan of $60 million to KyrgyzTelecom to lay fiber-optic cables and expand networks and digital broadcasting in the Batken region of Kyrgyzstan. The details of the commercial loan are currently unknown. According to a Freedom House Report, KT finished laying the fiber-optic cables in 2010. STAFF_NOTE: Unsure if loan occurred in 2008, but project was finished by 2010.
sources: https://www.imf.org/external/np/pp/eng/2010/072110.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2017/kyrgyzstan, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
implementing_agency: KyrgyzTelecom, Private Sector
recipient_agencies: KyrgyzTelecom, Private Sector

title: China Development Bank provides loan of US$195 million for Gampaha Attanagalla and Miniwangoda integrated water supply project
description: The China Development Bank (CDB) signed a loan agreement for US$195 million for the Gampaha Attanagalla and Miniwangoda Intergrated Water Supply Project (Gampaha, Attanagalla and Minuwangoda Integrated Water Supply Scheme) in 2016; the ground breaking ceremony for the construction of the project was held on 5 December 2014 and the project is expected to last until May 2020. The total project cost was listed as US$229.49 million; the China Development Bank (CDB) will provide a USD 195 million (20 year) loan, while the remaining 15 percent of the total cost of the project will be borrowed locally. The Bank of Ceylon will provide the Government with credit for 15 percent of the estimated cost or USD 34 million (Rs 5.3 billion). The goal of the project is to provide safe and reliable drinking water to the areas of the Gampaha, Minuwangoda and Attanagalla Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions and part of Meerigama Divisional Secretariat (DS) division. The project is expected to take three years, and will include the construction of Basnagoda 3.5 MCM capacity impounding reservoir at Karasnagala, the construction of 85,000 m3/day capacity water intake at Karasnagala, the construction of 54,000 m3/day capacity Water Treatment Plant (WTP) at Karasnagala, the construction of a waste water and sludge treatment facility including all accessories and pumping equipment at the treatment plant premises, the construction of 10,000 m3 capacity High Level Reservoir (HLR) at Nikahetikanda, construction of five (05) 1,500 m3 capacity elevated water towers at Ranpokunugama, Belummahara, Naiwala, Minuwangoda and Pasyala, the supply and laying of 1,000 mm diameter Ductile Iron (DI) pipes for raw water pumping main of 1.75 km length approximately from the water intake to the WTP, the supply and laying of 1,000 mm dia. DI pipes for treated water pumping main of 1.65 km length approximately from the WTP to the high level reservoir (HLR), the supply and laying of 1,100 mm dia. to 150mm dia. range DI pipes for the gravity transmission main approximate length of 89.2 km from the HLR to existing and new water towers, supply and laying of 225 mm dia. to 90 mm dia. range uPVC pipes for the distribution network, approximate length of 600 km, supply and laying of 400 mm dia. to 300 mm dia. range DI pipes for balance part of the distribution network, approximate length of 30 km, and finally catchment protection. The project is contracted by CMEC, which will be responsible for all the design, sourcing, civil engineering, installation, and commissioning works. The Sri Lankan Department of Project Management and Monitoring reports that as of 31 January 2018, the cumulative physical progress of the project is 20.27%.
sources: http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/Publications/ERDReport2017/ERDReport2017-English.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/Performance%20of%20Priority%20Projects.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/pdf/performance_report_2016_english_version.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=MENREP0020130517e95h001lh&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.colombopage.com/archive_14B/Dec07_1417973694CH.php, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/Progress%20of%20Prority%20Project%20as%20at%2031%20January%202018.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ft.lk/article/151679/Chinese-firm-signs----229-5-m-contract-for-water--project-in-Sri-Lanka, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2018/08/12/news/cmec-attanagalla-water-project-ag-points-%E2%80%98colossal%E2%80%99-squander-public-funds, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
implementing_agency: China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) , State-Owned Company

title: China EXIM Bank Provides Loan of US$33 million for 500 kV overhead line ‚ÄúTSS Syrdarya ‚Äì TSS Novo Angren' in Uzbekistan
description: The Export-Import Bank of China provided a loan of USD$33.02 million for the 500 kV overhead line (OHL) ‚ÄúTSS Syrdarya ‚Äì TSS Novo Angren' in Uzbekistan; the project is expected to run from 2014-2016. The length of the line will be approximately 130km. The total cost is the project is estimated at USD$93 million; funds not provided by the EXIM Bank of China will be provided by Uzbekenergo. Syrdarya may also be spelled 'Sirdaryo' or 'Sirdarya.' The project was also referred to as 'Syrdarya TPS ‚Äì Novo-Angren TPS.'
sources: http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/810761468318884305/pdf/ACS41460WP0Box0Issues0Note00PUBLIC0.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=TRENDE0020150116eb1g001jn&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/linked-documents/41340-015-dc.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/project-monitoring/5-sustainable-energy/E234/2014_NationalStudies/UZ/UZ_Report.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-document/73436/46007-002-uzb-iee.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: China EXIM Bank RMB denominated loan to Best Green Energy Pakistan Limited 100 MW solar power project (Linked to Project #50939, #53989 and #54286) (CPEC, IPP)
description: Best Green Energy Pakistan Limited (BGEPL) is a 100 MW Solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, District Bahawalpur in the Province of Punjab. BGEPL later signed Engineering, Procurement, Construction contracts with China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd and with MCC Ruba International Construction Company (Pvt) Ltd to build, own and operate a 100 MW AC Solar powered electric generation facility to be located at Bahawalpur, Punjab. On December 21, 2015 the company signed a Term Facility Agreement (TFA) with the Export-Import bank of China ('EXIM bank') and Bank of Jiangsu Co Limited. The Company achieved Financial Closing on Dec 28, 2015. The Commercial Operation Date of the project was July 31, 2016. Total project cost is 150.269 USD Million, with a debt-equity ratio of 81:19, China Eximbank gave 2 loans, one denominated in RMB worth 100 Million which amounts to 15.4 million USD (2.65% interest rate), and another denominated in USD worth 49.060 million USD (5.0058% interest rate). The Bank of Jiangsu gave 1 loan, denominated in USD which amounts to 64.440 (5.0958% interest rate). This projects records the RMB denominated loan from China EXIM bank. It is unclear how the equity component was financed.
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: China EXIM Bank loans 36 million USD for construction of water pipeline in Uzbekistan
description: In November 2007, China National Chemical Engineering Co., Ltd., China Exim Bank, and Uzbekistan signed a contract worth 44.97 million USD for the construction of a water pipeline in Uzbekistan. China Exim Bank provided a loan of 36 million USD, and the rest of the funds will be contributed by the Suvokava (Vodokanal) Company. The total cost of the project would be 48.3 million USD. Exim Bank's loan would be for 20 years with a 5 year grace period and 2% interest rate. The project is to construct the improvement of potable water supply at 100,000 cubic meters per day, a number of booster pump stations, and a big-caliber 120-km water transmission pipeline for the Uzbek cities of Fergana, Margilan, and Andizhan. The construction was reported as completed as of November 30, 2011. STAFF_NOTE: Sources reported different loan amounts provided by China Eximbank; transaction amount coded as $36 million because this was the more conservative amount and reported by the IMF.

title: China EXIM Bank loans Tajikistan $64 million for Chormagzak tunnel of Dushanbe-Dangara Road (linked to ID #53750, #40063)
description: In 2010, the Export-Import Bank of China loaned Tajikistan $64 million for the construction of the Chormagzak tunnel. This is part of the Phase II of the reconstruction project of the Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma road, which was also financed by Exim bank loans. The Chormagzak tunnel is 4.4 km long and was implemented between 2010 and 2013. This project is linked to projects ID #53750 and #40063, which capture Exim bank loans for phases I and II of the reconstruction of Dushanbe-Dangara road.

funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: China EXIM Bank loans Uzbekistan 42 million USD to construct phase 2 of Dehkanabad Potash Fertilizer Plant (Linked to Project ID #40129)
description: On September 22, 2011, China's EXIM Bank and Uzpromstroybank Uzbek Joint Stock Industrial Construction Bank signed a loan agreement for 42 million USD to build the second phase of the Dehkanabad potash fertilizer plant. The funds are under guarantee by Uzbek government and drawn from Chinese government reserves for SCO members. The loan has been issued for 20 years with a 5 year grace period, but with no specified interest rate. CITIC Construction was responsible for the construction. The project will also be funded by FRD (62 million USD) and Uzkimyosanoat (22 million USD) for a total of 126 million USD. The second phase construction is meant to triple capacity - up to 600,000 tons of potash/year, 350,000 tons of which is planned to be exported.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=IXCENT0020110923e79m000p2&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=TRENDE0020110922e79m0040h&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.uzbekembassy.org/userfiles/files/files/Fund%20of%20Reconstruction%20and%20Develpment.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://uz.chineseembassy.org/chn/zwgx/jmhz/t839131.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://uz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/201011/20101107248686.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

implementing_agency: CITIC Construction Group, State-Owned Company

title: China EXIM bank 82.56 million USD concessional loan funds construction of single point mooring system (SPM) and 220km pipeline system for Bangladesh (Linked to Project #53584)
description: In 2017, China EXIM Bank committed to provide a concessional loan worth USD 82.56 million for the construction of an oil tanker mooring platform and 220km of underwater and onshore pipelines in Chittagong, Bangladesh. China Petroleum Pipeline Bureau will construct the mooring platform, the 146km of underwater pipelines, and the 74km of on-land pipelines. The terms of the concessional loan are 30 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 2.25% interest rate. In January 2015, CPPB, a subsidiary of the state-owned China National Petroleum Corporation, and the Energy Division under the Ministry of Power, Energy and Mineral Resources signed an agreement to build a single point mooring system (SPM) in the Bay of Bengal to carry petroleum from vessels at the outer anchorage to depots onshore. Upon completion of the project, fuel unloading time will be shortened from the original 11 days to two and a half. This project will reduce lower fuel costs and the risk of oil spills. As of March 2015, state-run Eastern Refinery Ltd (ERL) had received the technical offer from the CPPB to build the SPM. Before submitting the technical offer, a team of the CPPB visited the project location near Moheshkhali island in the Bay of Bengal and found the site suitable. The ERL, along with an international consultant, would review the 'lone' technical offer before submitting its evaluation report to the Energy and Mineral Resources Division (EMRD) under the ministry of power, energy and mineral resources (MPEMR). The Chinese firm would submit financial offer on completion of the review. The project was expected to take 36 months, but 19 months into the project (October 2018), the China Petroleum Pipeline Bureau had only completed initial surveying and some designing. In addition to providing the 82.56 million USD concessional loan, the Chinese EXIM Bank also provided $467.8 million in preferential buyer's credits for this same project (project ID #53584).

title: China EXIM bank loans Uzbekistan 37.1 million USD for construction of high voltage line
description: In January 2012, Uzbekenergo and China Exim Bank agreed to cofinance construction of a high voltage power line costing 83.5 million USD total, with Uzbekenergo contributing 46.4 million USD and Exim Bank contributing 37.1 million USD. The loan is given for 20 years including a five-year grace period. Uzbekenergo will construct the 500 kV power transmission line by 2012 and planned completion is 2014.

title: China EXIM bank loans Uzbekistan 41.7 million USD for construction of phase 1 of Dehkanabad potash plant (linked to ID #40128)
description: In 2007, China EXIM bank allocated a $41.7M soft loan for the construction of the Dehkanabad potash plant in the Kashkadarya region of Uzbekistan, located on the Tyubegatan deposit. Construction of phase 1 of the plant started in 2010. The total cost of the project is $123.7M. In addition to the Eximbank funding, the Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan allocated a $61.9M loan, and Uzkimyosanoat also directed its own funds to finance the construction. This project will have the capacity to produce 200,000 tonnes of potash per year. In 2008, Uzkimyosanoat inked agreements with Russia‚Äôs Zapodnouralskiy Machinjstroitelniy Kontsern and China‚Äôs CITIC Pacific Ltd on construction of the plant. In particular, the Russian firm will build mining complex and Chinese firm - processing plant. Plans are currently in motion to triple the production capacity to 600,000 tons per a year. This project is linked to ID #40128, a second loan for the second stage of the project.

title: China Ex-Import Bank provides 49.1 million USD loan for the cofinancing of the Nandipur power plant in Pakistan
description: Pepco (Pakistan Electric Power Company) hired a Chinese firm -Dong Fang Electric Corporation -for building Nandipur power plant. . The project was delayed due to the pending 'placet' by the Pakistani Minister of Law, which cause great losses for the contractor. The delay forced a consortium of Chinese banks, comprising BNP Paribas and Export-Import Bank of China, to pull out of the project, for which it had already signed the above mentioned Sinosure Buyer Credit Facility Agreement. In 2013 the government wanted to acquire Rs23.49 billion in loans from domestic banks to finance the project itself. After new negotiaitions with the contractor the works started again. In February 2015 the Nandipur power plant started to partially function and it has been said it would have been completed by June 2015. In the end, the project was funded by a mixture of foreign loans and a Pakistan government equity. Each of the three banks, including the China Export-Import Bank, BNP Paribas (a French international banking group), and HSBC (a British multinational banking and financial services holding company), provides 49.1 million USD. The financing agreement was closed on April 19, 2009, and has a tenor of 10 years, meaning the loans will mature in April 2019. The Pakistani government supplied an unknown amount of equity.

title: China Exim Bank commits $44 million loan for Pakistan-China Cross-border Fiber Optic Cable
description: A Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) was signed between China and Pakistan in April 2007 for the establishment of a secure international Optical Fibre Cable (OFC) link between China and Pakistan along Karakaram Highway. The agreement was signed during Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif official visit to China in early July 2013, and Huawei has been assigned the task in this regard. The project is expected to be completed within a span of two years. The Pakistan government said that it will deploy the system at a cost of 3.7 billion rupees between Pakistan and China for security of information. The project would be funded within Public Sector Development Program (PSDP) and out of a Chinese soft loan. The project involves Rs 3.2 billion foreign exchange component (FEC). The project was deliberated at a recent meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Economic Council (ECNEC) under the chairmanship Finance Minister Dr. Abdul Hafeez Shakih, and consists of laying 820 km of Optical Fibre Cable (OFC) along the Karakaram Highway, from Rawalpindi to Khunjrab Pass (Chinese border via Mansehra, Chilas, Danyore (Gligit), Karimabad and Sust). Construction began October 2015. Financing will reportedly come in for of concessional loan of 2% from China Exim Bank. The project's expected cost is $44M. China reportedly released $11.24M for the project's implementation during this time period; for now, transaction amount is recorded as that already disbursed. The Pakistani Ministry of Planning,Development & Reform reports that, up to June 2016, 1,377.4 million Rupees have been disbursed, which corresponds roughly to the USD amount mentioned above. The Pak-China Optical Fiber Cable Project is a first of its kind project under the China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), which gives China alternate and shorter access for transit telecom traffic to Europe, Middle East and Africa. The project features the development of communication infrastructure of around 820 km underground OFC from Rawalpindi to Khunjerab and 172 km aerial OFC from Karimabad to Khunjerab to supplement in landslide prone areas. It provides 26 high capacity microwave links as backup to OFC network and 9 node centers in different locations along Rawalpindi-Khunjerab belt. The work on the project was formally launched in 2016 and has been completed in a record two years. The project is a collaboration between Special Communications Organization, China Telecom Global and Pakistan Telecommunication Company. In January 2017, Pakistan's Information Technology and Telecom Division contributed 72 million Pakistani rupees towards project construction of OFC system between Pakistan and China for international connectivity of voice/data traffic (SCO).

title: China Exim Bank loans 215.96 million USD to Nepal for construction of Pokhara Airport
description: On 22 May 2014, Chairman of the China CAMC Engineering Co Luo Yan and Director General of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN) Ratish Chandra Lal Suman signed the contract worth $215.96 million for the construction of the Nepal Pokhara airport on behalf of the Chinese and Nepalese governments. China Exim Bank has agreed to extend a $215.96 million soft loan to the Nepali government to build the Pokhara Regional International Airport. The two sides will discuss the terms and conditions related to the interest rate and commitment charges. Birendra Kumar Shrestha, spokesperson of CAAN, stated that The Ministry of Finance (MoF) of Nepal will get concessional loans from China Exim Bank, which will then be issued as a loan to CAAN charging interest rate of 8 percent. In 2017, the Chinese EXIM bank committed to providing 25% of the loan interest-free, and set the loan's interest rate at 2 percent per anum for the rest of the loan, with a 20 year repayment period. The planned airport will have a 3000 metre-long runway, an apron, international and domestic terminal buildings, an air traffic control tower, a cargo terminal building along with an airport hangar. The airport, which has been in the works for 39 years, is proposed to be built at Chinnedanda, Nepal. Upon the completion of this project, it will help improve the aviation and tourism facilities and help boost Nepal's economic and social development. In 2017, the construction began.

title: China Exim Bank loans 281.1 million USD for Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak road construction
description: In March 2006, a memorandum of understanding was signed which identifies the financing project of implementation of 1st stage of the Dushanbe--Khujand-Chanak highway in Tajikistan. The Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak highway project started in July 2006. According to the agreement, the China Road and Bridge company was to reconstruct the 354km highway connecting Dushanbe, the capital of Tajikistan, with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. It is expected that the works will be finished by August 2010. The total cost stood at 295.9 million US dollars. The loan portion was financed by EXIM Bank of China at $281,105,000 through 4 annual disbursements. The loan has a 20 year repayment period, 5-year grace period, and 2 percent annual interest rate. The project includes the construction of the Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. The project began in July 2006, and was expected to be completed in 2008. It was completed in 2010.

title: China Exim Bank loans Sri Lanka 13B Rs. for Lower Mulwathu Oya reservoir project
description: In 2016, Exim Bank of China agreed to provide a 13 billion Rs. loan for the Lower Mulwathu Oya Multi Sector Development Project in the Anuradhapura and Vavuniya Districts. 13,215 ha of lands will be irrigated benefiting 10,000 farm families. This project envisages construction of 209 MCM capacity reservoir, 3,590 m long earth dam, Radial Gated Spillway, Left Bank, Right Bank and River Sluices, canal systems to new settlement area, and a power house. Stored water at proposed reservoir is released through the river sluice to the Malwathu Oya and picked up at Tekkam Anicut (24 Km d/s from Proposed Malwathu Oya Reservoir). From Tekkam Anicut 500 Cusec and 250 Cusec capacity right bank and left bank canals respectively convey water to irrigate 24,450 acres and 6,230 acres under existing Giant‚Äôs tank and Akitamuruppu tank respectively. 2,000 acres of new irrigable lands just downstream of the Reservoir is proposed for introducing commercial farming and 675 acres of lands have been identified for paddy cultivation. Other expected benefits are the provision of 2.0 MCM of domestic water annually for the new settlers, generation of 4.28 GWH Hydro power energy annually and the improvement of agricultural activities, livestock development, and other infrastructure development. As of 2016, EIA had already been completed and cabinet approval had been obtained for implementation with CAMCE - China. Technical and financial proposals have been called from CAMC Company LTD for an EPC contract. MSD approval has been obtained for initial project carder. According to 'Progress of development projects and programmes being implemented in 2017,' only 15% of land surveying has been completed and financial progress is very low. The construction of the Malwathu Oya reservoir is expected to commence in the first quarter of 2018. STAFF_NOTE: The concessionality of this loan is unknown, so flow class was coded as Vague (Official Finance).
sources: http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/mid%20year-2016.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.dailynews.lk/2018/09/17/local/162770/malwathu-oya-reservoir-work-delayed, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ft.lk/columns/Lower-Malwathu-Oya-project-%E2%80%93-A-series-of-misconception-errors/4-639380, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.parliament.lk/uploads/documents/paperspresented/performance-report-ministry-of-irrigation-water-resources-management-2016.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/Final%20Document-%20English.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/Progress%20of%20the%20Projects%20Implemented%20through%20the%20Capital%20Budget%20in%20the%20year%202016_EN%20full.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/Development_Performance_2014_End.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Exim Bank loans Tajikistan 68.9 million USD for Vahdat-Javan railway section upgrade
description: China EXIM Bank has agreed to loan Tajikistan 68.9 million USD at concessional rates to construct the Vahdat-Javan (also spelled Yavan) railway section. This railway section is part of a larger regional railway construction that aims to link Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Turkmenistan. According to the State Committee on Investment and State Property Management of the Republic of Tajikistan, the official title of the project is 'Construction of railway tunnel on Dushanbe-Kurgan-Tyube railway, Vahdat plot - Yovon' and the total project cost is 71,992 million. 68,992 of this amount is being provided through a loan from China EXIM Bank, and the source for the remaining $3 million is listed as 'Other.' The project was previously reported as costing $56.9 million before the amount increased. The construction includes 5 bridges with 712 m length and 3 tunnels of 3755 m length. The contractor is China railway 19 bureau group. This project started in May 2015 and is expected to be finished by August 2016. According to news report, the project went into full operation in 2016.

title: China Exim Bank loans Uzbekistan 300 million USD for PVC plant construction
description: In 2013, China Exim Bank provided a loan of $300 million for the construction of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) plant at the Navoiazot chemical complex in Uzbekistan.The estimated cost of this project was initially $470.8, but was increased to $501.1M in 2015. $65.9 million in financing comes from the Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan as loans, and $61.4 million came from Uzkhimprom's own resource. This plant is to have the capacity to produce 100K tons of PVC, 300K tons of methanol, and 75K tons of caustic soda each year. The implementation period of this construction is 3 years, and its implementation is to start in December 2015. The Chinese company CAMC is the contractor of this construction. STAFF_NOTE: One source (Asaka Bank) reported the amount of the Eximbank loan as $373.83 million, but for this project the more conservative transaction amount was recorded. Loan details are unknown.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=CEASEN0020131003e9a3000rt&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://easttime.info/news/uzbekistan/china-has-provided-loan-uzbekistan-construction-new-plant, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.asakabank.uz/en/cooperation/project_financing, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.sohu.com/a/300900847_659458, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.uzdaily.uz/en/post/24953, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.eurasianbusinessbriefing.com/navoiazot-gets-300m-eximbank-loan-for-new-pvc-plant/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sohu.com/a/300900847_659458, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.camce.com.cn/cn/xwzx/gsxw/201505/t20150504_59541.htm, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: China Exim Bank loans Uzbekistan 350 million USD for Kamchiq Tunnel in the Angren-Pap Railway
description: On November 30, 2013, China EXIM Bank and National Bank of Uzbekistan signed an agreement with China providing $350 million for construction of the Kamchiq railway tunnel linking the Central Asian nation‚Äôs populous Ferghana Valley with the rest of the country. It appears the loan was disbursed in 2014. The loan period is 20 years, with a 5 year grace period and an interest rate of 2.25%. Uzbekistan Railways State Joint-Stock Railway Company signed a contract with China Railway Tunnel Group Co Ltd. to construct the tunnel. The tunnel, with a total project cost of 455 million USD, is to connect the Qamchiq pass and Ferghana Valley as part of the electrified Angren-Pap railway. Uzbekistan government and International bank for construction and development financed the rest of the Angren-Pap railway, with a total cost of 1.6 billion USD. This is part of the belt and road project. As of September 2015, construction of the ground part of the Angren-Pap railway had been implemented, including construction and electrification of the two sections of the railway with a total length of 104 km on both sides of the tunnel. In February 2016, the construction was finished. The project was completed February 27th, 2016 STAFF_NOTE: Tunnel also spelled Kamchik.

title: China Eximbank finances construction of Karaganda-Balkhash road
description: In May 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China provided a loan for the construction of the Karaganda-Balkhash road in Kazakhstan, which is part of the Central South Corridor. According to an article from CITIC, the company signed a EPC contract with KazAvtoZhol on May 17 2018. The Asian Development Bank states the cost of the project is 200 million USD. However, a Ministry of Commerce article reported that the Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee to China Eximbank's loan in June 2018, and that the loan valued 727 million USD. According to the BoP, the loan was likely disbursed in the 4th quarter of 2017. The implementing agency is KazAvtoZhol. The road will be 363 kilometers long and is part of the Central South Corridor. Construction is to begin in August 2018 and will be completed by fall 2020. According to a project report by KazAvtoZhol in May 2019, the project is implemented in 8 sections with a total length of 362 km by a consortium of CITIC Construction Co.Ltd and JV KazGerStroy LLP. No loan details can be found.

title: China Eximbank loan for construction of a small hydroelectric power station at Tuyabuguz reservoir (linked to #54385)
description: In 2017, China Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for the construction of a small hydroelectric power station at Tuyabuguz reservoir in Urta Chirchik district, Tashkent Region. The total cost of the project is $15,900,000, but the amount of the Eximbank loan is unknown. The power station will have a capacity of 12 MW and the implementation dates are 2017-2019. Construction on the project began in June-August 2017, and the plant is expected to be commissioned at the end of 2018. This project is linked to ID #54385, the umbrella project for an Eximbank loan for four hydropower plants.

title: China Eximbank provides loan for construction of Kamchik small hydropower station on Akhangaran river (linked to #54385)
description: In 2017, China Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for the construction of Kamchik small hydropower station on Akhangaran river in Pap district, Namangan region (reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan). The project cost is $27,200,000, but the amount of the Eximbank loan is unknown. The station will have a capacity of 18 MW and the dates of implementation are 2018-2021. According to MarketWatch, construction began in June-August 2017. This project is linked to project ID #54385, the umbrella project for an Eximbank loan for four hydropower plants.

title: China Eximbank provides loan for construction of Kamolot hydropower station on Chirchik-Bozsuv tract
description: In 2017, China's Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for the construction of Kamolot hydropower station on Chirchik-Bozsuv tract in Chirchik city, Tashkent region. The total cost of the project is $22,600,000, but the contribution of the Eximbank is unknown. The hydropower station will have a capacity of 8 MW and will be implemented from 2017-2020. Project status and loan details are unknown. STAFF_NOTE: Year marked uncertain because UNECE reports implementation period as 2016-17; loan may have been committed prior to 2017.

title: China Eximbank provides loan for construction of cascade of Zarchob hydroelectric power stations on Tupalang river (linked to #54385)
description: In 2017, China Eximbank provided a loan to Uzbekistan for the construction of a cascade of Zarchob hydroelectric power stations on Tupalang river in Sariasiya district, Surkhandarya region (reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan). The project cost is $80,390,000, but the amount provided by the Eximbank is unknown. The stations will have a capacity of 69 MW, and the dates of implementation are 2017-2020. This project is linked to ID #54385, the umbrella project for a $58.5 million Eximbank loan for four hydropower plants.

title: China Funds 300-bed China-Pakistan Friendship Hospital
description: In 2015, China funded a 300-bed China-Pakistan friendship hospital with a cost of Rs.9.96billion in Gwadar district, Balochista. This project will aim at creating a state-of-the-art medical facility in the port city of Gwadar. The project is proposed for implementation of Phase-II of 50-bedded hospital constructed under GDA Business Plan (Federal PSDP). The hospital is planned on 68 acres of land. As of August 2nd, 2018, the hospital consists of one medical block and some residential blocks. In order to upgrade the hospital to 300 beds five more medical blocks (with 50 beds each) will be constructed as well as nursing and paramedical institutes, medical college, central laboratory, and other allied facilities with a supply of medical equipment and machinery. Gwadar Development Authority will implement the project. Supervising agency is P&D Dept., Government of Balochistan and Planning, Development, and Reforms Commission. The specific funding organization is unknown. The CPEC website records the project with an estimated total cost of USD100 million, which is higher than the Rs 9.96 billion (roughly USD90 million) reported in the media article. Coder defers to the lower amount here.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASSAST0020170126eccv0000h&cat=a&ep=ASE, Academic Journal Article; http://cpecbulletin.com/2017/05/09/pak-china-friendship-hospital/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.beltroad-initiative.com/bri-factsheet-series-pakistan-china-friendship-hospital/, Other; http://cpec.gov.pk/project-details/38, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/8csdpteq2a5b3lj/2016%20Government%20of%20Pakistan%20Bond%20Prospectus.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/budget/Estimates_of_Foreign_Assistance_2018_19.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/budget/Estimates_of_Foreign_Assistance_2018_19.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://pk.chineseembassy.org/chn/zbgx/t1554975.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Funds Construction of New Gwadar Airport in Pakistan
description: In January 2015, China announced that it would soon begin construction of the New Gwadar International Airport in Pakistan. Pakistan has allocated 3000 acres of land 26km to the northwest of the current Gwadar International Airport for the new one. The design and work plan has already been agreed on, grant agreement was signed in May 2017, and construction work to begin in late 2017. The project is expected to be completed by the end of 2019 or early 2020 but is facing delays due to a change in funding type. The 2016 Government of Pakistan Bond Prospectus states the expected implementation start date as December 2016. This project is a part of the China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). The new airport should not be mistaken for the already existing one. According to both the CPEC and Pakistani Defense websites, the cost of the project totals 23 billion Pakistani Rupees. However, it is unclear how much of the cost is provided by China or in what ways. Both the Pakistani government monthly disbursement report in May 2017-2018 and the Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2017-2018 suggest that China has fulfilled part of the grant, PKR900million, USD equivalent of 8.531 million. The financial amount above is recorded as the confirmed disbursed figure. MOFCOM sources reported that the project is China's largest development assistance project in Pakistan.
