title: China to Construct Inland Container Depot in Timure, Nepal
description: In October 2014, China conducted the feasibility study for the project and signed the Memorandum of Understanding on development of the ICD with Nepal. On April 11 2015, China signed a Letter of Exchange with Nepal to construct the Inland Container Depot (ICD) in Timure, Rasuwagadi District of Nepal. China will cover all the expense except costs of purchasing land. The 6,900 m¬≤ ICD will includes two warehouses for storage and investigation before clearing, three quarantine check points for animals, plants and food testing, a parking lot for 315 freight vehicles, separate terminals for import and export, and food protection levee. China will also provide equipment for inspection and other infrastructure such as water tanks. On November 15, 2015, China sent a technical team to conduct the inspection of the site for construction. Nepal Intermodal Transport Development Board has acquired 8.5 hectares land for the project: 5 hectares from Langtang National Park and 3.5 hectares from the general public. The Chinese state-owned company, Architectural Reconnaissance and Design Institute of the Tibet Autonomous Region, has carried finished the design of the ICD. Construction was expected to begin from the end of October, 2018, however, as of October 27th, 2018, the construction has not begun. It is unclear what part of the Chinese government funded the project. SATFF_NOTE: This project is not label as implementation because the construction has not begun.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ATHIMT0020150411eb4b0000p&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://thehimalayantimes.com/business/construction-of-icd-timure-to-begin-from-october-end/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://thehimalayantimes.com/business/construction-work-of-timure-inland-container-depot-icd-to-begin/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/printedition/news/2015-03-09/china-moves-to-construct-inland-container-depot-at-rasuwagadhi.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://myrepublica.nagariknetwork.com/news/construction-of-dry-port-in-rasuwagadhi-yet-to-begin/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Architectural Reconnaissance and Design Institute of the Tibet Autonomous Region, State-Owned Company

title: China to build a small hydroelectric station on Sardoba reservoir
description: On May 17, 2017, President of Uzbekistan Shavkat Mirziyoyev declared that China had signed agreement for the construction of a new 15 MW hydroelectric power plant on the Sardoba Reservoir, Uzbekistan. The agreement was signed during Mirziyoyev's visit to China in 2017. The most up-to-date official source on the hydroelectric station on Sardoba reservoir is released on Feb 19, 2019, stating that the total costs of three projects ('modernization of Syrdarya thermal power station' and 'Farkhad hydroelectric station,''construction of a small hydroelectric station on Sardoba reservoir') would be 275 million USD, but the cost for this hydropower plant is unknown. Construction has begun on the projects.
sources: https://www.uzdaily.uz/en/post/39411, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://uzbekistan.lv/en/new-company-in-hydro-energy-sphere-to-be-established-in-uzbekistan/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://tashkenttimes.uz/economy/940-shavkat-mirziyoyev-inspects-sardoba-reservoir-construction-progress, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://mfa.uz/en/press/news/2019/02/17820/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.uzbekembassy.in/information-digest-of-press-of-uzbekistan-97-may-18-2017/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://kun.uz/en/news/2019/02/20/mirziyoyev-criticizes-officials-for-lack-of-industrial-facilities-in-rural-areas, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://web.archive.org/web/20180710093747/http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/zxxx_662805/t1464000.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China to fund the Pakistan-China Technical and Vocational Institute
description: The project is intended to impart specialized skills to Pakistanis so that they may be employed at the Gwadar Port, which is currently under major expansion as part of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor. The project will be executed bu Gwadar Port Authority Or any Financial Framework Agreement under CPEC and will be supervised by the Ministry of Maritime Affairs, Government of Pakistan and Planning, Development. According to the Chinese Embassy in Pakistan, the project is still under negotiation as of the end of 2018. The Pak-China Technical and Vocational Institute at Gwadar, Pakistan is a vocational school which will be set up by the Pakistani government at a cost of 943 million Pakistani rupees. The project was set to be completed by March 2016; however, it is still under construction as of 2018. The Pakistani government has allocated approximately 200 million rupees towards the project while the remaining 743 million rupees will be financed by the government of China. The specific funding agencies and form of funding are still unknown. The official China-Pakistani Economic Corridor states that that total cost of the project is 1,235,500,000 Pakistani rupees. The 2016 Government of Pakistan Bond Prospectus corroborates the transaction amount of 10 million USD. As of 2016, Pakistan was awaiting a response to the grant request from the Chinese MOC. According to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2017/18, the estimated cost for 2016-17 is 200 million Pak Rupees and that for 2017/18 is 400 million Pak Rupees. It is unclear if the cost is carried by the Chinese side or in what amount. In January 2017, the Pakistani governments Ports and Shipping Division contributed 20 million Pakistani rupees for The Pak-China Technical and Vocational Institute at Gwadar.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASSAST0020170126eccv0000h&cat=a&ep=ASE, Academic Journal Article; http://cpec.gov.pk/project-details/39, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/314653-cpec-is-project-of-inclusive-development-in-pakistan-planning-ministry&sa=U&ved=0ahUKEwjbrqXdjuvdAhUHhuAKHZJiAjwQFggXMAY&client=internal-uds-cse&cx=014389848304649563256:ureyfztd74a&usg=AOvVaw0ReGOkns9Ugjqf0IP6ZVxx, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/309970-govt-allocates-rs198-bn-for-cpec-projects, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pak-China_Technical_and_Vocational_Institute, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.finance.gov.pk/budget/Estimates_of_Foreign_Assistant_2017_18.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/budget/foreign_assistance_2016_17.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/8csdpteq2a5b3lj/2016%20Government%20of%20Pakistan%20Bond%20Prospectus.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.pc.gov.pk/uploads/archives/Details_of_Rleases_2016-17(06-01-2017).pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/budget/Estimates_of_Foreign_Assistant_2017_18.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://cpec.gov.pk/project-details/39, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://pk.chineseembassy.org/chn/zbgx/t1626098.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=NINTPK0020170118ed1i00035&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Gwadar Port Authority, State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: Gwadar Port Authority, State-Owned Company

title: China to invest USD44.6M in Harpo hydropower project, Pakistan (linked to #43228, #43229, #43230, #43231)
description: 5 September 2010 Besides these, China has taken up at least four other hydropower projects in these areas‚ÄîBhunji project in Gilgit-Baltistan, Kohala project (1100 MW), Naltar project and then smaller projects in places like Phendar, Harpo and Yuribo. 17 February 2014 The French Development Agency (AFD) and Germany‚Äôs Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ) will give 50 million euros and 20 million euros respectively towards the 35 MW Harpo hydropower project in Skardu district in Gilgit-Baltistan province, said Ali Raza Bhutta, joint secretary of the Federal Economic Affairs Division. The total cost of the project is 90 million euros. 24 May 2016 In addition to these undertakings, the Chinese firms are also working on six other power projects in Gilgit-Baltistan that include : US$7.8 billion Dasu Hydropower Project, US$ 70 million Phandar Project, US$ 40.01 million Bashu Hydropower Project, US$ 44.608 million Harpo Hydropower Project and US$ 6 billion Yulbo Hydropower Project. China is also investing an amount of US$ 300 million in housing, communication sectors. 9 June 2016 Other power generation projects are at various stages of construction, including 4,500MW Diamer Bhasha, 128MW Keyal Khwar, 106MW Golan Gol, 2,160 MW Dasu Hydropower Project, 34.5MW Harpo, 243MW 2nd Rehabilitation of Warsak Hydropower Station. WAPDA.gov The project area is located about 75 km north-west of Skardu town and 670 km north-east of Islamabad. - ECNEC approved PC-I amounting to Rs.9522.801 million approved by ECNEC on March 28, 2014. - Donor agencies KfW/AFD have conveyed their ‚ÄúNo Objection Certificate‚Äù on Development and Operation Agreement‚Äù. - NOC from KfW/AFD for combined evaluation (Technical & Financial Proposal) has been requested and reply awaited. - Chairman WAPDA and Chief Secretary GB along with Secretary KA&GB have signed the Development and Operation Agreement (D&OA) and submitted to EAD for counter signatures of Secretary EAD.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AIWINE0020100905e69500002&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.cpecinfo.com/cpec-news-detail.php?id=MTg0, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.ooskanews.com/story/2015/04/pakistan-approves-94-million-harpo-hydropower-project_164728, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pakobserver.net/2016/05/24/chinese-role-in-pak-development/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.wapda.gov.pk/index.php/projects/hydro-power/future/harpo, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://news.trust.org//item/20140217142812-dhgm0/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to support Construction of 61 KM Nawab shah Sanghar Road Project in Sindh, Pakistan
description: The Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2017-2018 suggests that despite earlier promises, the funding had not been disbursed by the Chinese side as of the end of 2017, and that no funding is planned for the year 2017-18.

title: China's Exim Bank Loans $88 million USD for coal-based power plant at Jhajjar, Haryana (Linked to #54344)
description: On November 17th, 2010, China's Export Import Bank loaned $88 million USD for the debt financing of the coal-based power plant at Jhajjar, Haryana. The coal-based power project was developed by CLP India Private Limited, a subsidiary of CLP Group. Construction began in January 2009. Stage one involved installing 660 MW capacity and that was commissioned March 2012. Stage two involved installing 660 MW capacity and was commissioned July, 2012. The loan has a duration of 13 years and 6 months, making the maturity date May 17th, 2024. The loan is described as a Sinosure-covered tranche. The loan is replacing a part of the Rs39 billion of the 15 year debt from a 2009 loan by IDBI. This project is co-financed by an $100 million USD by China Development Bank with the same terms (project #54344). This loan agreement is part of a larger syndicated loan for $288 million. The 5 institutions involved in the loan are the China Development Bank, the China Ex-Im Bank, The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, The Standard Chartered Bank, and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/qdih5dk09kqe8mc/IJGlobal%20-%20CLP%20Jhajjar%20Power%20Refinancing-%20India.pdf?dl=0, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.pp.u-tokyo.ac.jp/research/dp/documents/GraSPP-DP-E-14-003.pdf, Academic Journal Article; http://www.pp.u-tokyo.ac.jp/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/GraSPP-DP-E-14-003-SOM.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-document/67374/42933-ind-seia.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/vults7c3kv89j45/BU_PITCH_ENGLISH_2018.xlsx?dl=0, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://asian-power.com/regulation/news/clp-india-completes-228m-refinancing-jhajjar-plant, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.clpindia.in/media/CLP%20Jhajjar%20Financing%20India%20press%20release.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: China's Exim Bank Loans 2477.24 million rupees for the Raj Westpower Power Plant
description: On April 1st, 2009, China's Export-Import Bank loaned 2477.24 million rupees for the Raj Westpower (also known as the Barmer Plant) Power Plant, a 1080 MW lignite based pitehead power plant. This project was also funded by a 2477.24 million rupees loan by the ICICI Bank.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/1p8hb7lq43aqig2/IJGlobal%20-%20Raj%20Westpower%20power%20plant%20%281080MW%29%20-%20India.pdf?dl=0, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.jsw.in/energy/jsw-energy-barmer-plant, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: China's Exim Bank Loans to Create Food Transport Center in Bukhara (Linked to #54125)
description: In 2016, China's Xinjiang Silu Changlong Investment Co., Ltd committed to implementing, with the Ministry of Economy of Uzbekistan, a food transport center in Bukhara, Uzbekistan for the production, processing, and exportation of agricultural products. Total foreign financing will be $28.7 million; news sources report that this consists of investment by Xinjiang Silu Changlong Investment Co., Ltd. (project #54125) and a loan from the Eximbank of China, captured in this project. The breakdown of this financing is unclear. For the purpose of this project, $28.7 million has been coded as the transaction amount for the linked project, so as not to be double counted. The project will include a modern logistics center; 2 plants for processing of fruits, vegetables, meat and dairy products; a factory for the production of cardboard and plastic boxes; 4 refrigerators; energy efficient green houses; plant orchards using intensive technologies; and 20 refrigerated MAN trucks. The initial capacity of the project will be 10,000 products annually, and all fruits & vegetables will be exported.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=UZBDAY0020160718ec7i00031&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=TCASIA0020160722ec7m00002&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=TRENDE0020160719ec7j000jj&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.producereport.com/article/uzbekistan-china-broaden-cooperation-agriculture, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.uzbekistanitalia.org/home/fiera-internazionale-dell-ortofrutta/uzbekistanhasshowcasedsunnyfruitsandvegetablestotheworld, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.lex.uz/docs/3835897, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

implementing_agency: Xinjiang Silu Changlong Investment Co., Ltd, Private Sector; Ministry of Economy of Uzbekistan, Government Agency

title: China's Exim Bank loans $240 million USD to Uzbekhydroenergo for Hydropower Plant plant on Pskem River
description: In November 2017, it was reported that China's Export-Import Bank would loan $240 million to Uzbekhydroenergo for a hydropower plant on the Pskem River in the Bostanlyk district of the Tashkent region, Uzbekistan. The plant will cost a total of $800 million USD, with remaining other funding coming from Uzbekistan. Design and survey works for the project began in mid-2017. The projected capacity of the plant will be 400 MW with an average annual output of 900 million kWh. Loan details are unknown.
sources: https://www.energycentral.com/news/new-largest-hpp-appear-uzbekistan-0, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://eurasianet.org/uzbekistan-plans-its-own-hydropower-plant, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: Uzbekhydroenergo JSC, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Uzbekhydroenergo JSC, Government Agency

title: China's ICBC Loans $80 million USD to IL&FS
description: On September 13th, 2016, the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China loaned $80 million USD to Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services Group (IL&FS) for infrastructure projects and the creation of a subsidiary company in the transportation sector: IL&FS Transportation Networks Limited (ITNL). Terms of the loan are unclear. STAFF_NOTE: 5 MARCH 2019 Phone numbers and email addresses for contacts listed on page 3 of IL&FS source.

title: China-Pakistan Faqeer Primary School Project
description: On August 26 2016, Faqeer primary school opened up to 121 students. On September 1 2016, Nawaz Sharif, Prime Minister of Pakistan visited Gwadar for the school's inauguration, along with Chinese Ambassador Sun Weidong. On September 13 2016, Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan Sun Weidong visited the school. The Chinese Overseas Port HOlding Company (COPHC) donated books to help set up the school's library along with 380 school uniforms. The project is listed on CPEC website under the Gwadar project tab. The Chinese embassy website introduction to CPEC projects suggests that the project has a 0.399 million USD cost, covered by a Chinese government grant. The construction started in November 2015 and completed in September 2016. However, the exact commitment date is unclear.
sources: http://www.cpecinfo.com/gwadar-port-city, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/k2fbw5jdczjtj5g/Introduction%20to%20CPEC%20Project%20on%20Chinese%20Embassy%20Website%20in%20Pakistan%20September%202018.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://pk.chineseembassy.org/eng/zbgx/t1627110.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
implementing_agency: China Communications Construction Co., Ltd. (CCCC), State-Owned Company

title: China-funded Takuriabu Anti-drug Branch office building
description: On March 18, 2016, Yue Bin, the ambassador to Tajikistan, attended the completion handover ceremony of the office building of the China-funded Takuriabu Anti-drug Branch office building. The project was funded by Ministry of Public Security of China and implemented by China Jing'an Import & Export Corporation. The office building aided by the Chinese side is a three-story brick-concrete structure with a construction area of ‚Äã‚Äãmore than 1,000 square meters, including offices, equipment rooms, interrogation rooms, lounges.

title: Chinese Central Bank loans Tajikistan 20 million USD
description: In 2014, the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan, Amonatbok, and the Chinese Central Bank have negotiated a 20 million US concessional loan. The loan will be used for construction of the bank's new building and expansion of the bank's agricultural credit. The project's overall aim is to expand entrepreneurship and alleviate poverty in Tajikistan.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020140715ea7f0056c&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.avesta.tj/eng/goverment/3758-amonatbonk-peoples-bank-of-china-negotiating-on-allocation-of-concessional-loan.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Chinese EXIM Bank agrees to loan 988.46 Bangladeshi Taka Crore to Bangladesh to construct six TV stations
description: In November 2015, the Chinese EXIM Bank loaned Bangladesh 988.46 BDT crore to establish 5 regional TV stations through Bangladesh Television (BTV). Negotiations began in 2015 to establish 5 TV stations, but BTV announced plans for a 6th station after already signing the initial deal with the Chinese EXIM Bank. The 6th station in the Mymensing region will join the first 5 stations in the Rajshahi, Khulna, Sylhet, Rangpur, and Barisal regions. The loan details are unclear, but a Bangladeshi news agency, the Independent, reports that the loan is concessional. In October 2017, the Chinese state-owned organisations Aerospace Long March International Trade Company Limited (ALIT) and Radio, Film and TV Design and Research Institute (DRFT) secured contracts to help implement the project.

title: Chinese EXIM Bank loans $227 million to build Padma Water Plant in Bangladesh (linked to #34225)
description: In 2013, China committed to provide Bangladesh with $291 million to build the Padma (Josholdia) Water Treatment Plant, as a water treatment and sanitisation facility. China lent $227 million under a concessional loan from the EXIM Bank and $64 million under the Preferential Buyer's Credit (reflected in project #34225). The terms of both are 2% interest with a repayment period of 20 years (with a grace period of 5 years), with management and commitment fees at the rate of 0.2 per cent. The Dhaka Water and Sewage Authority contracted the Chinese SOE, CAMC Engineering Co. to construct the plant. Construction started in January 2013, and is expected to be completed by June 2016. As of 2018, the Bangladesh Bridge Authority reported significant delays, resulting in the project being overdue.

title: Chinese Embassy Establishes Gulafshon Sewing Training Center
description: In June 2014, the Chinese Embassy of Tajikistan helped to establish a sewing training center 'Gulafshon' in Dushanbe and employs 60 women. On June 4, Zhao Xiangrong, the Chinese Ambassador to Tajikistan, attended the inauguration ceremony of the ‚ÄúGulafushang‚Äù Women's Sewing Training Production Center. Others attending included Mr. Ratibov, Vice Chairman of the People‚Äôs Democratic Party of the People‚Äôs Republic of China, Kurbova, Vice Mayor of Dushanbe, Mrs. Sun Wei, the wife of the Political Counselor of the Embassy, and more than 100 representatives from the relevant departments of the tower and local women and children. STAFF_NOTE: Transaction amount was not found. Coder decided that this is most likely a grant.
sources: http://www.avesta.tj/eng/4732-chinese-embassy-supports-to-open-sewing-center-in-varzob-district.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://tj.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t1162244.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chinanews.com/gn/2014/07-16/6391048.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Construction of 47 houses in H.Dh Nolhivaranfaru (linked to #54166)
description: On October 24, 2008, Maldives and China signed an agreement for the construction of 47 housing units in Hdh Attol. Nolhivaranfaru funded by a Chinese grant of 40,000,000 RMB. The Maldives Government Budget Summary from 2013-2015 lists the actual disbursement amount as 175,504,781 Rufiyaa in 2011. The transaction amount has been coded as 40 million CNY, because that is the amount an official Maldives source refers to as the transaction amount from the original grant agreement. The agreement was sighed by Dr. Husain Niyaz, Executive Director at the Department of External Resources of Maldives, and Guo Rushaan, Managing Director at the China Shanghai Group Corporation, the contracting agency. Construction started in June 2009, and the project was expected to be completed in December 2010. It seems that this project was completed, and project ID #54166 is a follow-up project for the construction of additional houses in Nolhivaranfaru.
sources: http://isles.egov.mv/Island/IslandProjects.aspx?lid=2&tid=1&cid=6&id=48, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://lk.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t768118.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.mv/public/attachments/BFdQChbFNpNL5dXAsb67yjlwEPD6FhJqwTcdtVdv.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.maldivesinfo.gov.mv/home/files/bulletinx_det.php?id_news=1062, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://saruna.mnu.edu.mv/jspui/bitstream/123456789/3217/1/2011-03-28%20-%20Nolhivaranfaru%20100%20Housing%20Units.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.miteco.gob.es/es/parques-nacionales-oapn/proyectos-de-cooperacion/Producto-H_tcm30-287669.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://presidencymaldives.gov.mv/Press/Article/1495, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Construction of Out Patient Department (OPD) of National Hospital (NHSL)
description: On 16 September 2014, the Government of China signed a 138 million USD grant agreement with Sri Lanka for the construction of a new Outpatient Department (OPD) of the National Hospital (NHSL) (see 'Resource Mobilization' from Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). The project work began in 2017, and as of May 2019 is ongoing. The building will be nine stories, and will contain an emergency department, an outpatient center, clinics (ex: Obstetrics, Gynecology and Paediatrics), medical and technology rooms, and administrative offices. It is expected to be 49,150 square meters. The project is being undertaken as an attempt to make up for the lack of repairs to the current outpatient center, which sees 5000 patients each day. The construction will be completed by 2020. According to a press release by the Chinese Agency for International Economic Cooperation on Apr 19, 2017, the chairman of CPPCC (Chinese People's Political Consultative conference), Yu Zhengsheng attended the foundation laying ceremony in Sri Lanka on April 6. The project is undertaken by the China Railway 25th Bureau Group Co., Ltd., with a construction period of 39 months.

title: Conversion of RMB11.099 million loan to grant for Bangabandhu International Convention Centre (linked to project #33925)
description: In 2002, the Foreign Minister of China stated Beijing converted RMB11.099 million out of a total loan of RMB200 million into a grant for the China-Bangladesh Friendship Conference Center. The center, constructed in Dhaka, has been presented to Bangladesh as a gift. The agreement occurred between Foreign Minister M. Morshed Khan and Prime Minister Begum Khaleda Zia's visit to China. The project was renamed Bangabandhu International Convention Centre in 2009. This project captures the grant portion; for the interest-free loan portion, see project #33925.

title: Development of 1500 Housing Units (Phase 2)
description: In September 2012, President Dr. Mohamed Waheed and Premier Wen Jiabao signed two agreements regarding the provision of a concessional loan of 982,500,000 RMB for a housing development project in the Maldives. This housing project broke ground in December 2014 and the 1500 units, built by contractor China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) and dispersed across 9 different islands, was completed in December 2017. A breakdown of the 1500 housing unit locations by island is as follows: Hulhumale, Kaafu atoll ‚Äì 704 housing units Hithadhoo, Addu atoll ‚Äì 264 housing units Hulhumeedhoo, Addu atoll ‚Äì 48 housing units Fuvahmulah, Gnaviyani atoll ‚Äì 200 housing units Villingili, Gaafu Alif atoll ‚Äì 52 housing units Gahdhoo, Gaafu Dhaal atoll ‚Äì 50 housing units Thinadhoo, Gaafu Dhaal atoll ‚Äì 120 housing units Madaveli, Gaafu Dhaal atoll ‚Äì 22 housing units Hoadehdhoo, Gaafu Dhaal atoll ‚Äì 40 housing units For the above listed Thinadhoo Island project, which falls under the China Eximbank-funded 1500 housing unit project, the inauguration ceremony took place in 2015. 80 of the 120 housing units were designated for Thinadhoo residents, 25 of the 120 housing units were allotted for people who migrated to the island, and the rest would be sold through open bidding. Disbursements per year of China Exim Bank loan funds for this project according to Maldives government sources: 2013: 722,137,500 MVR according to Budget in Statistics 2015 2015: 408,181,393 MVR according to Budget in Statistics 2017 [actual] 2016: 727,400,058 MVR according to Budget in Statistics 2018 [actual] 2017: 269,306,723 MVR according to Loans - Budget 2019 [actual] 2018: 63,239,487 MVR according to Loans - Budget 2019 [revised] 2019: 72,174,857 MVR according to Loans - Budget 2019 [budgeted] STAFF_NOTE: The purpose of funds disbursed after completion of construction is unclear. The December 2017 handover ceremony was reported by the Maldives Housing Development Corporation, and that source is included in this project.

title: EXIM Bank loans Sri Lanka USD104.3 million for Lotus Tower
description: Sri Lanka and China have signed an agreement for the construction of the South Asia's tallest tower, a multi-faceted telecommunication tower and leisure park that will be named the Lotus Tower ('Nelum Kuluna'). The project will be completed by the end of 2015. The Telecommunication Regulatory Commission of Sri Lanka will finance and implement the project with technical assistance from the Faculty of Architecture of the University of Moratuwa. A Chinese conglomerate comprising China National Electronics Import and Export Corporation and Aerospace Long-March International Trade Co.Ltd., will complete the project on a turnkey basis.The construction is estimated to cost 104.3 Million U.S.Dollars and it will be funded by China EXIM Bank. Recently, the Sri Lankan government has announced that the 'Lotus Tower'' project is to be reviewed, in order to assess whether the construction of the tower should continue. Sri Lanka's Ports and Aviation Minister Arjuna Ranatunga claims that construction is taking place on land that belongs to the Ports Authority without proper government protocol. As of 2019 March, the project is expected to be completed by 2020. STAFF_NOTE: This project is confirmed by Director of China and AIIB Division, External Resources Department, Ministry of National Policies and Economic Affairs, Sri Lanka

title: EXIM Bank provides $88.5m USD loan for three industrial TALCO aluminum plants
description: In July 2016, the Tajik Aluminum Company (TALCO) was expected to put three industrial plants into operation in the Yovon district. One plant will produce 18,000 tons of aluminum fluoride annually, another will produce 12,000 tons of cryolite, and another will produce 130,000 tons of sulfuric acid. The plants are part of a five-year plan to shift Tajikistan's aluminum smelters to domestic raw materials. Construction originally began in 2008, and the total cost was $126 million USD. This includes the $88.5 million soft loan provided by China Exim Bank, and $37 million invested by TALCO. News report from Asia Plus in July 2016 says that in June 2014, TALCO reportedly signed a contract with China National Heavy Machinery Corporation on completion of work on introducing these plants into operation, and that the three plants were expected to be introduced into operation in Yovon July of that year. A press statement from the Chinese embassy indicates that the project had been finished by as late as October, 2016.

title: EXIM Bank provides USD 464 million loan for the 747 MW Guddu Combined Cycle Project
description: On September 20, 2009, Pakistan Electric Power Company (PEPCO) and Harbin Power Engineering (HPE) sighed a contract for a 747 MW Combined Cycle Project at Guddu Power Company. The project is expected to have a net efficiency of 54.5 percent. HPE has been involved in other power projects in Pakistan, and will be using size 9-FA gas turbines from General Electric USA. In June 2012, Harbin reportedly completed 50 percent of the project, but top management voiced concerns over employee's safety after fighting between tribal groups. The officials at Pakistan's Ministry of Water and Power wanted the project to be completed in June 2013. China Exim Bank is providing a credit of $464 million backed by Chinese insurance company Sinosure. The government of Pakistan already provided $40 million USD to Sinosure. The total cost of the 747 Guddu project stands at $550 million. A Pakistani ministry of finance government project status report - disbursement report in April from 2015-2016 records the project as a loan of a committed amount of 464.08 million USD. The project has a start date of 23.12.2011 and an end date of 23.12.2015. The report suggests that 71.25 million of the total loan was fulfilled. STAFF_NOTE: Monthly Disbursement Report states executing agency as Wapda Power. Listed under 'fin' tab of source.

title: Exim Bank loans Tajikistan $200 million to construct hydroelectric power plant on Zarafshon River
description: In 2007, China Exim Bank and Tajikistan's Ministry of Finance signed an agreement for a 200 million USD loan for the construction of a 150 MW hydroelectric power plant on the Zarafshon River. The loan has a maturity of 25 years and 1% annual interest rate. SinoHydro will be constructing the plant, and the project is expected to take three years. The power plant will have a capacity of 150 MW with an annual output of 0.6 billion kilowatt-hours. The project also includes the construction of a 60- kilometer, 220-kilovolt power transmission line to carry electric power from the HPS to sub-station Rudaki in the city of Panjakent. STAFF_NOTE: River also spelled Zeravshan.

title: Eximbank loan for 12 dams, Pakistan
description: In 2009, Pakistan signed an agreement with China for the $1 billion construction of a series of 12 small dams for electricity generation and irrigation purposes. Under the terms and conditions, China EXIM Bank would provide a loan of $700 million, while Pakistan would provide $300 million. The dams would be constructed in all 4 of the Pakistani provinces and would irrigate about 650 000 acres of barren land.

title: Extension of Southern Expressway Section 1 from Matara to Beliatta (link to projects ID #53526, #33488, #53522 and #53529)
description: On 9 December 2014, China Eximbank signed a 684 million USD concessional loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Extension of Southern Expressway Project (ESEP) Section 1 from Matara to Beliatta. which accounts for 85% of the total project cost. The loan has an interest rate of 2% and a maturity of 20 years, including a 5 year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2014 Annual Performance Report). According to the 2017 Government of Sri Lanka Bond Prospectus, the estimated total project cost was 804.11 million USD. The 15% of the project cost not covered by the China Eximbank loan would be financed by the Government of Sri Lanka. The objective of ESEP is to enhance the efficiency of the transport system by linking the country's major economic centers with Colombo City and other parts of the country. Under this objective, ESEP Section 1 consists of the construction of a 30 km length road section from Matara to Beliatta. The scope of this project includes the construction of 3 interchanges, 28 underpasses, 8 overpasses, 7 bridges, and 74 box culverts. ESEP Section 1 commenced on 19 January 2016 and was completed on 19 January 2019 (see 'Resource Mobilization' from the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). The Southern Expressway Extension Project is implemented by AVIC International Engineering Corporation (a subsidiary of Aviation Industry Corporation of China), China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC or 'China State Construction') and China Harbour Engineering Corporation (CHEC). The China Railway First Survey and Design Institute Group l is responsible for supervision and consultation. For information on other sections of ESEP, see projects ID #53526 (Section 2), #33488 (Section 3), and #53522 (Section 4). Additionally, China Eximbank provided a loan to fund consultancy services for the expressway (see project ID #53529).

title: Extension of Southern Expressway Section 2 from Beliatta to Wetiya (link to projects ID #38337, #33488, #53522 and #53529)
description: On 7 April 2016, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a 360.3 million USD concessional loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Extension of Southern Expressway Project (ESEP) Section 2 from Beliatta to Wetiya (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2016 Annual Performance Report). Based on information from IJGlobal Project Finance & Infrastructure Journal, the total project cost is 498.58 million USD, and the project's debt-equity ratio is 85:15. The USD 423.58 million debt portion is funded by two loans. The first loan is a USD 360 million loan from China Exim Bank with a 20-year maturity, 5 year grace period and 2% interest rate. The China Exim Bank loan includes an upfront fee of 25bp and a commitment fee of 25bp paid each year. The second loan is a USD 63.58 million loan from Hatton National Bank. The Road Development Authority of Sri Lanka provided the equity funding amounting to USD 75 million. For the purpose of this project, only the USD 360 million loan (USD 360.3 million according to the 2016 Annual Performance Report) from China Exim Bank has been recorded. The objective of ESEP is to enhance the efficiency of the transport system by linking the country's major economic centers with Colombo City and other parts of the country. Under this objective, ESEP Section 2 consists of the construction of a 26 km length road section from Beliatta to Wetiya. The scope of this project includes the construction of 2 interchanges, 26 underpasses, 7 overpasses, 8 bridges, and 70 box culverts. The contractor for this project is China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC). ESEP Section 2 commenced on 28 October 2016, and this section has a target completion date of 27 October 2019 (see 'Extension of Southern Expressway' from Road Development Authority). As of 31 December 2018, this section was 61.23% complete. For information on other sections of ESEP, see projects ID #38337 (Section 1), #33488 (Section 3), and #53522 (Section 4). Additionally, China Eximbank provided a loan to fund consultancy services for the expressway (see project ID #53529).

title: Extension of Southern Expressway Section 3 from Wetiya to Andarawewa (also known as Hambantota Hub Development Project) (link to projects ID #38337, #53526, #53522 and #53529)
description: On 16 September 2014, EXIM Bank of China signed a 1,555,990,000 CNY concessional loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Extension of Southern Expressway Project (ESEP) Section 3 from Wetiya to Andarawewa, also known as the Hambantota Hub Development Project. The loan, which covers the total estimated cost of the project, has an interest rate of 2% and a maturity of 20 years, including a 5 year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2014 Annual Performance Report). The objective of ESEP is to enhance the efficiency of the transport system by linking the country's major economic centers with Colombo City and other parts of the country. Under this objective, ESEP Section 3 consists of the construction of a 15 km length road section from Wetiya to Andarawewa. The scope of this project includes the construction of 1 viaduct, 18 underpasses, 5 overpasses, 2 bridges, 45 box culverts, and 6 pipe culverts. This project also includes the construction of the Ranna-Wetiya Road (HR 21) and Sooriyawewa-Galwewa Junction-Embilipitiya Road (HR 06, HR 10). The contractor for this project is China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC). ESEP Section 3 commenced on 25 January 2016, and this section has a target completion date of 24 March 2019 (see 'Extension of Southern Expressway' from Road Development Authority). As of 31 December 2018, the expansion was 88.77% complete. The original target completion date was 24 January 2018, but this project is behind schedule due to soil issues and delay in possession of the site. For information on other sections of ESEP, see projects ID #38337 (Section 1), #53526 (Section 2), and #53522 (Section 4). Additionally, China Eximbank provided a loan to fund consultancy services for the expressway (see project ID #53529).

title: Extension of Southern Expressway Section 4 from Mattala to Hambantota via Andarawewa (link to projects ID #38337, #53526, #33488 and #53529)
description: On 16 September 2014, China Eximbank signed a 2,528,170,000 CNY concessional loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Extension of Southern Expressway Project (ESEP) Section 4 from Mattala to Hambantota via Andarawewa. The loan has an interest rate of 2% and a maturity of 20 years, including a 5 year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2014 Annual Performance Report). According to the 2017 Government of Sri Lanka Bond Prospectus, this loan covers the total estimated cost of the project. The objective of ESEP is to enhance the efficiency of the transport system by linking the country's major economic centers with Colombo City and other parts of the country. Under this objective, ESEP Section 4 consists of the construction of a 25 km length road section from Mattala to Hambantota via Andarewa. The scope of this project includes the construction of 2 viaducts, 1 interchange, 6 bridges, 2 bridge underpasses, 2 overpasses, 10 culvert underpasses, 61 box culverts, and 1 aqueduct. The contractor for this project is China Harbour Engineering Company Ltd. (CHEC). ESEP Section 4 commenced on 19 January 2016, and this section has a target completion date of 28 May 2019 (see 'Extension of Southern Expressway' from Road Development Authority). As of 31 December 2018, this section was 86.06% complete. For information on other sections of ESEP, see projects ID #38337 (Section 1), #53526 (Section 2), and #33488 (Section 3). Additionally, China Eximbank provided a loan to fund consultancy services for the expressway (see project ID #53529).

title: Funding for construction of Multi Functional Centre of Presidential Palace
description: Construction for the Multifunction Centre Project in Afghan Presidential Palace began on 2 June 2008. Construction was carried out by China Railway Shisiju Group Corporation (China Railway 14th Group Corporation - updated November 2018), a subsidiary of China Railway Construction Corporation Limited. China Friendship Development International Engineering Design & Consultation Corporation (FDDC) was also involved in the project. The project is one of Chinese government foreign aid project to Afghanistan; China funds the construction of the project which cost about 32.7 million Chinese Yuan. The Multifunction Centre is used primarily for state dinners and press conferences; the project covers an area of ‚Äã‚Äã1150 square meters, construction area of ‚Äã‚Äã2979 square meters. On 22 December 2009, Ambassador to Afghanistan Zheng Qingdian, was invited for a presidential visit to inspect the progress of the multi-purpose hall project; high standards and strict requirements were expected in ensuring project quality especially for the 55th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic ties. Construction of the building was completed at the end of December 2009.

title: Greater Kurunegala Water Supply & Sanitation (Sewerage) Project
description: On 18 September 2013, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a 487 million CNY concessional loan agreement with Sri Lanka to fund the Greater Kurunegala Water Supply & Sanitation Project (also listed as Greater Kurunegala Water Supply and Sewerage project). The loan has a 2% fixed interest rate, a 5 year grace period, and a maturity of 19 years (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2013 Annual Performance Report). The project began on 26 February 2014 and was completed on 31 August 2018 (see 'Resource Mobilization' from Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). This project was constructed by China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC). The objective of the project is to meet the present and future demand of drinking water in the Greater Kurunegala area by increasing water supply capacity from 6500m3/d to 13000m3/d and establishing a proper waste water disposal system with a capacity 0f 4500m3/d. This will be accomplished by the construction of a new treatment plant, a pipe sewer network (135 km), water transmission lines(8km), water distribution network(110km), and two elevated water towers (Kurunagala 1750 m3/d, 750 m3/d at Vahara). STAFF_NOTE: Some mention of export credits in sources, coded as loan due to official source indication.

title: Hambantota Bunkering Project (also known as Bunkering Facility & Tank Farm Project)
description: On 8 June 2009, China Exim Bank signed a 65 million USD loan agreement with the Sri Lankan government for the construction of a bunkering facility at the new Hambantota Port, known as the Hambantota Bunkering Project or the Bunkering Facility & Tank Farm Project. The contract for the project was awarded to the China Huanqiu Contracting and Engineering Corporation. The loan has a maturity of 15 years including 3 years of grace period. The interest rate is not found. The total project amount was listed as US$96 million, but it is unclear who will be providing the remaining funding. According to the China Huanqiu Contracting & Engineering Co. website, the mechanical works for this project were completed on 10 October 2011, and according to the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources the project reached full completion on 8 June 2012. STAFF_NOTE: Because the interest rate is not specified in available resources, the flow class has been coded as Vague (Official Finance). The bunkering facility and tank farm was located 1.2km from the waterfront, and will be connected to the oil terminal through a pipeline. The facility has 14 tanks (total storage of 80,000 m3). Bunkering operations began in 2014, and are run by the SPLA; these operation were suspended due to a loss of $19.9 million as a result of irregularities.

title: Hambantota International Airport (also known as Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport or Southern International Airport)
description: STAFF_NOTE: Confirmed by Director- China and AIIB Division, External Resources Department, Ministry of National Policies and Economic Affairs, Sri Lanka In 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China gave Sri Lanka a $190 million concessional loan for the construction of the Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport (also known as Hambantota International Airport or the Southern International Airport) in the city of Hambantota which is located in southeast Sri Lanka. The airport is being constructed by the China Harbour Engineering Company, their first airport construction project ever taken. The total cost of the airport was US$209 million. The goal of this project was to provide an alternative airport, located in Mattala, for the Bandaranaike international Airport. The project involved the construction of a 4Km loan runway, a parking apron, a taxiway connecting the runaway and the apron, a terminal building, cargo storage, a fuel arm, and a fire service building. The project has two phases. Construction began on March 5, 2010, and the entire Phase-1 construction was completed in 2012 while the entire project was finished on March 5th, 2014. While some reports quoted a loan amount of US$209 million, Sri Lanka's Department of External Resources (ERD) quoted a loan amount of US$190 million.

title: Hambantota Port Development Project - Phase II: 1 billion CNY Concessional Loan (link to projects ID #33481, #39023 and #39025)
description: Based on Sri Lanka's Department of External Resources (ERD) 2012 Performance Report, EXIM Bank of China, on 17 September 2012, has signed an agreement to provide a total loan of $809.35 million to the government of Sri Lanka for phase II of the port construction in Hambantota (umbrella project #33481). The $809.35 million loan was provided in 3 segments, one of the segment is Government Concessional Loan (GCL)- CNY 1 billion, with 2% interest rate, 0.5% management fee, 0.5% commitment fee and a repayment period of 19 years including 6 years of grace period (captured in this project). According to the Department of External Resources, the loan funds are still being utilized by the project (see 'Resource Mobilization'). For the other two segments of the loan see #39023 and #39025. Based on ERD Disbursements of Foreign Funded Loan/Grant 2014, EXIM Bank had disbursed a loan amount of US$299,817,176.39 in the period of May to December 2014. China Communications Construction Company has been assigned as the contractor for the second phase of Hambantota port. ERD also reported that China Harbour Engineering Com. Ltd. would also be involved in the project. The project was commenced in 2012, and will include the construction of a quay wall (2140 m long) to accommodate 6 container berths, oil terminal (300 meters long), yard & roads, a flyover bridge, deepening of entrance channel (450 m wide, 840 m long, 18 meter deep), 2 feeder berths, construction of an artificial island (50 Ha) & handling facilities, and excavating a new basin area. An extension has been granted to the project up through May 2018, despite the original completion date being planned for November 2015. As of December 31st, 2017, the project was at 96% physical completion. The new port complex required the acquisition of 1,500Ha of land. The project envisaged a large industrial area and a shipyard facility. The port in Hambantota, deeper than the one at Colombo, is to be used as a refueling and docking station for the Sri Lankan Navy.

title: Hambantota Port Development Project Phase I - Ancillary Works & Supply of Equipment Project (linked to #33256)
description: On 24 March 2013, China and Sri Lanka signed a CNY 960 million concessional loan agreement for the Hambantota Port Development Phase I - Ancillary Works and Supply of Equipment. The loan would be provided by China Eximbank to deepen the harbor basin one additional meter, dredge for approaching channel, provide additional work on the oil terminal, generate breakwater and revetment modification and handling facilities, provide a new administration and services building, and change specification of navigational aid and price escalation. The loan has a fixed interest rate of 2%, a grace period of 5 years and a maturity of 20 years (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources Performance Report 2013, page 52 of PDF). Project implementation began on 24 April 2013 and was completed on 24 April 2015.

title: Hunan Branch of EXIM Bank of China will fund USD $67M construction of Kattankudy Waste Water Disposal Project
description: In a 2017 Performance Report by the Sri Lankan Department of External Resources, it was reported that the Hunan Branch of the Export-Import Bank of China will provide a US$67 million loan for the construction of Kattankudy Waste Water Disposal Project (determined to be also known as Kattankudy Division Sewerage Disposal Project), which will be implemented in 2018. The project will provide sewerage connections for Baticolao municipal council area and Kattankudy DS division area will be covered. A 50km collection network and 10,500m3/day wastewater treatment plant will be constructed. The total project cost will be $92.8 million.

title: ICBC loans 100 million USD to Sachal 100 MW Wind Power project in Jhimpir, Pakistan (CPEC, IPP)
description: Sachal Energy Development (Ptd) Limited's 49.5 MW wind power generation project is located at Jhimpir, District Thatta, Province of Sindh, Pakistan. Sachal Energy Development (Ptd) Limited is 100% owned by Arif Habib Corporation Limited. According to the National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA), the total project cost is 130.481 Million USD. The project achieved commercial operation on April 10, 2017. The debt-equity ratio of the project is 80:20. Hydrochina Corporation is the Offshore EPC Contractor and Hydrochina International Engineering Company Ltd Pakistan is the Onshore EPC Contractor for this project. Goldwind provided 33 Wind Turbine Generators with a capacity of 1.5 MW each. Sachal Energy Development Pvt Ltd entered into a foreign facility agreement with ICBC China on February 15, 2015 for an amount of 100 Million USD. This was later revised to 104.385 Million USD to reflect the 80% debt component of the total project cost. The interest rate is 6 Months LIBOR (1.4154%) + 3.75%. The repayment period of 10 years was determined according to the Debt Service Schedule on a 2018 document released by NEPRA. The project's inauguration ceremony was held on April 20 2015 during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Pakistan. According to ICBC, the project is the first private new energy loan project in Pakistan undertaken by China Export and Credit Insurance Corporation (SINOSURE), and is also the first project to complete loan signing under CPEC. A 2013 Tariff Petition Determination document released by National Electric Power Regulatory Authority stated that the debt was to be shared between China CITIC Bank (80% of debt) and Askari Bank Limited (20% of debt). However, the Tariff Petition was ultimately rejected, which suggests that ICBC may have become the sole foreign financier to the project.

title: Irufen Island Resort Project
description: On 14 December 2017, China's Export-Import Bank signed a 127.5 million USD loan agreement with Ahmed Siyam Holdings Pvt Ltd for the Irufen Island Resort Project. China Communications Construction Company was contracted in late January 2016 to implement the project. The resort will be the biggest in the Maldives with 509 rooms. At the end of September 2018, the disbursed outstanding debt was 42,061,601 USD. The project appears to be in implementation because the Maldives Ministry of Finance reported disbursement of a portion of the loan funds, but the current status of the project is unclear. The loan details are not specified in available documents.

title: Kandy North Pathadumbara Integrated Water Supply Project
description: On 22 December 2017, China Eximbank signed a 1,636,600,000 CNY concessional loan agreement for the Kandy North Pathadumbara Integrated Water Supply Project. This loan will cover the total cost of the project, and it has an interest rate of 2% and a maturity of 20 years, including a 6 year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2017 Annual Performance Report). The objective of this project is to provide safe pipe-borne water supply facility to six divisions, namely Pathadumbara, Harispattuwa, Akurana, Pujapitiya, Kandy Four Gravets and Thumpane. The scope of this project includes the construction of a clear water reservoir (2100m3 within existing water treatment plant), a filtration unit, a flocculation unit, a new pump station and improvements to existing stations, Slude lagoon, service reservoirs, and pump houses. The project also includes the improvement of existing pump stations and the supply and laying of distribution lines and transmission lines. As of 31 March 2018 there was no physical progress on this project, and loan funds had yet to be disbursed. The loan agreement had been finalized, but cabinet approval was needed for deviations. Land acquiring and procurement activities were in progress (see 'Progress...as of 31 March 2018' from Department of Project Management). The project is expected to be completed in 2021.

title: Laamu Atoll Link Road Project
description: During Xi Jinping's visit to Maldives in late 2014, the Chinese delegation expressed its interest in participating to the construction of the Laamu Ring Reef Road Connection (ÊãâÁ©ÜÁéØÁ§ÅËøûÊé•ÂÖ¨Ë∑Ø) project and the groundbreaking ceremony took place on December 15, 2014, with a Chinese Government grant supporting the project. In November 2016, the construction of the road finished and it was opened. HEP Abdulla Yameen officially inaugurated the road on 8 September 2018. The 15.1-kilometer road connects Fonadhoo, Kahdhoo, Maandhoo and Gan. The road was designed by CCCC Second Harbour Engineering and built by Jiangsu Transportation Engineering Group. The Maldives Ministry of Housing and Urban Development reported in September 2018 that the China-funded project cost 447 million MVR, and the Maldives Ministry of Finance and Treasury in its Government Budget in Statistics documents reports disbursements by year for this grant that total 440,534,097 MVR. The transaction amount in this project has been recorded as 447 million MVR based on the article from the Ministry of Housing and Development, since the final actual disbursement figures were not available for 2015 and 2017 in the Maldives Government Budget in Statistics documents. This road project was funded by a Chinese government grant, and the disbursements by year are as follows: -2014: 1,518,337 MVR [Actual] according to Maldives Government Budget in Statistics 2016 -2015: 321,095,196 MVR [Revised] according to Maldives Government Budget in Statistics 2016 -2016: 108,068,170 MVR [Actual] according to Maldives Government Budget in Statistics 2017 -2017: 9,852,394 MVR [Estimate] according to Maldives Government Budget in Statistics 2017 STAFF_NOTE: A 2016 vNews article claims the project cost 171.7 million MVR, a 2018 Public Service Media article claims the project cost USD 2 million, and a 2014 Sun Media Group article claims the project cost USD 30 million. The transaction amount recorded in this project is based off the 447 million MVR figure reported by the Maldives Ministry of Housing and Urban Development, which is close to the grant disbursement amounts for this project that the Maldives Ministry of Finance and Treasury reported in the Government Budget in Statistics 2016 & 2017 documents. There was no information related to this project in the Government Budget in Statistics 2018 document.

title: Matara Beliatta Section of Matara Kataragama Railway Extension: Concessional Loan (link to project ID #33396)
description: On 28 May 2013, EXIM Bank signed a 508 million CNY concessional loan agreement with Sri Lanka to finance the Matara-Beliatta Section of the Matara-Kataragama Railway Extension Project. The loan has an interest rate of 2% with a repayment period of 20 years including a seven year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2013 Annual Performance Report). The total cost of the project is 278.2 million USD, with the remainder of the funds coming from a China Eximbank 200 million USD preferential buyer's credit (see project ID #33396). This project began on 19 February 2013 and was completed on 31 December 2018 (see 'Resource Mobilization' from the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). The main goal of the project is to improve transport in the southern region. This project involves the construction of 26.75km length of single line broad gauge rail track from Matara to Beliatta; the construction of structures such as culverts, bridges, viaducts those required over the Nilwala river flood plain, level crossings, underpasses, overpasses, and tunnels; as well as the construction of four numbers railway crossing stations, 2 numbers sub stations and functional requirements of stations (see 'Resource Mobilization').

title: National Arts Theater (Nelum Pokuna Performance Art Center)
description: In 2004, the Chinese government agreed to provide $17 million (150 million RMB) to Sri Lanka for the construction of the proposed National Arts Theater in capital Colombo. Construction began in 2006 and was completed around early 2011. It was opened in December 2011. This has also been known by the names of Nelum Pokuna Performance Art Center, and Nelum Pokuna Mahinda Rajapaksa Theatre.

title: National Museum in Sultan Park, Male
description: China began construction on a national museum in 2007 in Sultan Park, Male, Maldives with funding from a Chinese Government grant. Based on information from Maldives Government Budget reports that detail grant disbursements from China for this national museum project, the Chinese grant funding totaled MVR 61.6 million. The project reportedly cost a total of USD 7.8 million, and it is unclear whether or not the Chinese Government grant covered the total cost of the project. The project broke ground during an official ceremony on November 16, 2007. It was completed, then handed over to Maldives on July 10, 2010. Annual Disbursement Amounts: 2008: 21.3 million MVR (Rev. Estimate, Maldives' 2009 Government Budget report) 2009 40.3 million MVR (Actual Maldives' 2010 Government Budget report) STAFF_NOTE: The 2007 Maldives Budget in Statistics document lists a 15.5 million MVR estimated disbursement for 2006 for this project, but later documents (2008 & 2009) list no disbursement from 2006 for this project, so it seems the 2006 transaction never occurred.

title: Outer Circular Highway Project - Phase III (Kadawatha to Kerwalapitiya)
description: On 4 September 2014, the 'Construction of Outer Circular Highway Project ‚Äì Phase III' (OCH III) was approved by the Sri Lankan Cabinet. The circular highway is located at the Colombo Metropolitan Region and passes through two administrative districts, namely Colombo and Gampaha. The Project consists of three main sections namely, Kottawa to Kaduwela (11.0 km) (Phase I), Kaduwela to Kadawatha (8.9 km) (Phase II), and Kadawatha to Kerawalapitiya (9.32 km) (Phase III). For the purpose of this project, only funding and details for Phase III are captured because China does not appear to have contributed funding to Phase I or Phase II. On 16 September 2014, EXIM Bank of China signed an agreement with Sri Lanka to provide a loan of 494.03 million USD for the third phase of the OCH. The loan accounts for 95% of the total project cost and has a 2% interest rate, with a 0.25% commitment fee and a one-off 0.25% management fee, as well as a maturity of 20 years including 5 years of grace period (ERD Performance Report 2014). According to the 2017 Sri Lanka Government Bond Prospectus, the estimated total cost of the project was 520.04 million USD. The remaining 5% of total costs would be covered by the Government of Sri Lanka (see 'Basic Project Details' from the Ministry of Highways). On 21 February 2013, Metallurgical Corporation of China Ltd (MCC) was awarded the contract for the Outer Circular Highway project. The project commenced on 1 January 2016 and is expected to be completed by 30 June 2019 (see 'Outer Circular Highway Project - Phase III' from Road Development Authority). As of 30 September 2018, the project was 75.9% complete. A 2017 progress report listed the project as behind schedule due to poor contractor performance. A 2017 report indicates that there was a delay with construction of Kadawatha IC and overpass bridges, as well as a delay in land acquisition at Kadawatha IC due to trade union activities in the survey department. Finally, another report ('Progress ... as of 30 September 2017') cites that delays were also the result of Exim Bank disbursements not being realized, and several houses refusing to vacate.

title: Part I: China gives financial package including concessional loan of 2.647 billion RMB to Pakistan for GCL Karachi Nuclear Power K2/K3 project (Project ID linked to #41917 #41918)
description: On January 14, 2014 China Exim Bank agreed to a mixed credit of $6.5 billion USD to finance Pakistan's Karachi Nuclear Power Plant's K-2/K-3 projects. The inter-government framework agreement went through various stages of approval until February 18, 2014. The groundbreaking ceremony of the 2000 MW energy plants, took place in November 2013. The project is being jointly financed by China Export-Import Bank in the form of a 'mixed credit' at a ratio 81.97 [$6.5 bn] with Pakistan financing 18.03 percent (the Pakistani government will have to mark up against this loan at a rate of 3.20 %). The terms of the financial package are as follows:(i) Government concessional loan of RMB 2.647bn (with interest @ 1pc per annum)[approved FEb 18, 2014]; (ii) preferential buyer credit of $4.001bn (with interest @ 2pc per annum); and (iii) buyer credit of $2.250bn (with interest @ 6pc per annum) China developed the ACP-1000 reactor, which cost about $5 billion each to build, bringing the total cost of the project up to US$10 billion.The construction is being managed by China National Nuclear Corporation, using Hualon One technology (the CNNC's third-generation nuclear reactor design). STAFF_NOTE: NOV 19 2018 South and Central Asia Scrape According to the Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book in the fiscal year of 2015/16, the project is listed as a Preferential Buyer's Credit Loan at the amount of USD3,618.15 million.

title: PowerChina constructs Sirajganj 3x225MW Combined Cycle Power Plant in Bangladesh with China EXIM Financing
description: The Sirajganj 220MW Combined Cycle Power Plant is a major project under the Belt and Road Initiative. Its successful implementation will help alleviate Bangladesh's power shortages, improve its self-development capacity, export Chinese technologies and standards and boost international industrial capacity cooperation. The implementing company is Northeast Power Construction (‰∏≠ÂõΩËÉΩÂª∫‰∏úÁîµ‰∏ÄÂÖ¨Âè∏, or NEPC), a subsidiary of China Power Construction Co. The project includes 3 units of electricity generators, each of 225MW capacity. The second unit of generators passed the final test in February 2018. The third unit started construction in October, 2017, and started commercial operation in February 2019. No information could be found on the first unit. The project is listed on China Exim Bank annual report for year 2015 (see attached exim source p.43); it is unclear whether or how China Exim is financially involved. It is also unclear whether NEPC is only the contractor or whether it also invested in the project.

title: Shahjalal Fertilizer Factory: Chinese Government loan (link to Project ID #38969)
description: In December 2011, the Government of China signed an agreement to provide a 1.6 billion yuan (about USD 235 million) concessional loan to Bangladesh Chemical Industries Corporation for the construction of the Shahjalal fertilizer factory in Fenchuganj, Sylhet. The loan has a 2% interest rate and is repayable in 20 years with a grace period of 5 years. Construction began in January 2012 by China National Complete Plant Import and Export Corporation Ltd and the plant was handed over on 29 February 2016, although it was planned for completion in June 2015. The factory has an annual production capacity of 580,800 MTPY. Based on a document from the Shahjalal Fertilizer Company Limited (SFCL) website, the project's debt-equity ratio is about 80:20, with the Chinese Government and China Exim Bank funding the debt portion amounting to USD 560 million. The breakdown of the debt portion is as follows: 1.60 billion RMB Yuan (about USD 235 million) from a Chinese Government concessional loan, and about USD 325 million preferential buyer's credit from Exim Bank of China. For the purpose of this project, only the 1.60 billion RMB Yuan funding from the Chinese Government is recorded. For details on the USD 325 million buyer's credit from China Exim Bank, please see the linked project ID #38969. STAFF_NOTE: In the document from the Shahjalal Fertilizer Company Limited (SFCL) website, the public assistance is listed as USD 560 million from China, or 39,860,800,000 Taka. Therefore, the exchange rate used was 1 USD = 71.18 Taka. Using this exchange rate, the funding listed from Government of Bangladesh in the document (8,883,672,000 Taka) would equal about USD 124.8 million.

title: Sinamal√© Bridge (China-Maldives Friendship Bridge from Mal√© to Hulhul√©): China Exim Bank loan (linked to #38082)
description: During high-level meetings in Beijing in December 2014 Maldives expressed interest in China's involvement in a potential 'China-Maldives Friendship Bridge,' or the 'Sinamale Bridge' and both governments agreed to sign an MOU for a pre-feasibility study. On December 29, 2015, President Abdulla Yameen of the Maldives and Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce Gao Yan inaugurated the landmark project. China Communications Construction Company Second Harbor Engineering was awarded construction of the bridge, while a RMB 455.6 million China Exim Bank loan and a USD 126 million Chinese government grant would fund it. According to the 2017 Government of Maldives Bond Prospectus, the Government of Maldives would also contribute funding for the project via an equity contribution, but the amount of equity invested by the Government is unspecified. For the purpose of this project, only the RMB 455.6 million China Exim Bank loan is recorded. For details on the USD 126 million Chinese government grant, please see linked project ID #38082. According to a document from the Maldives Ministry of Finance, the official commitment date for the China Exim Bank loan was 14 July 2016, and the transaction amount of RMB 455.6 million comes from the same Maldives Ministry of Finance 'Active Loans' document. The Bridge will stretch out to 1.39 kilometers in length and 20 meters in width. It will have 2 lanes for four-wheeled drives, 2 lanes for motorcycles, 1 lane for bicycles, and 1 lane for pedestrians. The project will connect the international airport to capital city Male, and is considered a 'major element of the Beijing-sponsored Maritime Silk Road project.' Work on the bridge's foundation was planned for March 2017, and work on the 'superstructure' of the bridge would begin on 23 April 2017. In August 2018, the construction of the bridge finished and it opened. The Maldives Government Budget in Statistics documents list planned disbursements of grant and loan funds from China for this project after 2018, so the funds may be used for bridge maintenance and operation. Male-Hulhule friendship bridge maintenance and operation would commence in 2018 according to the Maldives Government Budget in Statistics Financial Year 2018 document. Disbursements (in MVR) from China Exim Bank per year for this project, according to the Maldives Government Budget in Statistics Financial Year 2018: -2016: 262,449,478 MVR [Actual] -2017: 261,058,800 [Revised] -2018: 127,932,480 [Approved] -2019: 159,915,600 [Estimate] -2020: 245,203,920 [Estimate]

title: Sinamal√© Bridge (China-Maldives Friendship Bridge from Mal√© to Hulhul√©): Chinese Government grant (linked to #38037)
description: The Bridge will stretch out to 1.39 kilometers in length and 20 meters in width. It will have 2 lanes for four-wheeled drives, 2 lanes for motorcycles, 1 lane for bicycles, and 1 lane for pedestrians. The project will connect the international airport to capital city Male, and is considered a 'major element of the Beijing-sponsored Maritime Silk Road project.' Work on the bridge's foundation was planned for March 2017, and work on the 'superstructure' of the bridge would begin on 23 April 2017. In August 2018, the construction of the bridge finished and it opened. The Maldives Government Budget in Statistics documents list planned disbursements of grant and loan funds from China for this project after 2018, so the funds may be used for bridge maintenance and operation. Male-Hulhule friendship bridge maintenance and operation would commence in 2018 according to the Maldives Government Budget in Statistics Financial Year 2018 document. In July 2015, the Chinese government pledged to provide $126 million USD as free grant aid to finance the construction of a $210 million USD bridge between Male and the airport island Hulhule. The project bidding opened in November 2017, and the China Communications Construction Company Second Harbor Engineering was ultimately awarded construction of the bridge, while a RMB 455.6 million China Exim Bank loan and a USD 126 million Chinese government grant would fund it. According to the 2017 Government of Maldives Bond Prospectus, the Government of Maldives would also contribute funding for the project via an equity contribution, but the amount of equity invested by the Government is unspecified. For the purpose of this project, only the USD 126 million Chinese government grant is recorded. For details on the RMB 455.6 million China Exim Bank loan, please see linked project ID #38037. Grant disbursements (in MVR) from the Chinese Government per year for this project, according to the Maldives Government Budget in Statistics Financial Year 2017: -2016: 82,497,000 MVR [Actual] -2017: 164,994,000 MVR [Estimate] -2018: 194,292,000 MVR [Estimate] -2019: 242,094,000 MVR [Estimate] STAFF_NOTE: There is no information on the Chinese Government grant in the 'Project Grant Disbursements 2016-2020' section of the Maldives Government Budget in Statistics Financial Year 2018, although on p. 25 of the document under the subtitle 'Grants' it is specified that there were expected grant disbursements in 2018 for the China-Maldives Friendship Bridge project.

title: Southern Transport Development Project
description: On 17 February 2011, China Exim Bank signed a 138 million USD loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Southern Transport Development Project. The loan has an interest rate of LIBOR 06 Month for US$ + 2.40% margin and a maturity of 15 years, including a 3 year grace period (see 'Global Partnership' document from Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in February 2011 was 0.464%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.464% + 2.40%, or 2.864%. The objective of the project was to assist development of the economic activities of the Southern Province by encouraging growth in industries, tourism, fisheries & agriculture sectors. The project includes 15 km of highway section from Pinnaduwa to Kodagoda and the 15 km of highway section from Kodagoda to Godagama as well as the balance work in Galle Port Access Road. The contractor for this project was China National Technical Import & Export Corporation. According to the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources, this project was completed on 17 February 2014 (see 'Resource Mobilization'). STAFF_NOTE: In the 2017 Government of Sri Lanka Bond Prospectus this project is referred to as Southern Expressway Construction Project (Phase II).

title: Thalpitigala Reservoir Project
description: On 22 December 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a 147.9 million USD loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Thalpitigala Reservoir Project in the Badulla District of Uva Province. This loan covers 85% of the total project cost, and it has an interest rate of 2% and a maturity of 15 years, including a 6 year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2017 Annual Performance Report). The estimated total cost of the project is 174 million USD, and the remaining 15% of funding (26.1 million USD) not covered by the China Eximbank loan will be provided by the Peoples Bank, a state-owned commercial Sri Lankan bank (see 2017 Annual Performance Report). The contractor for this project is China Sinohydro Corporation Ltd. (see Sri Lanka Ministry of Irrigation and Water 'Thalpitigala Reservoir Project'). The project is targeted for completion within 5 years after the signing of the loan agreement. As of 31 March 2018, loan funds had yet to be disbursed, but the pre-feasibility study had been completed and the loan agreement had been approved (see 'Progress...as of 31 March 2018' from Ministry of Program Management). The objective of the Thalpitigala Reservoir Project is to improve the agricultural productivity in the Badulla district by providing irrigation water while enhancing provision of safe drinking water and generation of hydropower. The scope of this project includes the provision of irrigation water to new and existing lands around 1400 hectares in the area through constructing upstream of the Battmedilla anicut in the Badulla district, the provision of safe drinking water facilities to Wasanagama, Madulla, Thetilla and Beramada villages in the Kandaketiya Divisonal Secretary's Division, and the construction of a hydropower station with a capacity of 15 MW that will generate 51 GWh of hydro power annually to fed the National Grid.

title: Velana International Airport (Ibrahim Nasir International Airport) Upgrade and Expansion
description: On December 2nd of 2014, China and Maldives signed an MoU for a feasibility study for the improvement of the Velana International Airport (previously known as Ibrahim Nasir International airport) in Male, Maldives. The Chinese company Beijing Urban Construction Group was promised the contract to expand the Male airport after a $511 million deal with India‚Äôs GMR Infrastructure was cancelled by Maldives' government, and both BUCG and Sinohydro were involved in the implementation of the project. On September 16, 2014 China and Maldives signed a 'preliminary agreement' that China would participate in the construction of an additional runway and bridge leading to the airport. On December 28, 2015, the project secured a USD 373,838,500 concessionary loan from the Chinese EXIM Bank, with a 20 year maturity rate and a 5 year grace period. The interest rate is unclear. The funds were used to build a new 3,400 meters long and 65 meters wide runway, reclaim land, and develop a 45 million liter capacity fuel farm and an 80,000 ton cargo complex. The project opened in September 2018. Loan disbursements in MVR: 2015: 480,580,000 MVR [estimate] according to Budget in Statistics 2015. There is no follow-up information on 2015 disbursements in subsequent Budget in Statistics documents. 2016: 1,692,168,975 MVR [actual] according to Budget in Statistics 2018 2017: 636,040,144 MVR [actual] according to Maldives Loans - Budget 2019 2018: 1,572,164,505 MVR [revised] according to Maldives Loans - Budget 2019 2019: 978,000,000 MVR [budgeted] according to Maldives Loans - Budget 2019 A 2016 IMF report estimated total costs would be about 828 million USD. The Maldives Government also signed loan agreements with the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development for 15 million KWD (9 August 2016), with the Saudi Fund for Development for 375 million SAR (26 September 2016), with the OPEC Fund for International Development for 50 million USD (18 December 2016), and with the Abu Dhabi Fund for Arab Economic Development for 183.65 million AED (17 October 2017). STAFF_NOTE: The transaction amount of USD 373,838,500 comes from the Maldives Ministry of Finance 'Active Loans' document. The information on additional loans from other organizations also comes from the 'Active Loans' document.
