title: Waste Water Infrastructure for Greater Hambantota, Sri Lanka
description: In 2014, China Development Bank provided $75 million to finance the Waste Water Infrastructure project for Greater Hambantota in Sri Lanka. The project creates a network that will provide 9,000 sewerage connections centered around a treatment plant that will have the capacity of 12,000 cubic meters of waste per day. The entire 142km collection network will be constructed by a JV between M/S China Textile Industrial Corporation for foreign Economic and Technical corporation (lead partner), China Machinery TDI International Co.Ltd & China Mechanical Engineering and Construction corporation. According to the website of the implementing agency (China Textile), the project is in implementation.
sources: http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chtgc.com/n142/n169/c12431/content.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.ctexic.cn/tm/content_exim/index.aspx?nodeid=248&page=ContentPage&contentid=588, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: [BRI] China EXIM Bank provides USD Denominated concessional loan worth for $405.8 million to Bangladesh for Multi Lane Road Tunnel under River Karnaphuli (linked to #52873 and #38342)
description: On October 14, 2016, the Chinese EXIM Bank signed a loan agreement with Bangladesh to fund the second railway bridge across the Karnaphuli River at Kalughat point. The loan package came in the form of a 405,800,000 USD loan (project #38342) and a separate 1,791,608,000 CNY loan (project #55046). Both loans have a 20 year repayment period and a 2% interest rate. This project is a part of the Belt and Road Initiative and one of a series of loans described in umbrella project #52873. June 2014, Bangladesh and China signed a memorandum of understanding on the construction of a tunnel under the Karnaphuli River. In June 2015, the road transport and bridges ministry of Bangladesh signed a US$705 million deal with China Communication Construction Company to implement the multi-lane tunnel to be constructed beneath the Karnaphuli River in Chittagong. This bridge will be located next to the existing Kalurghat railway bridge. The project will cost around 1.07 billion USD total, with the government of Bangladesh covering the remainder of the expenses. According to news reports from the Chinese state news agency Xinhua News, the construction started formally in Dec 5, 2017 after preliminary investigations, and was still in implementation as of Feb 2019. The project duration is expected to be 5 years. STAFF_NOTE: The grace period is unknown, however, this projects repayment period and interest period match the typical EXIM concessional loan terms, making a grace period of 5 years likely. The grace period is not included to avoid overstating the volume of Chinese giving. Even with a grace period of zero years, this project would have a grant element over 25%, so it was confidently coded as ODA-like.

According to news reports from the Chinese state news agency Xinhua News, the construction started formally in Dec 5, 2017 after preliminary investigations, and was still in implementation as of Feb 2019. The project duration is expected to be 5 years. STAFF_NOTE: The grace period is unknown, however, this projects repayment period and interest period match the typical EXIM concessional loan terms, making a grace period of 5 years likely. The grace period is not included to avoid overstating the volume of Chinese giving. Even with a grace period of zero years, this project would have a grant element over 25%, so it was confidently coded as ODA-like.

title: [BRI] Chinese EXIM Bank loans 12.27 billion taka to connect 2,600 union buildings
description: In 2017, Bangladesh's Minister of Information, Communications, and Technology stated that a loan agreement will be agreed upon with the China EXIM Bank. The Minister said that the project would be implemented by 2018 with an estimated cost of Taka 1,999.49 crore (ten million), while Taka 1,227 crore will come from China as assistance. Once completed, about 100,000 rural educational institutions will be connected by fiber optic cables. The project is still ongoing as of 2019. This project is part of the initiative ‚Äòone-belt, one-road‚Äô that aims at expanding links between Asia, Africa and Europe. STAFF_NOTE: Since no loan details are known, this project is marked as vague official finance.
sources: https://www.bangladeshpost.net/fiber-optical-connectivity-to-3600-unions-police-offices/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=NNATBD0020170527ed5s00030&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://bdnews24.com/technology/2017/05/21/bangladesh-plans-to-sign-new-ict-project-with-china-soon, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: Bangladesh Ministry of Post and Telecommunication, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Bangladesh Ministry of Post and Telecommunication, Government Agency

title: [CPEC] China funds Dera Ismail Khan-Zhob Project in Pakistan
description: In 2016, the Pakistan-China Joint Cooperation Committee approved the Dera Ismail Khan-Zhob project. According to the express tribune report, the western route of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), including the Khan-Zhob project, is going to be completed by the end of 2018 along with other 11 mega projects which were initiated in 2015-16. In January 2017, Pakistan's Under Communications Division provided 120 million Pakistani rupees for the Zhob Mughal Kot road. The division also contributed 40 million Pakistani rupees for the rehabilitation of DI Khan Mughal Kot road. As of Nov 2018, CPEC website only indicates that Feasibility and PC-I have been completed and the LOI has been forwarded to Chinese side. No other progress is indicated. A second CPEC website puts the project cost at US$195 million. It also suggests that the project is an 'upgradation of D.I.Khan - Zhob Phase I.' It is unclear whether the transaction amount is provided solely by China and in what form the fund is provided. The Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for FY 2017/18 lists this project as a 'Dualization of Yarik - Mughal Kot-Zhob Section of N-50'. It includes the Zhob Bypass. Cross-checking with the CPEC website confirms they are the same project. According to the source, Pakistan received no loan assistance in FY 2016/17 for the project, and are estimating loans of 4,000 million Pakistan rupees in FY 2017/18.

title: [CPEC] China funds the Khuzdar-Basima Road in Pakistan
description: In 2016, the Pakistan-China Joint Cooperation Committee approved the Khuzdar-Basima Road project costing USD$200 million. The 110 kilometers long road project includes objectives such as the road contributing to the economic and social development of Balochistan, serving mineral rich Sandak and Rekodek areas, and linking the National Highways N-85, N-25 and Motorway M-8. However, the other two sources report the cost to be USD$80 million. It is possible that the $80m is contributed by China but this likelihood cannot be confirmed. During January 2017, it was reported that Pakistan's Under Communication Division contributed 310 million Pakistani rupee towards the 110 km section. In December 2017, the funding from China was temporarily paused. After that, no further information can be found about the relaunch of the project. CPEC website confirms the estimated cost of US$80 million. It also suggests that reports on Feasibility and PC-I have been completed and LOI forwarded to Chinese side. According to CPEC website as of Nov 2018, procedural formalities to be completed shortly. The Pakistan Ministry of Finance economic survey for 2018 reports the project is planned to be completed by 2020. A Pakistani government Finance Ministry annual project status report in May from 2017-18 does not specify the total loan commitment, but records that in May from 2017-18 China fulfilled part of the loan at the amount of 11.374 million USD, meaning the project is likely to have started or at least committed.

title: [CPEC]China provides Business Concessional Loan of US164.4 million for the Phase-II repair project of KKH Highway (Thakot-Havelian section) in Pakistan (Linked to projects #52525 and #54424)
description: On February 19, 2014, China Road and Bridge Corporation, a subsidiary of China Communications Corporation, and the Pakistan Ministry of Communications signed a memorandum of understanding on the Phase-II Reconstruction and Expansion of the Karakoram Highway (Raikot-Islamabad). After that, China Road and Bridge Company submitted the engineering feasibility study report and preliminary design of the project to the Highway Bureau. Due to the large amount of project and the high total cost of the 487-kilometer Raikot-Islamabad project, China and Pakistan have decided to divide the project into three sections. The first section is Thakot-Havelian section, the second section is the Havelian to Islamabad section, and the third section is the Thakot-Raikot section. In 2016, the Pakistan-China Joint Cooperation Committee approved the repair for the section of the Thakot-Havelian of the eastern route with length of 136 kilometers. As part of CPEC, this project being developed by the Pakistani government will be financed by concessionary loans, with composite interest rates of 1.6%. The concessional loans are subsidized by the government of China, and are to be dispersed by the Exim Bank of China and the China Development Bank. China Communication Construction Co. Ltd. is the project contractor, with the executive agency being Pakistan National Highway Authority. A Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report 2015-16 records three loans provided by China to Pakistan for this KKH project. The first part is noted as GCL (Government Concessional Loan) with an amount of CNY 1,200.00 million (equivalent to 180.64 million USD). The second part is noted as BCL with an amount of 164.40 million USD. The last part is noted as PBC with an amount of 966.19 million USD. It is unclear what the latter two labels stand for or whether they are provided by the Chinese government. The three parts add up to USD1311 million, which is fairly close to the CPEC-reported amount of USD1366 million. This project captures the BCL component; for the other two fundings, see projects #52525 and #54424. Below are other sources that corroborate the financial details above: A Pakistani government project status report in May from 2017-18 records that China has committed only CNY1.2 billion on the project, which is significantly lower than the CPEC project total amount. During January 2017, it was reported that Pakistan's Under Communication Division contributed 600 million Pakistani rupee towards the project. According to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2016-2017, the revised budget states that 20,500 million Pakistani rupees are likely to be disbursed in 2015-2016. In the Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2017-2018, the Pakistan revised budget estimate predicts China to lend 11,137.010 million Pakistani rupees, or 82.96 million USD, to the project in 2016-2017. The budget estimate for 2017-2018 estimates China to lend 20,750 million Pakistani rupees, or 154.57 million USD, in that year. The 2016 Government of Pakistan Bond Prospectus lists the project cost as 1366 million USD, equal to the CPEC listed amount. The project is expected to be completed in 2018. STAFF_NOTE: The third proposed section of the Phase-II project from Thakot to Raikot is captured under project #53713. The project is still in the process of signing the Letter of Intent, and has not been confirmed. The second proposed section from Havelian to Islamabad is captured under project #52719.

title: China EXIM Bank commits USD300M for Turkmenistan Carbamide Production Plant
description: On Aug. 24, 2006, Turkmen President Saparmurat Niyazov has permitted its State Bank for Foreign Economic Activity to conclude a $300-million USD loan deal with the Export-Import Bank of China. The loan is to be released for 20 years at a preferential rate of 3.0% annually. In the end of the talk between Turkmen President Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedov and Chinese Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, the ceremony of signing bilateral documents was held. The Agreement on providing the lax credit for construction of new facilities and reconstruction of MaryAzot Production Association (US$ 239,358,000) and the Agreement on providing lax credit for construction of glass-manufacturing plant in Turkmenistan ($ 60,642,000). This is the first foreign long-term loan that Turkmenistan received in recent years. MaryAzot Production Association is a carbamide plant with the capacity of 400 thousand tons in the town of Mary. The 266-million-USD reconstruction project was contracted to CITIC Group, 90% of which was funded by the preferential loan provided by Chinese government aforementioned.

title: China Export-Import Bank commits Preferential Buyer's Credit of US$1.23 billion to Pakistan for Lahore Orange Line Metro Train project (linked to project #53820 and #54420)
description: China Export-Import Bank committed a concessional loan of 165.226 billion rupees to Pakistan for the Lahore Orange Line Metro Train project. The loan has been approved, as of May 2015, according to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance. The project is to develop a city-wide train system in the eastern city of Lahore, a senior Pakistani government official announced on April 27, 2011. The governments of Pakistan and China on May 22, 2014 signed an agreement to start a metro train project in Lahore. Multiple Chinese companies will purportedly be involved with implementation. Chief Minister Punjab Shahbaz Sharif and the National Development and Reform Commission China signed the agreement from Pakistan side at a ceremony which was also witnessed by President Mamnoon Hussain and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The 15-year loan will be disbursed in the next five years, and negotiations are under way to finalize other details, Khwaja Ahmed Hassan, chairman of the Lahore Transport Company (LTC), said that the bank agreed to lend the money with a two-year grace period, and he aimed to get it at 6 percent interest. He said the project was likely to begin by the end of 2011. Lahore, the capital of Punjab province, Pakistan‚Äôs most populous and prosperous province, home to more than 5 million people. Officials expect the new transport system, the first of its kind in the country, will substantially decrease road traffic. The project was initially expected to start by the end of 2014, last for 27 months, and conclude in 2018. The financing agreement was signed between China Exim Bank and Pakistani Economic Affairs Divison on Dec 21, 2015. The Punjab government completed its impact assessment in June 2015. The Lahore Development Authority began marking sites for demolition in August 2015, including government buildings, royal tombs, mosques, schools, and residences. Protests prompted the Lahore high court to suspend work surrounding heritage sites in January 2016 while the court deliberated the issue. In August 2016, the Lahore high court ruled that the government could not evict people or harm the heritage sites. The Punjab provincial government challenged the ruling, and in April 2017, the Supreme Court reversed the decision, allowing construction to continue under 31 conditions to limit the disruption and damage of the project. According to the Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book in the fiscal year of 2015/16, the project has three components. One is a government concessional loan of CNY1,200 million, the second is a BCL of USD203.25 million, and the last one is a preferential buyer's credit of USD1235.48 million. The finalized loan terms are unclear. This project captures the Preferential buyer's credit; for the other subcomponents, see project #53820 and #54420. Below are other sources that corroborate the financial details above: A Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report from 2015-16 reports that loans for this project consist of three main parts, a PBC component of 1,235.48 million USD, a GCL component of 180.64 million USD, and a buyer's credit of USD 203.25 million offered by China to Pakistan. A Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book in the fiscal year of 2016/17 records the project with a slightly different amount. It suggests a mixed credit loan of USD USD 1626 million. This lines up well with the approximately 1.234 billion USD PBC loan. According to the report, by June 30, 2017, 672.7 million of the total amount has been disbursed. The Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book in the fiscal year of 2015/16 records the project with a mixed credit loan of USD1626 million and a fulfilled part of 327 million. According to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2017-2018, Pakistan included 34,534.200 million Pakistani rupees lended from China in FY 2016/17 and estimates 93,455.235 million Pakistani rupees lended from China in FY 2017/18. As of January 2017 the project completion status is: 9.2% of civil works on metro train project had been completed, including 74% Package-I (from Dera Gujjran to Chaburji), 44.25% Package-II (from Chaburji to Ali Town), 60.5% Package-III and 58% Package-IV. As of December 2017, the Orange Line Metro has entered its completions phase, however there still is much progress to be made since the Supreme Court delay sidetracked project construction. 30% of mechanical works by the projects crucial central station infrastructure have been completed by Chinese engineers. Contractors on the project have projected the completion date of Package-I to be at the end of March 2018. The projects Package-2 was been completed February 2017 and handed over to Chinese engineers to install rails and other equipment. In order to meet the projects established timeframe contractors and engineers have increased work efforts. STAFF_BOTE: Commitment year coded as the date of signing the financing agreement.

title: China loans Kyrgyzstan $389.795 million USD for construction of Datka-Kemin power transmission line and Kemin substation (Linked to Project #40431)
description: The agreement to construct a power line was agreed to sometime in 2010. On June 5, 2012, China and Kyrgyzstan signed an agreement to construct a national power transmission line from Datka to Kemin and a substation in Kemin, Kyrgyzstan. The preferential credit agreement of 389.795 million USD was ratified by the Kyrgyz law on June 19, 2012. The construction of the line and substation began in 2012 and ended in 2015, with the inauguration of the transmission line occurring on September 1, 2015. The loan was financed by the Chinese EXIM Bank, and the line and substation were constructed by the Tebian Electric Apparatus company after an agreement with the National Electric Network of Kyrgyzstan. According to the Kyrgyz Republic AMP, $344,373,400 USD (88%) of the total committed amount was disbursed as of 2015. This is probably linked to project #40431.

title: China's Exim Bank loans 63,855,200 USD to Tajikistan for construction of Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line
description: In April 2006, China's Exim Bank provided a 63,855,200 USD preferential loan to Tajikistan for the construction of the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line in Khatlon province. The loan has a 2 percent interest rate, 5 year grace period, and 20 year maturity. The total cost of the project is 66.7 million USD, with Tajikistan paying for the remainder. China's Tebian Electric Apparatus will construct the 93 km Lolazor-Khatlon line for Tajikistan's Barqi Tojik (Tajik electric systems). Construction began in 2006 and was completed in June 2008. The Lolazor-Khatlon line has a capacity of approximately 4 billion kWh of electricity a year and it will also allow for the exporting of electrical power to Afghanistan. China Eximbank also provided loans to Tajikistan for the North-South power transmission line (see Project ID #39644) and the Khujand-Ayni transmission line (see project ID #40051). STAFF_NOTE: Several sources refer to the preferential loan facility as 55.2 million USD and the total cost of the project as 58 million USD. The Tajikistan AIMS indicates that the commitment from China Eximbank was 63,855,200 USD for this project, and a case study from the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific indicates that the total cost of the project was 66.7 million USD.

title: China Exim Bank loans 35,055,000 USD for Khujand-Ayni power transmission line
description: On June 18, 2010, an agreement between Barqi Tojik, Tajikistan and China‚Äôs TBEA on construction of the Khujand-Ayni electricity transmission line was signed during President Rahmon‚Äôs visit to China. China's Exim Bank will loan Tajikistan 35,055,000 USD for the construction of the transmission line. The loan has an interest rate of 2%, grace period of five years, and repayment period of 20 years. The Khujand-Ayni power transmission line is 118 kilometers in length and has a total project cost of 36.9 million USD. The project was implemented by China‚Äôs TBEA. The project includes construction of the Ayni and Shakhristan substations and transmission lines.The Khujand-Ayni power transmission line will connect the Zarafshon Valley to the unified power system through the 500kV South-North power grid. The project began on July 9, 2010 and was inaugurated on September 26, 2011.

title: China grants Tajikistan 41,664,633 USD for construction of Shar Shar (Liberty) Tunnel (linked to #53615)
description: On August 30, 2009, Tajikistan opened the Liberty Tunnel on the Dushanbe-Kulab road. The tunnel project was partly financed by a 41,664,633 USD grant from China. The Liberty Tunnel is part of the major overhaul of Dushanbe roads financed by the Chinese government and Chinese banks. Construction of the project started in October, 2006. The tunnel was originally named Shar-Shar (alternatively: Sharshar) Tunnel, then renamed Ozodi (freedom, liberty) Tunnel in 2014. The construction was carried out by the Chinese Railway Company and was completed in 2009. The project is part of the Dushanbe road construction and rehabilitation megaproject. STAFF_NOTE: A document from the Asian Development Bank reports the Chinese grant amount as 32.9 million USD, while media sources report the amount as $36 million, $38 million or $40 million. The transaction amount of 41,664,633 USD from the Tajikistan AIMS has been used, since it is the only official source that provides a figure. This project has ID TJK/102014 in the Tajikistan AIMS, and its title is 'Project 'Construction of auto-tunnel Shar-shar''.

title: China EXIM Bank loans Tajikistan 26.5 million USD for construction of unified power system
description: In 2011 Tajikistan‚Äôs lower chamber (Majlisi Namoyandagon) of parliament signed an agreement between the Government of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China (China Exim Bank) on providing a US$26,463,790 million preferential loan to Tajikistan. The loan would go to financing a unified power system/single power grid through the construction of a new substation, Sughd-500, in the north of Tajikistan. The government‚Äôs share in the project is 1.4 million U.S. dollars and China allocates the preferential loan with an annual interest rate of 2.0 percent for 33 years with a seven-year grace period. Construction of the Sughd-500 substation will also promote implementation of the Central Asia South Asia Electricity Trade and Transmission Project (CASA 1000), which aims to establish the necessary transmission and trading infrastructure and systems to enable a trade of surplus electricity from Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan to Afghanistan and Pakistan. According to the 2011 Foreign Aid Report by the State Committee on Investments and State Property Management of Tajikistan, the project had a total cost of US$27,857,000. The project is completed.

title: China Eximbank loans 331,058,220 USD to Tajikistan for Dushanbe CHP-2 (Phase II) (linked to #54106)
description: In 2014, China ExIm Bank provided a 331,058,220 USD loan to Tajikistan for the second phase of construction of Dushanbe CHP-2, a thermal power plant. This project will add an additional capacity of 300MW to the plant. The total cost of the project is reportedly 349 million USD and it is being implemented due to the loan provided by the Export-Import Bank of China and 17.4 million USD provided by the Tajik government. This coal-powered plant was built by the Chinese company TBEA between 2014 and 2016 in the Luchob area of the Tajik capital. Construction of the coal-powered plant was reportedly in compliance with Tajikistan‚Äôs environmental regulations. An independent commercial agency, IJ Global, provides a different loan amount at 280 million USD, which has not been confirmed by any other official source. This project defers to the first amount. Unlike Phase One (see project ID #54106), EXIM Bank loaned directly to the Tajik government instead of an implementing Chinese company. There is some speculation that there was political pressure before Xi Jinping's visit to Tajikistan for the SCO Leader's summit in September 2014. The contract for Phase 2 was signed at that summit. As agreed between Tajikistan and TBEA, the Tajik government granted licenses to explore gold deposits. The government has now also agreed to give additional licenses if the profit from the gold deposits does not cover the cost of the power plant's construction. On November 10, 2015, the Dushanbe-2 combined heat and power (CHP) plant began generating electricity and heat. 252,000 tons of coal have reportedly been delivered for the plant and it is expected to provide with heat more than 242 residential and nonresidential buildings in the city. On 8 December 2016, the construction of the power plant was reported to be finished. Yue Bin, Ambassador of Tajikistan, and Rakhmon, President of Tajikistan, attended the launching ceremony. which was built by Xinjiang TBEA Ltd. using the Chinese government's concessional loans. STAFF_NOTE: pg.32 of US ExIm source; pg. 33 of other; pg.49 of the China Exim source. This project is part of Chinese 'One belt, one road' project. In the Tajikistan AIMS and some other sources, this project is referred to as 'Project of construction of second in succession construction of 'TPS-2' in Dushanbe'.

title: China commits a buyer's credit of USD 203.25 million to Pakistan for Lahore Orange Line Metro Train project (Linked to project #37280 and #54420)
description: China Export-Import Bank committed a concessional loan of 165.226 billion rupees to Pakistan for the Lahore Orange Line Metro Train project. The loan has been approved, as of May 2015, according to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance. The project is to develop a city-wide train system in the eastern city of Lahore, a senior Pakistani government official announced on April 27, 2011. The governments of Pakistan and China on May 22, 2014 signed an agreement to start a metro train project in Lahore. Multiple Chinese companies will purportedly be involved with implementation. Chief Minister Punjab Shahbaz Sharif and the National Development and Reform Commission China signed the agreement from Pakistan side at a ceremony which was also witnessed by President Mamnoon Hussain and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The 15-year loan will be disbursed in the next five years, and negotiations are under way to finalize other details, Khwaja Ahmed Hassan, chairman of the Lahore Transport Company (LTC), said that the bank agreed to lend the money with a two-year grace period, and he aimed to get it at 6 percent interest. He said the project was likely to begin by the end of 2011. Lahore, the capital of Punjab province, Pakistan‚Äôs most populous and prosperous province, home to more than 5 million people. Officials expect the new transport system, the first of its kind in the country, will substantially decrease road traffic. The project was initially expected to start by the end of 2014, last for 27 months, and conclude in 2018. The financing agreement was signed between China Exim Bank and Pakistani Economic Affairs Divison on Dec 21, 2015. The Punjab government completed its impact assessment in June 2015. The Lahore Development Authority began marking sites for demolition in August 2015, including government buildings, royal tombs, mosques, schools, and residences. Protests prompted the Lahore high court to suspend work surrounding heritage sites in January 2016 while the court deliberated the issue. In August 2016, the Lahore high court ruled that the government could not evict people or harm the heritage sites. The Punjab provincial government challenged the ruling, and in April 2017, the Supreme Court reversed the decision, allowing construction to continue under 31 conditions to limit the disruption and damage of the project. According to the Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book in the fiscal year of 2015/16, the project has three components. One is a government concessional loan of CNY1,200 million, the second is a BCL of USD203.25 million, and the last one is a preferential buyer's credit of USD1235.48 million. The finalized loan terms are unclear. This project captures the USD 203.25; for the other subcomponents, see project #37280 and #54420. Below are other sources that corroborate the financial details above: A Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report from 2015-16 reports that loans for this project consist of three main parts, a PBC component of 1,235.48 million USD, a GCL component of 180.64 million USD, and a buyer's credit of USD 203.25 million offered by China to Pakistan. A Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book in the fiscal year of 2016/17 records the project with a slightly different amount. It suggests a mixed credit loan of USD USD 1626 million. This lines up well with the approximately 1.234 billion USD PBC loan. According to the report, by June 30, 2017, 672.7 million of the total amount has been disbursed. The Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book in the fiscal year of 2015/16 records the project with a mixed credit loan of USD1626 million and a fulfilled part of 327 million. According to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for 2017-2018, Pakistan included 34,534.200 million Pakistani rupees lended from China in FY 2016/17 and estimates 93,455.235 million Pakistani rupees lended from China in FY 2017/18. As of January 2017 the project completion status is: 9.2% of civil works on metro train project had been completed, including 74% Package-I (from Dera Gujjran to Chaburji), 44.25% Package-II (from Chaburji to Ali Town), 60.5% Package-III and 58% Package-IV. As of December 2017, the Orange Line Metro has entered its completions phase, however there still is much progress to be made since the Supreme Court delay sidetracked project construction. 30% of mechanical works by the projects crucial central station infrastructure have been completed by Chinese engineers. Contractors on the project have projected the completion date of Package-I to be at the end of March 2018. The projects Package-2 was been completed February 2017 and handed over to Chinese engineers to install rails and other equipment. In order to meet the projects established timeframe contractors and engineers have increased work efforts. STAFF_BOTE: Commitment year coded as the date of signing the financing agreement.

title: China Exim Bank RMB Denominated loan to 100 MW Crest Energy Pakistan Limited Solar Power Plant at Quaid-e Azam Solar Park (Linked to Project #50939, #53988 and #54284) (CPEC, IPP)
description: Crest Energy Pakistan Limited (CEPL) is a 100 MW Solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, District Bahawalpur in the Province of Punjab. CEPL signed Engineering, Procurement, Construction contracts with China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd. and MCC Ruba International Construction Company Pvt. Ltd. on June 27 2015 to build, own, and operate a 100 MW AC Solar powered electric generation facility in the Solar Park. The cumulative EPC contract value is 984 Million RMB. On December 21 2015 CEPL signed a Term Facility Agreement with China EXIM Bank and China Bohai Co Limited. Financial closure was reached on December 28 2015. The Commercial Operations Date for this CEPL Solar Power plant was July 31 2016. The total project cost is 149.457 USD Million, with a Debt-Equity ratio of 75:25. China EXIM Bank made 2 loans to CEPL - one denominated in RMB worth 100 Million (equivalent to 15.196 million USD) and another one denominated in USD, worth 40.810 Million USD. China Bohai Bank made 1 loan to CEPL, denominated in USD and worth 56.190 million USD. These two loans make up the 75% debt component of the overall project. The interest rate for Exim Bank's RMB denominated loan is 2.65%. The Interest rate for Exim Bank's USD denominated loan is 5.6916%, and the interest rate for China Bohai Bank's loan is 5.0958%. This projects records the RMB denominated loan from China EXIM bank. It is unclear how the equity component was financed.
sources: http://nepra.org.pk/Tariff/IPPs/002%20Solar%20IPPs/Crest%20Energy%20Pakistan%20Limited/2017/TRF-318%20CEPL%20COD%2018875-77%2016-11-2017.PDF, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.nepra.org.pk/Licences/Generation/RE-2006/Crest%20Energy%20Solar/LAG-294%20CREST%20ENERGY%20PL%20GENERATION%20LIC%2030-06-2015%209851-57.PDF , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/aboutExim/annals/2015/201807/P020180712414684910260.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
funding_agency: China Export-Import Bank, State-Owned Company

title: China Exim Bank funds Port Qasim 2x660 MW Coal-Fired Power Project [CPEC, IPP]
description: In April 2015, China's President Xi Jinping and Pakistan's Prime Minister, Mian Muhammad Nawaz Sharif witnessed the signing of an investment agreement on a coal-based power project in Port Qasim, Karachi. The Project is located in the Port Qasim Industrial Park, and consists of two modern supercritical coal-fired units, a self-dedicated coal unloading jetty and a 4 km-length channel dredged and transferred to Port Qasim Authority. The coal will be imported. This project is one of the largest Priority Implementation Projects under China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). According to a CPEC website last updated in 2017, the total investment for the project amounts to 2.085 billion USD, with a debt-equity ratio of 75:25. China Eximbank will be providing a loan of 1554.9 million USD dollar, which is the 75% debt component of the total 2.085 billion project cost. A Special Report on CPEC Projects from the Chinese embassy stated that as of October 2018, China Eximbank has disbursed 975 million USD (62.7% of total loan). Shareholders Powerchina Resources Ltd., who holds 51% shares and AMC, Qatar, who holds 49% shares, injected USD 346 million (i.e. 65.3% of total equity). The exact breakdown is unknown. For the purpose of this project, only the loan by China Eximbank is recorded. According to a February 2015 report from the National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA), the interest rate of the loan is 4.95%. For determination of the upfront tariff, the repayment period was assumed to be 10 years, and the grace period was assumed to be the same as the construction period, which is 4 years. This project has thus recorded the loan details as such. On November 29th, 2017, Yao Jing, the Chinese ambassador to Pakistan, accompanied the Prime Minister of Pakistan at the power generation ceremony of the first unit of the coal power plant at Port Qasim.

title: China Exim Bank loans 147.9M USD for Talpitigala Reservoir project in Sri Lanka
description: As of December 30th, 2016, Sri Lanka had completed a feasibility study for the Talpitigala Reservoir Project, and an EPC contract agreement was signed with Sinohydro Corporation Ltd of China to commence work on the project. According to Sri Lanka's Department of External Resources, the EXIM Bank of China will provide a loan of USD 147,900,000 under a Preferential Buyer Credit (PBC) facility. The project is expected to be completed in 2018. According to the Ministry of Irrigation and Water Resources Management, the budget per year for this project was -2012: 1.460 million Rs [actual] -2013: 387 million Rs. [estimate] -2014: 1.2 billion Rs. [estimate] The Thalpitigala Reservoir is located about 3 km upstream of the existing Bathmedilla anicut at a location near the village Hunuketiya (Dematapelessa) which will lead to enhanced regulation and management of Uma Oya basin. The project will include the construction of a 46 m high, 15.83 MCM capacity reservoir across Uma Oya at Thalpitigala, which will release 20 MCM water to Bathmedilla Scheme to improve irrigation facilities to 668 ha of paddy lands. In addition to that it is expected to generate 51.3 GWh of electrical energy. It is also proposed to provide safe drinking water facilities to Wasanagama, Madulla, Thetilla and Beramada villages in the Kandaketiya Divisional Secretary's Division.
sources: http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/Progress%20of%20the%20Projects%20Implemented%20through%20the%20Capital%20Budget%20in%20the%20year%202016_EN%20full.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=114:news&catid=29&Itemid=226&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://irrigationmin.gov.lk/thalpitigala-reservoir-project/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.treasury.gov.lk/documents/10181/39476/152.pdf/0b7cfe61-03b1-4ae7-b979-c9980b2f6ab8?version=1.0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: China Export-Import Bank, State-Owned Company
implementing_agency: SinoHydro , State-Owned Company

title: China pledges preferential buyer's credit of USD1,790.11 million to Pakistan for Karachi-Lahore highway (Sukkur-Multan Section) (linked projects #39013 and #54415)
description: The Karachi‚ÄìLahore Motorway (KLM) is a 1,694-kilometre-long (1,053 mi) under construction six-lane, high-speed, limited-access motorway that will connect Karachi and Peshawar through Islamabad, Lahore, Multan and Sukkur. It is now considered a major component of the China Pakistan Economic Corridor.The Sukkur-Multan Section is also known as the M5-Motorway, which is a part of the Karachi-Lahore Motorway. The 387km-long, six-lane Sukkur-Multan section includes construction of bridges, interchanges, nullahs, and so on. As of Jun 18, 2014, a revised feasibility study was done by a Chinese firm. The Construction began in August 2016 and is expected to end by August 2019, with the executing agency being the National Highway Authority (NHA). The Multan-Shujabad section of the highway has been inaugurated by Prime Minister on May 2018. A Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report later revised the expected closure date to 30-APR-21. Pakistani news outlet reports that M-3 section from Lahore to Abdul Hakeem was completed and delivered on March 31, 2019. STAFF_NOTE: This project also has another name: Peshawar-Karachi Motorway (Multan-Sukkur Section) Project Overall Transaction Amount: The government of China, through the China Export-Import Bank, would provide 90% of the funding, as a concessional loan, amounting to 233.4177 billion rupees. The remaining 10% of the project cost would be met through Public Sector Development Programme (PSDP) of Pakistan. A later report from the Economic and Commercial Counsellor‚Äôs Office (ECCO) of the Chinese Embassy puts the contract amount at 294.3 billion rupees (US$2.89 billion). CPEC website puts the contract amount at US#2.98 billion. During January 2017, it was reported that Pakistan's Under Communication Division contributed 650 million Pakistani rupee towards the Multan-Sukkur 387 km section. Project Financing Subcomponents: According to the Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report, the project funding consists of three parts, a GCL (assumed to be Government Concessional Loan) of CNY4,800.00 million (the USD equivalent of 722.57 million), a BCL (assumed to be Business Concessional Loan) of USD 361.22 million, and a PBC component of USD1,790.11 million. The three components add up to around USD2.87 billion, which is fairly close to the statistics provided by CPEC and the Chinese Foreign Ministry. This project captures the PBC amount. For the other two components, please see linked projects #39013 and #54415.

title: Chinese donates LKR450m for commemorative exhibition hall in Sri Lanka (linked to #33186)
description: China donated 450-million-rupee towards the building of an exhibition hall which is to be dedicated to ex-PM Sirimavo Bandaranaike, who died in 2000. On 18 May 2001, Chinese Prime Minister Zhu Rongji unveiled a plaque in Sri Lanka to inaugurate the construction of the exhibition hall. The Sirimavo Bandaranaika Memorial Exhibition & Convention centre was officially opened on May 17, 2003. This project is an expansion of, and should not be confused with the BANDARANAIKE MEMORIAL INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE HALL (BMICH), which was also a gift from China in 1970.

funding_agency: Chinese Government

title: ICBC loans $29.2 million for Kungrad Soda Ash Plant in Uzbekistan (linked to #54832)
description: In 2003 an agreement was signed in which the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China would provide 29.23 million USD of credit for the construction of the Kungrad Soda Ash Plant in Uzbekistan, in the autonomous republic of Karakalpakstan. The project was also funded by the Uzbek government. Implementing organizations included China CITIC group and the Uzbek company, Uzkimyosanoat. In line with contract, Citic Pacific Ltd. designed and constructed technical part of the plant on ‚Äúon turnkey‚Äù basis ( in which CITIC would turn over the plant after a certain number of years of its operation) with the cost of US$32.3 million. China Industrial-Commercial Bank financed technological part of the project under insurance coverage of China Export-Credit Insurance Corporation (90% of the contract) and loan of Uzpromstroytbank (10% of contract) under the guarantee of the Uzbekistan Government. Resources for the plant will be extracted from the salt deposit Barsakelmes and the lime deposit Jamansay in Karakalpakstan Construction of the plant began in 1996, and was commissioned in August 2006 by China‚Äôs Citic Pacific Ltd. and Uzkimyosanoat. Total project cost was US$100 million. The plant built for a capacity of 100,000 tons of soda ash per year. In 2012, the capacity of the plant was expanded to 200,000 tons per year, which was partially financed by a loan from China's Eximbank (see project ID #54832).

title: Matara Beliatta Section of Matara Kataragama Railway Extension: Preferential Buyer's Credit (link to project ID #33407)
description: On 19 February 2013, China's EXIM Bank signed a 200 million USD preferential buyer's credit agreement with Sri Lanka to finance the Matara- Beliatta Section of the Matara-Kataragama Railway Extension Project (phase I). The loan will be provided at an annual interest rate of 2% with a repayment period of 20 years including a seven year grace period (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2013 Annual Performance Report). The total cost of the project is 278.2 million USD; EXIM Bank is also providing a concessional loan of 508 million CNY (see project ID #33407). This project began on 19 February 2013 and was completed on 31 December 2018 (see 'Resource Mobilization' from the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). Construction was carried out by China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CNMIEC). The main goal of the project is to improve transport in the southern region. This project involves the construction of 26.75km length of single line broad gauge rail track from Matara to Beliatta; the construction of structures such as culverts, bridges, viaducts those required over the Nilwala river flood plain, level crossings, underpasses, overpasses, and tunnels; as well as the construction of four numbers railway crossing stations, 2 numbers sub stations and functional requirements of stations (see 'Resource Mobilization').

title: China Development Bank loans $4.1 billion for Galkynysh Gas Field Phase II (Linked to #40393)
description: In April 2011, China signed an additional 4.1 billion USD loan-for-gas agreement with Turkmenistan for Phase II of the development of the country's biggest gas field, Galkynysh (also known as South Yolotan‚ÄìOsman) Gas Field, which will increase the export potential of Turkmengaz. The loan will be dispensed in the course of 3 years, and in return Turkmenistan will supply natural gas to China for 10 years. The project officially started in August 2010, and was completed on September 4, 2013. In June 2009, China Development Bank agreed to provide Turkmenistan with a 3 billion USD long-term preferential loan to for Phase I of the development of the Galkynysh Gas Field (see project ID #40393). This project is part of the umbrella project captured in project #43168. This is part of the belt and road initiative.

title: Alternative North-South Road Project Section Aral-Kazarman, Preferential Buyer Credit Loan (Linked to Project ID #40491, #46350)
description: On June 15 2015, the Kyrgyz government signed an agreement with China on the allocation of a Preferential Buyers Credit loan for the Alternative North-South Road Project Section Aral-Kazarman. The Ministry of Transport and Communications of the Kyrgyz Republic and China Road and Bridge Corporation entered into a Commercial Contract on May 4 2014 for the purpose of implementing the project. The aim of this international transport corridor North-South is to provide cooperation of the North European countries and Russia with the countries of the Persian Gulf, the Indian Ocean and South-East Asia through Iran. The international transport corridor North-South, which is an alternative to the sea route through the Suez Canal, primarily deals with container cargo traffic. The loan details for this project are as follow: 20 Year Maturity, 11 Year Grace Period, 2% Interest Rate Kyrgyzstan's 'North-South' highway will have a total length of 433 km and require $850 million in capital. The project is being implemented in three parts: Phase I (2014): Alternative North-South Road Project Section Kazarman-Jalal Abad (km291-km433) and Section Balykchy-Aral (km183+500-195+486); US $399,989,041 Preferential Buyers Credits financed by the Export-Import Bank of China [Project 40491] Phase II (2015): Alternative North-South Road Project Section Aral-Kazarman (KM 195-KM 291); US $185,254,119 export buyer's credit from EXIM Bank [Project 53585] & RMB 697,562,608 concessional loan from EXIM Bank [Project 46350] Phase III (planned): 'Balekchi-Kezeldez' (0-183km) [Total: 183km] STAFF_NOTE: Since this project is an export credit and has concessional terms, it was coded as mixed intent.

title: Alternative North-South Road Project Section Kazarman-Jalal Abad and Section Balykchy-Aral (Linked to Project ID #46350, #53585)
description: In September, 2013 officials from China's Exim Bank and the Kyrgyz Republic's Ministry of Finance signed a $399,989,041 USD preferential buyer credit loan agreement to finance the construction of the Alternative North-South Road Project Section Kazarman-Jalal Abad (km291-km433) and Section Balykchy-Aral (km183+500-195+486). The Ministry of Transport and Communications of Kyrgyzstan and China Road and Bridge Corporation entered into a Commercial Contract on July 8 2013 for the purpose of implementing the project. Construction began in 2014. The aim of this international North-South transport corridor is to reduce trade costs and connect Russia, Central Asia, Iran, and India. As of 2015, phase 1 was still in implementation, and an agreement had been signed for the financing of phase 2. According to AMP report on the project last updated in 2015, the project status is still ongoing. Kyrgyzstan's 'North-South' highway will have a total length of 433 km and require $850 million in capital. The project is being implemented in three parts: Phase I (2014): Alternative North-South Road Project Section Kazarman-Jalal Abad (km291-km433) and Section Balykchy-Aral (km183+500-195+486); US $399,989,041 financed by the Export-Import Bank of China [Project 40491] Phase II (2015): Alternative North-South Road Project Section Aral-Kazarman (KM 195-KM 291); US $185,254,119 export buyer's credit from EXIM Bank [Project 53585] & US $112 million concessional loan from EXIM Bank [Project 46350] Phase III (planned): 'Balekchi-Kezeldez' (0-183km) [Total: 183km] STAFF_NOTE: Since this project is an export credit and has concessional terms, it was coded as mixed intent.

title: Bank of China refinances 2010 loan to Caspi Bitum LLP
description: In September 2010, Caspi Bitum LLP, a joint venture between KMG RM and CITIC, entered into a U.S.$232 million loan agreement with the Bank of China for the purpose of funding the proposed road bitumens production plant at the plastics plant in Aktau. On 17 June 2016, Caspi Bitum LLP entered into two additional loan agreements with the Bank of China in an aggregate principal amount of U.S.$208 million, for the purposes of refinancing the loan entered into in 2010. As of 2018, such funds have been drawn down and the 2010 loan has been fully repaid.
sources: http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: CDB Loan for Duddar Zinc-lead project
description: Description: On March 22, 2002, China Metallurgical Construction Group Corp (MCC) signed an Memorandum of Understanding with Pakistan Minerals Development Company (PMDC) on the project development. On November 3, 2003, an agreement for the development of the Duddar zinc-lead project was signed, with a total investment worth US$72.64 million. The agreement stipulated that PMDC would be responsible for the construction of external roads leading to the project site. In addition, the Pakistan government would convert the Duddar zinc-lead mine area into an export processing zone (EPZ). On March 5, 2004, PMDC transferred its stake in the contract to MCC Resources Development Limited (MRD), which is a wholly owned subsidiary of MCC, authorized to register in Pakistan by the Ministry of Commerce of PRC. In order to manage the project more efficiently, MCC entered into an agreement with several other Chinese companies. With the approval of the Ministry of Commerce of PRC, MCC Duddar Minerals Development Company Pvt. Limited (MDMD), a joint venture of the 3 companies, was registered on November 23, 2004. The consortium was composed of MCC (51%), Hunan Zhuzhou Non-ferrous Metals Smelter Co. Ltd. (34%), and Hunan Huangshaping Lead and Zinc Mine Co. (15%). On January 6, 2005, the company signed a financing agreement with China Development Bank. The consortium signed a contract to borrow US$54 million from the China Development Bank to finance the development of the Duddar lead and zinc mine in Pakistan. The loan was expected to fund 80% of the total investment of $72.6 million in the project. The offer has been made by a visiting delegation of China Development Bank, headed by its Provincial Chief, Mei Jia Xiang in a meeting with Managing Director, Pakistan Mineral Development Corporation (PMDC) Brig. Khalid Sajjad Khokhar in Islamabad. The Duddar project has a designed annual processing capacity of 660,000 tons of ores, including mining and concentration processes. Its final products will be zinc and lead concentrates. The mines have a depth limit of 900 meters underground. The project officially started construction in January 2005 and will continue operations until 2023. Multiple sources refer to the project as being completed.

title: CDB Loans $85 million for construction of a propanebutane mixing unit at the 'Mubarek Gas Processing Plant‚Äù in Uzbekistan
description: China Development Bank loaned $85 million USD for the construction of a propanebutane mixing unit at the Mubarek Gas Processing Plant. In September 2014, it was reported that China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) participated in the construction of Mubarek Natural Gas Processing Plant, a gas chemical complex created in the Kashkadarya (also spelled as Qashqadaryo) region of Uzbekistan. The project has a total cost of about $2.5 billion. The plant is expected to produce 492,000 tons of polyethylene, 66,000 tons of condensate gas and tonnes of pyrolized petroleum a year. In May 2012, Uzbekneftegaz and Indorama Group (Singapore) established a joint venture based on the Mubarek Natural Gas Processing Plant (UzIndoramaGasChemical). CNPC signed a MOU with this joint venture in September of 2013 in order to participate in the gas chemical project, but their involvement became official in 2014. It is expected that each of the three involved companies will own 33.3% of the shares, although funding may also be secured from a loan from the Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan. The project was expected to begin construction in 2015, and will last 3 years.

title: CDB loans $607 million for reconstruction and modernization of Shymkent oil refinery in Kazakhstan
description: In June 2017, the China Development Bank provided a $607 million loan to the Kazakhstan Development Bank, for Stage 2 of the reconstruction and modernization of the Shymkent Oil Refinery owned by Petro Kazakhstan Oil Products LLP. The project increased production from 5.25 million tons a year (Mt) to 6Mt and included to construction of a complex of catalytic cracking units with a capacity of 2Mt. The project is being implemented as part of State program of industrial-innovate development for 2015-2019. The China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Corporation is the main contract developer of the project. The facility matures on 25 April 2030 and bears interest at a rate of 2.7% per annum plus LIBOR. As the LIBOR rate is not specified, the 6 Month LIBOR rate of 1.432% is used. As at 30 June 2017, no amounts were outstanding under the facility. In September 2017, DBK drew down U.S.$100 million under the facility agreement. Stage 2 of the modernization of Shymkent Oil Refinery was completed in July of 2018.

title: China $200 million Loan to Pakistan for Gwadar Coastal Highway Project
description: In 2006, the China provided 200 million USD to finance the Gwadar coastal highway project. The highway connects the Gwadar port with Karachi. According to shipping industry experts, the Gwadar Port could be used as corridor for energy supply to China. As of 2014, the project is completed. The highway is also referred to as the Makran Coastal Highway. STAFF_NOTE: This highway project is not to be confused with the China ExIm Bank funding of the Gwadar-Karachi Motorway project in 2011 (#37276), or phase one of the Gwadar Port project with Chinese financing of $198 million (#35124, #38995, #38996).

title: China Development Bank finances construction of Astana Light Rail
description: On May 7 2015, China Railway Group Limited signed a EPC agreement with Astana LRT to construct the Astana Light Metro. Later in August 2015, the China Development Bank Chairman Hu Huaibang signed a financing agreement for not more than 1.6 billion USD loan to the transportation project. The funds borrowed were taken for 20 years at 2.5 % per anum. In May 2017 MOFCOM announced that construction of the Astana Light Rail Transportation system will begin that month, and the project is estimated to cost $1.8 billion, with a final value varying on the construction process. Chinese contractors will be leading construction. The light rail system is expected to be completed within 2 years. The light rail system will have 18 stations, with a length of 22.4 km. It is unclear where the 0.2 billion increase in project cost was also covered by the CDB. STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to ID #53932

title: China Development Bank financing for construction of an oil refinery complex in Jizzakh region
description: In 2017, China Development Bank provided debt financing for the construction of an oil refinery complex in Zafarabad district, Jizzakh region, Uzbekistan, as reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan. The project is cofinanced by Gazprombank of Russia and BELVOR Holdings Ltd of Cyprus. The total cost of the project is $2.2 billion, but the amount financed by China Development Bank is unknown. Construction began in April 2017, and the dates of implementation are 2017-2020.Once completed, the refinery will produce 3.7 million tpy of motor fuel conforming to Euro 5-quality specifications, as well as 700,000 tpy of aviation fuel and 300,000 tpy of other finished products. The refinery will receive raw materials via pipeline from Russia and Kazakhstan.The contractors for the project are Enter Engineering Pte. Ltd. of Russia, Amec Foster Wheeler PLC of the UK, and Hyundai Engineering Co. Ltd. of South Korea. Once complete, the plant will be operated by the recently formed Jizzakh Petroleum JV LLC.
sources: https://invest.gov.uz/en/invest-projects-taxonomy/realizuemye-investitsionnye-proekty/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.ogj.com/articles/2017/05/uzbekistan-breaks-ground-on-new-refinery.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.ogj.com/articles/2017/09/uzbekistan-lets-contract-for-refinery-in-jizzakh-region.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency; Gazprom, Private Sector

title: China Development Bank loans $2 billion to construction of Atyrau Petrochemical Complex in Kazakhstan
description: In December 2015, China National Chemical Engineering Corporation agreed to construct an integrated gas-chemical complex in Atyrau region, Kazakhstan. On September 3 2016, China Development Bank signed a financing agreement with Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries (KPI) to provide a $2 billion loan for the construction of the complex. Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries (KPI) will operate the complex. The complex will produce 500,000 ton/year of polypropylene and is the first integrated gas-chemical complex in Kazakhstan. Loan details are not available at the moment of project creation.

title: China Development Bank loans 84.1 Million USD to Three Gorges Second Wind Farm (Linked to Project #54317, #54012, #37233) (CPEC, IPP)
description: The Karot Three Gorges Second Phase Wind Power Project (49.5MW) is located in Jhimpir, Thatta District, Sindh Province, Pakistan, which is 90 km west of Karachi city and 80 km north of the coast of Arabian Sea. Financial closure was achieved March 17 2017, and the Commercial Operation Date was June 20 2018. The project was developed on a Build-Own-Operate basis. Three Gorges Second Wind Farm Pakistan (Pvt.) Limited reported to National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA) that it entered into a financing agreement on December 28, 2016 with China Development Bank for a 84.1 Million USD loan, with a 3 Months LIBOR rate of 0.2706% + 450 bps. Grace period is assumed to be the same as construction period, which is 18 months. The repayment period is inferred from the Debt Servicing Schedule on a 2019 tariff adjustments decision document from NEPRA. Project is part of the $2 billion Karot power projects, focusing on hydro and wind power, under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor reported to be completed by 2018. The total project cost and financing breakdown is not known.

title: China Development Bank loans 84.4 Million USD to Three Gorges Third Wind Farm (Linked to Project #53675, #37233, #54012) (CPEC, IPP)
description: The Karot Three Gorges Second Phase Wind Power Project (49.5MW) is located in Jhimpir, Thatta District, Sindh Province, Pakistan. Financial closure was achieved March 17 2017, and the Commercial Operation Date was June 9 2018. The project was developed on a Build-Own-Operate basis. Three Gorges Third Wind Farm Pakistan (Pvt.) Limited reported to National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA) that it entered into a financing agreement on December 28, 2016 with China Development Bank for a 84.4 Million USD loan, with a 3 Months LIBOR rate of 0.2706% + 450 bps. Grace period is assumed to be the same as construction period, which is 18 months. The repayment period is inferred from the Debt Servicing Schedule on a 2019 tariff adjustments decision document from NEPRA. Project is part of the $2 billion Karot power projects, focusing on hydro and wind power, under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor reported to be completed by 2018. The total project cost and financing breakdown is not known.
sources: https://nepra.org.pk/Tariff/IPPs/000%20IPPs%20Wind/Three%20Gorges%20third%20wind%20farm/2019/TRF-349%20TGTWFPL%20Adjustment%20COD%2008-01-2019%20207-209.PDF, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://nepra.org.pk/Tariff/IPPs/000%20IPPs%20Wind/Three%20Gorges%20third%20wind%20farm/TRF-349%20TGTWFPL%20UPFRONT%20TARIFF%2001-04-2016%204197-99.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BUSFINC020170311ed3b000b5&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency

title: China Donates 1 Million USD to India for the Construction of Nalanda University
description: In 2010, Chinese Ambassador to India, Zhang Yan, announced that China will donate 1 million USD to Nalanda University (Nalanda Mahavihara) in Rajgir, India. Yan made the announcement after meeting Bihar Chief Minister Nitish Kumar. The donation aims to enhance cultural relations with India. In 2010, the Indian Parliament passed an act to establish the new Nalanda University in the image of the Nalanda University of ancient India. The funds will be used to build a Chinese-type library at the university. The project has been completed. It is unclear what branch of the Chinese government provided funding. The project is part of Sino-India culture communication initiative. As a part of the same cultural communication initiative, the government of India provided 4 million USD worth of technical, financial, and other support to build an Indian-style Buddhist Temple in Luoyang, Henan Province, China. The new temple sits adjacent to the 1st century White Horse Temple (Baima Si).
sources: http://ccs.ncl.edu.tw/files/current_newsletter/%E5%85%A7%E9%A0%81-4-%E7%A0%94%E7%A9%B6%E6%A9%9F%E6%A7%8B-%E5%8D%B0%E5%BA%A6%E6%96%B0%E9%82%A3%E7%88%9B%E9%99%80%E4%BD%9B%E6%95%99%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%B8%E4%BB%8B%E7%B4%B9.pdf, Academic Journal Article; http://in.china-embassy.org/chn/zygx/zywx/t779468.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://in.china-embassy.org/chn/zygx/zywx/t738015.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.oneindia.com/2011/01/21/chinaannounces-donation-for-nalandauniversity-aid0121.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/china-donates-one-million-for-nalanda-university-revival/articleshow/10742865.cms, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://proxy.wm.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&AuthType=cookie,ip,url,shib&db=a9h&AN=56583410&site=ehost-live&scope=site, Academic Journal Article
implementing_agency: Nalanda University, Academic, Training and Research
recipient_agencies: Nalanda University, Academic, Training and Research

title: China EXIM Bank $467.8 million in preferential buyer's credits funds construction of Oil Tanker Mooring Platform and 220km pipeline system (Linked to project #38349)
description: In 2017, China EXIM Bank agreed to provide preferential buyers' credit USD 467.8 million for the construction of an oil tanker mooring platform and a 200km of underwater and onshore pipeline in Chittagong, Bangladesh. The project is to build a ship-to-shore crude oil pipeline. China Petroleum Pipeline Bureau, which is a subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, will be in charge of constructing the oil tanker mooring platform as well as establishing the 146 km of pipeline under the Bay of Bengal to the coast. An additional 74km onshore pipeline will also connect to new storage tanks and Bangladesh's only oil refinery in Chittagong. The repayment terms of the preferential buyer's credit are unclear. In January 2015, CPPB, a subsidiary of the state-owned China National Petroleum Corporation, and the Energy Division under the Ministry of Power, Energy and Mineral Resources signed an agreement to build a single point mooring system (SPM) in the Bay of Bengal to carry petroleum from vessels at the outer anchorage to depots onshore. Upon completion of the project, fuel unloading time will be shortened from the original 11 days to two and a half. This project will reduce lower fuel costs and the risk of oil spills. As of March 2015, state-run Eastern Refinery Ltd (ERL) had received the technical offer from the CPPB to build the SPM. Before submitting the technical offer, a team of the CPPB visited the project location near Moheshkhali island in the Bay of Bengal and found the site suitable. The ERL, along with an international consultant, would review the 'lone' technical offer before submitting its evaluation report to the Energy and Mineral Resources Division (EMRD) under the ministry of power, energy and mineral resources (MPEMR). The Chinese firm would submit financial offer on completion of the review. The project was expected to take 36 months, but 19 months into the project (October 2018), the China Petroleum Pipeline Bureau had only completed initial surveying and some designing. This project is linked to the 82.56 million USD concessional loan from the Chinese EXIM bank in 2017 to finance this same project (project #38349). STAFF_NOTE: The loan terms are assumed to be concessional due to the fact that they are preferential buyer's credits.
sources: http://www.bu.edu/cgef/#/2017/Country/Malaysia, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://newsbase.com/topstories/cpp-wins-bangladesh-pipeline-contract, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; https://www.dropbox.com/s/lwto3uv514o4hpr/IJGlobal%20-%20Bay%20of%20Bengal%20Pipeline%20%28220KM%29%20%26%20Single%20Point%20Mooring%20%28SPM%29%20-%20Bangladesh.pdf?dl=0, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; https://www.dropbox.com/s/1qqsuu3xdaor87q/Double%20Pipeline%20Project.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://energybangla.com/550-4m-single-point-mooring-project-hits-snag/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: China Export-Import Bank, State-Owned Company
implementing_agency: China Petroleum Pipeline Bureau

title: China EXIM Bank USD loan to Best Green Energy Pakistan Limited 100 MW solar power project (Linked to Project #50939, #54285 and #54286) (CPEC, IPP)
description: Best Green Energy Pakistan Limited (BGEPL) is a 100 MW Solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, District Bahawalpur in the Province of Punjab. BGEPL later signed Engineering, Procurement, Construction contracts with China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd and with MCC Ruba International Construction Company (Pvt) Ltd to build, own and operate a 100 MW AC Solar powered electric generation facility to be located at Bahawalpur, Punjab. On December 21, 2015 the company signed a Term Facility Agreement (TFA) with the Export-Import bank of China ('EXIM bank') and Bank of Jiangsu Co Limited. The Company achieved Financial Closing on Dec 28, 2015. The Commercial Operation Date of the project was July 31, 2016. Total project cost is 150.269 USD Million, with a debt-equity ratio of 81:19, China Eximbank gave 2 loans, one denominated in RMB worth 100 Million which amounts to 15.4 million USD (2.65% interest rate), and another denominated in USD worth 49.060 million USD (5.0058% interest rate). The Bank of Jiangsu gave 1 loan, denominated in USD which amounts to 64.440 (5.0958% interest rate). This projects records the USD denominated loan from China EXIM bank. It is unclear how the equity component was financed.
sources: https://nepra.org.pk/Tariff/IPPs/002%20Solar%20IPPs/Best%20Green%20Energy%20Pakistan%20Limited/2017/TRF-317%20BGEPL%20COD%2018683-65%2016-11-2017.PDF, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: China EXIM Bank and CDB RMB denominated loan to Appolo Solar Development Pakistan Limited 100 MW solar power project (Linked to Project #50939 and #54287) (CPEC, IPP)
description: Appolo Solar Development Pakistan Limited (ASDPL) is a 100 MW Solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, District Bahawalpur in the Province of Punjab. On June 27 2015 ASDPL signed Engineering, Procurement, Construction contracts with China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd and with MCC Ruba International Construction Company (Pvt) Ltd to build, own and operate a 100 MW AC Solar powered electric generation facility to be located at Bahawalpur, Punjab. On October 16, 2015 the company signed a Term Facility Agreement (TFA) with the Export-Import bank of China ('EXIM bank') and China Development Bank. The Company achieved Financial Closing on November 6, 2015. The Commercial Operation Date of the project was May 31, 2016. Total project cost is 149.154 USD Million, with a Debt-Equity ratio 79:21. China Development Bank and the Export Import Bank of China provided 2 syndicated loans, one worth 400 Million RMB which is equivalent to 62.93 USD Million (interest rate 2.65%), and a loan denominated in USD which amounts to 62.6 USD Million (interest rate 4.96%). These loans make up the 79% debt component. This project records the RMB denominated loan. It is unclear how the equity component was financed.

title: China EXIM Bank loans $1.98 billion for Payra Coal-Fired Thermal Power Plant debt portion (linked to projects #56005 #38245 #56547 and #56357)
description: On March 27, 2016, the Chinese EXIM Bank committed to loan 1.98 billion USD to support the construction of the ‚ÄúPayra 1320 MW Thermal Power Plant Project‚Äù. On June 9, 2014, the Northwest Power Generation Company Ltd. (NWPGCL) signed a joint venture agreement with China National Machinery Import & Export Corporation (CMC) to construct the first phase of the ‚ÄúPayra 1320 MW Thermal Power Plant Project‚Äù. The two companies formed the Bangladesh-China Power Company Ltd. (BCPCL) to carry out this project. The Prime Ministers from both countries attended the June 2014 signing ceremony for the BCPCL. NWPGCL and CMC registered BCPCL on October 1, 2014. NWPGCL is a subsidiary of the Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB). BPDP and CMC are both state-owned companies. The Payra Power Plant will be constructed with 30% equity funding and 70% debt funding. Of the 30% equity, NWPGCL and CMC each will provide 50%. This project only tracks the debt funding. For the equity funding, see project #56005. An IJ Global report indicates that the Chinese EXIM Bank loaned 1.9 billion USD to Bangladesh for phase one. An April 2018 article from the Dhaka Tribune reported a quote from the BCPCL managing director valuing the Chinese EXIM Bank loans at 1.98 billion USD. Reports from Bangladeshi newspapers ‚ÄúThe Observer‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe New Nation‚Äù and from the Energy & Power Magazine state that the loan had an interest rate of 2% + LIBOR, a 4 year grace period, and a 19 year maturity. The LIBOR rate was not specified by any official sources, so this project reports a final interest rate of 3.306% at the time of commitment. The Chinese EXIM Bank committed to the loan on December 29, 2016 and 1.306% was the average 6-month LIBOR for that month. A June report on loan guarantees from the Bangladeshi Ministry of Finance states that the Bangladeshi Ministry of Finance insured the Chinese EXIM Bank funding up to 83,328,000,000 BDT on December 31, 2017. The Bangladeshi ‚ÄúStanding Committee on Non-Concessional Loans‚Äù approved this loan on September 15, 2017, at the same time they approved a 1.6 billion USD loan from the Indian Export Import Bank. Since both loans came from EXIM banks to fund power projects, and the 1.6 billion USD is close to the 1.56 billion used for the contracted consortium, some news agencies mistakenly reported this loan as 1.6 billion USD as well. The Payra Power Plant will be constructed with 30% equity funding and 70% debt funding. Of the 30% equity, NWPGCL and CMC each will provide 50%. This project only tracks the 234 million USD of funding coming from CMC. Since the total project cost is 1.56 billion USD, so the 234 million USD reflects the 15% of the funding that comes from the joint-venture equity from the CMC. The Payra power plant is located in Dhankhali, Patuakhali, Bangladesh. This places the power plant along the north side of the Payra port, which will be renovated by the China Harbour Company and the China State Construction Engineering Corporation (see project #55522). Phase one will build units one and two. Each unit will have a capacity of 660 MW, so phase one has a combined capacity of 1320 MW. Prior to this project beginning, the Government of Bangladesh had to carry out a land acquisition and preparation project. The March 1, 2014 MOU between between NWPGCL and CMC also calls for a project on ‚ÄúLand Acquisition, Land Development & Protection‚Äù for the Payra 1320 MW Power Plant project. This subproject has an estimated total cost of 7,826,300,000 BDT. The Government of Bangladesh provided 7,727,700,000 of the funding, while the NWPGCL provided the remaining 98,700,000 BDT. That project had completed 98% of physical progress and 92% of financial progress as of June 2018, and is presumed to be complete, since construction on the power plant itself has now begun. In December 2017, BPDB contracted China Energy Engineering Group Northeast No. 1 Electric Power Construction Co., Ltd. (NPEC) and China National Energy Engineering & Construction Co., Ltd. (CECC) to construct the power plants. These firms agreed to a 1.56 billion USD deal. According to a NWPGCL April 2019 update, all of unit 1 had been installed and installation of unit 2 was underway. Construction of the coal jetty, the coal unloader, and the water intake system are complete. The coal conveyer gallery and steel structure were still under construction. According to the NWPGCL 2018 annual report, unit 1 will become operational in August 2019 with unit 2 becoming operational in December 2020. A consortium led by the China Datang Overseas Electric Technology and O&M Co. Ltd. will carry out operations and maintenance of this project. 77% of the physical progress is complete. NWPGCL reported ‚ÄúFinancial Progress‚Äù at 57.48%, which possibly reflects the amount of disbursed funds, but the definition of ‚Äúfinancial progress‚Äù is unclear. Once operational, this power plant will sell energy to the BPDB at a cost of 6.56 BDT per unit of energy. NWPGCL has submitted a Coal Supply Agreement (CSA) and a Coal Transportation Agreement (CTA) to operate using imported coal. China has highlighted the fact that this is the so-called ‚Äúclean coal‚Äù, so this project is also referred to as the 'Bangladesh's first eco-friendly power plant'. Other names for this power plant include 'Payra Power Hub' and the alternative spellings of ‚ÄúPyra‚Äù and ‚ÄúPaira‚Äù. There are three different power plants being constructed in the Patuakhali region of Bangladesh. Each one of these projects is funded partially from a joint venture between Chinese and Bangladeshi state-owned enterprises and partially from Chinese EXIM Bank Funding. Two of the coal-fired plants will contain two 660MW generators, with the third project containing two phases, both of which have two 660MW generators. The joint venture partners clarified that these plants are near each other, but distinct plants within the region-wide electrification campaign. These projects include: Patuakhali 1320MW (2 x 660MW) Ultra Supercritical Coal Based Thermal Power Plant Project (phase 2) (BCPCL): Bangladesh‚Äôs Northwest Power Generation Company Ltd. and China‚Äôs China National Machinery Import & Export Corporation established the Bangladesh-China Power Company Ltd. (BCPCL) Joint Venture in October 2014. The joint venture is captured in project #56005. The Chinese EXIM Bank funding for phase one (units 1 and 2) is captured in project #52748. The Chinese EXIM Bank funding for phase two (units 3 and 4) is unspecified, with the most recent details reported in project #38245 Patuakhali 1320MW (2 x 660MW) Coal-Fired Power Plant (Ashuganj/ APSCL): Bangladesh‚Äôs Ashuganj Power Station Company Ltd. (APSCL) and China‚Äôs China Energy Engineering Corporation Ltd. (CEEC) established a joint venture in July 2017 to build a power plant in Patuakhali. The joint venture is captured in project #56547. CEEC will solicit a loan from the Chinese EXIM Bank for the debt portion of the project. The Chinese EXIM Bank funding is currently uncaptured. Patuakhali 1320MW (2 x 660MW) MW Coal Fired Thermal Power Plant (RPCL): Bangladesh‚Äôs Rural Power Company Ltd. (RPCL) and China‚Äôs NORINCO established a joint venture in November 2017. The joint venture is captured in project #56357. The Chinese EXIM Bank funding is currently uncaptured. This project should not be confused with any of the joint-development agreements for the Payra 3600 MW LNG-to-Power Project signed between NWPGCL and Siemens (Germany). STAFF_NOTE: Despite the news articles which reported the loan terms and the Bangladeshi Government refer to this loan as non-concessional, the grant element is 43.52%, so this project codes it as concessional. This project is coded as mixed intent, because the power plant also has equity financing (described in project #56005).

title: China Exim Bank Provides $10 million loan for Andijan Hydropower Plant in Uzbekistan (linked to #53684)
description: In 2007, the Export-Import Bank of China provided a $10 million loan to the government of Uzbekistan for the construction and equipping of the Andijan Hydropower Plant in Andijan. The loan had a government guarantee. The hydropower plant has a capacity of 50MW and was opened in 2010 (the designed capacity is 171.1 million kilowatts-hours of electricity). The total cost of the project was $28.5 million USD; it is unclear where the remaining funding was sourced from. The plant was a joint venture between the Uzbek Agriculture and Water Management Ministry and the China National Electric Equipment Corp (CNEEC), which signed an agreement in 2007 to build one hydropower station each in Andijan and Akhangaran (project ID #53684). Based on the agreement, the Chinese company would provide equipment and execute the assembly of the plants. STAFF_NOTE: Commitment year unclear. Conflicting sources regarding the wattage of the station (original source stated 17MW), defaulted to most frequently listed wattage.
