title: China Exim Bank USD Denominated loan to 100 MW Crest Energy Pakistan Limited Solar Power Plant at Quaid-e Azam Solar Park (Linked to Project #50939, #54283 and #54282) (CPEC, IPP)
description: Crest Energy Pakistan Limited (CEPL) is a 100 MW Solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, District Bahawalpur in the Province of Punjab. CEPL signed Engineering, Procurement, Construction contracts with China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd. and MCC Ruba International Construction Company Pvt. Ltd. on June 27 2015 to build, own, and operate a 100 MW AC Solar powered electric generation facility in the Solar Park. The cumulative EPC contract value is 984 Million RMB. On December 21 2015 CEPL signed a Term Facility Agreement with China EXIM Bank and China Bohai Co Limited. Financial closure was reached on December 28 2015. The Commercial Operations Date for this CEPL Solar Power plant was July 31 2016. The total project cost is 149.457 USD Million, with a Debt-Equity ratio of 75:25. China EXIM Bank made 2 loans to CEPL - one denominated in RMB worth 100 Million (equivalent to 15.196 million USD) and another one denominated in USD, worth 40.810 Million USD. China Bohai Bank made 1 loan to CEPL, denominated in USD and worth 56.190 million USD. These two loans make up the 75% debt component of the overall project. The interest rate for Exim Bank's RMB denominated loan is 2.65%. The Interest rate for Exim Bank's USD denominated loan is 5.6916%, and the interest rate for China Bohai Bank's loan is 5.0958%. This projects records the USD denominated loan from China EXIM bank. It is unclear how the equity component was financed.

title: China Exim Bank agrees to finance Masalsky Mining and Processing Plant construction project
description: In May 2017, during Nazarbayev's visit to China, Massalsky Mining and Processing Plant LLP and China National Technical Import and Export Corporation ('CNTIC') signed two agreements for the construction of a mining and metallurgical complex at the Massalskoe titanium magnetite deposit in the Akmola region. It is planned that the complex will cover the entire value chain, from ore extraction to the production of high-quality steel grades. C1 and C2 reserves at the Massalskoe deposit amount to 729 million tonnes. In addition, Massalsky Mining and Processing Plant LLP and Exim Bank of China signed a framework agreement to finance the project, which cost 1.3 billion USD. In 2017, a feasibility study was performed on the construction site and was approved by Tau-Ken Samruk analysts. As of 2018, the funds from the Chinese EXIM bank are yet to be sent, and Tau-Ken Samruk describes the site as under design development, with an estimated completion year of 2025. Mazhit Turmagambetov, CEO of Tau-Ken Samruk JSC, commented during the signing ceremony: 'We want to produce our own high-quality steel, as currently Kazakhstan only imports the metal, bringing in around 1.5 million tonnes of steel annually. Our plant is not large by international standards, with an annual capacity of 940,000 tonnes. This is a new industry trend, because enterprises increasingly need to be flexible. They have to be ready to adapt at any moment and produce what is required by industry customers at any given time.' It is unclear whether China Exim Bank will finance the entire project cost, although Germany Trade & Invest reported that Exim Bank will finance 1,190 million USD in export credit, while Tau-Ken Samruk will finance 210 million USD. No other sources were found to substantiate this. STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to ID #53932

title: China Exim Bank first loan to 969 MW Neelum-Jhelum Hydroelectric Project (Linked to project #54087) (non-CPEC, IPP)
description: The Neelum-Jhelum Hydropower Project is a 969 MW run-of-the-river project in the State of Azad Jammu and Kashmir. The Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) claims that it is the largest hydropower project undertaken by WAPDA since the completion of Mangla, Tarbela and Ghazi Barotha Hydropower Projects. The Project is designed to divert the water from river Neelum through a tunnel. The tunnel intake is at Nauseri 41 Km North East of Muzaffarabad and the underground powerhouse is being constructed at Chatter Kalas, 22 Km South of Muzaffarabad. The diverted water will produce electric power by passing through the turbines and thereafter this water will be released back into the River Jhelum, about 4 Km South of ChatterKalas.The Project will produce 5.15 Billion units of electricity annually. Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company Limited was created to design, construct, own, operate and maintain the Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Project. On 7 July 2007, the Chinese consortium CGGC-CMEC (Gezhouba Group and China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation) were awarded the contract to construct the dam and power station. The construction contract was settled at a cost of PKR 90.90 billion by the end of the year and in January 2008, the letter of commencement was issued. According to WAPDA, as of March 2018, 90%of the construction works have already been completed. According to a March 2018 Tariff Petition document issued by Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company Limited to Pakistan National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA), the total project cost of PKR 506,579 million is estimated to be funded based on a debt-equity-grant ratio of 79:9:11. The total debt component amounts to PKR 401,416 million, which is around 3823 USD million. According to the document, the debt portion consists of Foreign Relent Loans from GoP, cash development loans and local commercial financing. Foreign Relent Loans are raised by the Government of Pakistan and relent to NJHPC at a fixed rate set by Economic Affairs Division of Pakistan. Foreign Relent Loans received by NJHPC consist of Islamic Development Bank Loans IDB Istisna I &II of US$ 358 Million, China Exim Bank Loan I and II of US$ 1024 Million, Kuwait Fund for Arabic Economic Development KFD loan I and II of US$ 74 Million, Saudi Fund for Development SFD Loan I and II of US$ 181 Million and OPEC Fund for International Development OFID Loan I and II of US$ 81 Million. The China Eximbank Loans are broken up into China Eximbank Loan 1 of 448 USD million and China Eximbank Loan 2 of 576 USD million. Both have a repayment period of 20 years and a grace period of 8 years, with an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + 280 bps. As the relevant LIBOR interest rate was not explicitly identified in the document, the LIBOR rate at the time the project agreement was finalized or published would be used. As such, the 6 month LIBOR rate in March 2018 (2.32%) was used for the purpose of this project record. A interest rate of 5.12% is thus recorded. According to the Economic Affairs Division, as of 30th June 2017, the 448 USD million loan has been fully disbursed in the form of Preferential Buyer Credit, and 191.067 million USD of the 576 million USD loan has also been disbursed in the form of Preferential Buyer Credit. The same division also states that the 448 million USD loan was signed on 22 May 2013, and the 576 million USD loan was signed on 29 September 2016.

title: China Exim Bank funds 1,791,608,000 CNY for Dasher Kandi Sewage Treatment Plant in Bangladesh (linked to #52873)
description: On October 14, 2016 the Chinese EXIM Bank loaned 1,791,608,000 CNY to the Dhaka Water and Sanitation Authority to construct the Dasher Kandi Sewage Treatment Plant. The loan has a 2% interest rate, 5 year grace period, and 20 year maturity. According to the 2016 ODA Report from the Economic Relations Division of the Bangladeshi Government, none of the pledged funds have been dispersed as of 2017. On August 19, 2018, Chinese Ambassador Zhang Zuo visited the project site for the stone laying ceremony, implying the project is now under construction. In November 2014, China Electric Power Construction Group and Bangladesh Dhaka Water Supply and Drainage Board signed a sewage treatment project agreement named the Dasher Kandi Sewage Treatment Plant Project [ËææËàçÂ∞îÁîòÂú∞Ê±°Ê∞¥Â§ÑÁêÜÈ°πÁõÆ]. The project is located on 60 acres of land in Dhaka, Bangladesh, and construction includes sewage treatment plants, pumping stations and a sewage pipe network with a sewage treatment capacity of 500,000m3/day. After the project is completed, CEPCC will be responsible for operation and maintenance for one year. The project was previously scheduled to begin in January 2011 and end in December 2013, but the project could not launch due to insufficient funding. Bangladesh's Economic Relations Division's 2016-2017 Annual Report Indicates that the Chinese EXIM Loan agreement was signed on October 14, 2016. Since this project tracks the funding from the Chinese EXIM Bank, the commitment year corresponds with the October 2016 signing. For the umbrella project of Chinese loans to Bangladesh on November 14, 2016, see project #52873. The other two sub-projects are #34433 and #38342. This project is not to be confused with project #34019, which is earlier than and has different financial information from the project captured here. STAFF_NOTE: The sources from China typically spell this project as 'Dasher Kandhi' or 'Dasher Gandhi', while most of the sources from Bangladesh spell the project as 'Dasherkanhi'. It is possible that this project is an Export Credit deal instead of a loan, since some of the funding immediately went back to a Chinese contractor. However, it is unclear if all the funding went back to the CEPCC or if only a portion did. Consequentially, this project was coded as a loan.

title: China Exim Bank loans 199.5 Million USD to Development Bank of Kazakhstan for deeper oil refining complex
description: On 15 October 2012, DBK entered into a U.S.$199.5 million preferential buyer credit loan agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China to finance the construction of a deep oil refining complex in Atyrau, which was amended on 30 October 2014. This loan matures on 15 October 2025 and bears interest at a rate of 3% per annum. As at 30 June 2017, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under this preferential buyer credit loan agreement was U.S.$179.5 million.
sources: https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0289Y_-2017-11-30.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Exim Bank provides USD 98 million state credit for Gwadar Port Project, Pakistan (Linked to #38995 and #35124)
description: During the visit of Chinese Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to Pakistan in May 2001, the Gwadar port was a key item of discussion. Pakistani Finance Minister Shaukat Aziz said China has agreed to help fund the construction of phase one of the $250 million Gwadar Port project. China provided $198 million for the project in various forms of funding. $50 million would be an outright grant (#35124), $50 million a commercial credit (#38995), and $98 million a state credit (#38996), repayable at generous terms over 15 years. The loan is guaranteed by the Export-Import Bank. The remaining $50 million in funds, is to be arranged by the government of Pakistan. Gwadar, located about 350 kilometers west of Karachi on the Arabian Sea coast, is considered the nearest warm water port for the Central Asian states for their trade with Europe, East Asia, and the Americas. Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz inaugurated the deep-sea port on March 20, 2007.

title: China Eximbank loan for Kalbatau-Maykapshagai (415 km) road (BRI)
description: On May 15 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol and China Exim Bank signed a loan agreement for the reconstruction of the 415 km Kalbatau-Maykapshagai road. An agreement was also signed for the reconstruction of the 262 km Merke-Burylbaytal road, and the costs of both projects amount to 808 Million USD. The agreement was signed under the framework of the Belt and Road Initiative, and signed during the BRI forum in Beijing. This road reconstruction project is also part of Kazakhstan's State Program of Infrastructure Development ‚ÄúNurly Zhol‚Äù for 2015-2019, through which the Ministry for Investments and Development of Kazakhstan implements projects on the development of roads, transport, civil aviation and modernization of heat, water and sanitation networks. The Chinese contractor for this project is China Xinxing Construction Group. According to KazAvtoZhol, a 37Km section of the 415 km Kalbatau-Maykapshagai road is scheduled to be operational in 2019. According to Xinxing Construction group, construction for the project started in April 2019. No information can be found on the loan amount and loan details. title: China Eximbank loan for southwest bypass road of Astana (33 km) (BRI)
description: The southwest bypass road of Astana is part of Kazakhstan's State Program of Infrastructure Development ‚ÄúNurly Zhol‚Äù for 2015-2019, through which the Ministry for Investments and Development of Kazakhstan implements projects on the development of roads, transport, civil aviation and modernization of heat, water and sanitation networks. The project is being constructed to close the outer bypass roads of Astana. The official website of the Prime Minister of Kazakhstan listed this project as one that is funded by a loan from the Chinese Eximbank, though the amount is unknown. The Chinese contractor for this project is China Xinxing corporation. The project is also known as XH33. According to Xinxing, the financing agreement for this project was supposed to be signed in June 2017. The expected start date is 2017, and the expected end date is 2019.
sources: https://primeminister.kz/en/news/all/gosprogramma-nurli-zhol-avtomobilnie-dorogi-logistika-zhkh-16616, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.genertec.com.cn/s/8293-22545-102110.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://kz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/t/201807/20180702767861.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.sasac.gov.cn/n2588025/n2641611/n4518442/c11103815/content.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.government.kz/en/novosti/1015138-development-of-the-astana-agglomeration-discussed-in-the-government-of-the-republic-of-kazakhstan.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Eximbank loan for the construction of the 266 km Merke-Burylbaytal road (BRI)
description: On May 15 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol and China Exim Bank signed a loan agreement for the reconstruction of the 262 km Merke-Burylbaytal road. An agreement was also signed for the reconstruction of the Kalbatau-Maykapshagai (415 km) road, and the costs of both projects amount to 808 Million USD. The agreement was signed under the framework of the Belt and Road Initiative, and signed during the BRI forum in Beijing. This road reconstruction project is also part of Kazakhstan's State Program of Infrastructure Development ‚ÄúNurly Zhol‚Äù for 2015-2019, through which the Ministry for Investments and Development of Kazakhstan implements projects on the development of roads, transport, civil aviation and modernization of heat, water and sanitation networks. The Chinese contractor for this project is China Xinxing Construction Group. According to Germany Trade & Invest, China Eximbank loaned 253.2 million USD to the project. No other information can be found on the project. Reconstruction of the road started May 16 2019, according to an announcement from KazAvtoZhol. The reconstruction of the Merke-Burylbaytal road, 262 km long, is divided into 4 sections, of which the road section from Merke to Shu, 86 km long, will be listed under the first technical category with 4-lane traffic. The remaining 3 sections from the town of Shu to the village of Burybaytal with a length of 176 km will be listed under the technical category II with 2 lanes. The road will pass through the settlements of Tatti, Shu, Birlik. The reconstruction project involves the construction of 6 bridges, 3 overpasses over the railroad, 11 illuminated traffic intersections, 276 culverts, recreation areas, and auto pavilions. The project is expected to be completed in June 2022. STAFF_NOTE: The official Chinese project name for the road is Ê¢ÖÂ∞îÂÖã-Â∏ÉÈ≤ÅÊãúÂ°îÂ∞îÂÖ¨Ë∑ØÊîπÈÄ†.

title: China Eximbank loans 558.73 Million USD to 1223 MW Balloki RLNG Project [non-CPEC; IPP]
description: National Power Parks Management Company Limited and Harbin Electric International Company Limited completed the construction of a Regasified Liquefied Natural Gas Power Project (RLNG) on July 30, 2018. The project is located in Balloki, District Kasur in the Province of Punjab, Pakistan, with an installed capacity of 1223.106MW. National Power Parks Management Company (Private) Limited is a private limited company, wholly owned by Government of Pakistan and incorporated under the Companies Ordinance 1984 on 2nd March 2015 with an objective to set up two RLNG based power projects on fast track basis at Balloki, Kasur and at Haveli Bahadur Shah, Jhang in the Province of Punjab. Harbin Electric International Company Limited is the Engineering, Procurement and Construction (EPC) contractor for the project. According to a Generation Tariff Determination document issued by Pakistan's National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA) on August 9 2016, the total project cost is 798.183 million USD. The same document reported that funds have been provided under Cash Development Loan (CDL) In accordance with the approvals of Cabinet Committee on Energy (CCoE) and Executive Committee of National Economic Council (ECNEC), but a decision has been taken to finance the cost of the Project on a debt to equity ratio of 70:30 with loan provided at 3-month KIBOR plus 3% floating mark-up rate. The financing arrangement is reportedly in line with the government's objective to sell down the project to the private sector, which requires the Project to be commercially attractive and financially viable. There is a minimum equity requirement of 20%. According to NEPRA, the EPC contractor of this project is a Joint Venture of Harbin Electric International and Habib Rafiq (Pvt.) Ltd, selected after an International Competitive Bidding process. It also indicates that Sinosure provides insurance for the project. The 70% debt component amounts to 558.73 million USD. According to the IMF, this will be funded by China EximBank, with a loan of interest rate 9.35%, repayment period of 10 years and grace period of 30 months. The 30% equity component will be provided for by the Federal Government. For the purpose of this project record, only the 70% debt component value has been recorded.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/bd1mi9adzm3o4e3/Pakistan_IMF_Project_List_December_2017.xlsx?dl=0, Academic Journal Article; http://www.nepra.org.pk/Tariff/IPPs/NPPMCL%20-%20Balloki/TRF-359%20NPPMCL%20Determination%2009-08-2016%2010954-10956.PDF, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.pips.gov.pk/sites/default/files/PIPS%20Parliamentary%20Research%20Digest%20November%202017.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.genewsroom.com/press-releases/nppmcl-hei-ge-announce-completion-balloki-power-plant-284451, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: Harbin Electric International Co., Ltd., State-Owned Company

title: China Funds Tupolong Hydropower Plant in Uzbekistan
description: The Chinese government assisted the government of Uzbekistan with the construction of the Tupolong Hydropower Plant with a capacity of 90MW (the first unit had 30MW). The total cost of the project was $115,00,000 USD, but it is unclear how much of the funds China provided. STAFF_NOTE: Had not been completed as of 2009 report, but indicated it had been started. No current status could be found
sources: https://www.carecprogram.org/uploads/Diagnostic-Study-CAREC-Energy-Strategy-Pillar1-Full-Report.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://open_jicareport.jica.go.jp/pdf/246217.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: China Grants USD 50 million for Pakistan Gwadar Port Project (Linked to #38995 and #38996)
description: During the visit of Chinese Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to Pakistan in May 2001, the Gwadar port was a key item of discussion. Pakistani Finance Minister Shaukat Aziz said China has agreed to help fund the construction of phase one of the $250 million Gwadar Port project. China provided $198 million for the project in various forms of funding. $50 million would be an outright grant (#35124), $50 million a commercial credit (#38995), and $98 million a state credit (#38996), repayable at generous terms over 15 years. The loan is guaranteed by the Export-Import Bank. The remaining $50 million in funds, is to be arranged by the government of Pakistan. Gwadar, located about 350 kilometers west of Karachi on the Arabian Sea coast, is considered the nearest warm water port for the Central Asian states for their trade with Europe, East Asia, and the Americas. Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz inaugurated the deep-sea port on March 20, 2007.

title: China agrees to first phase of upgrades for Karachi-Peshawar main railway line
description: In 2016, the Chinese government agreed to help finance the first phase of upgrades to the Karachi-Peshawar railway, otherwise known as Rail Line 1 (RL-1). Pakistan's Ministry of Railways is overseeing the construction of the project. The Chinese firm that will carry out the upgrade has yet to been named. The project has recently suffered delays and cutbacks to the overall budget as Pakistan reviews all CPEC-projects. So far the feasibility study has been completed and framework agreement signed between the two governments. The document indicates that the project will be funded by concessional loans. Continuing negotiations between the two governments will see the overall cost of project fluctuate, as well as the total amount of financing China is willing to give. However, so far the estimated cost had been adjusted from the initial 3.4 billion USD to 8.2 billion now. It is unclear which institution is funding in the project, in what form, and for how much of the total cost.

title: China commits to Pakistan nuclear plant construction assistance
description: 2013 Pakistan and China signed a construction agreement, being the two parties represented by the Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission, or PAEC, and China National Nuclear Corporation or CNNC, for the construction of a fifth 1000 MW nuclear plant (CHASNUPP-5) at Chashma, in Punjab province. The plant is currently under construction.

title: China funds 3rd and 4th nuclear plants in Chashma through mix credit loans
description: In March 2010 China and Pakistan signed a framework agreement on the financing of 'Chashma Nuclear Power Project 3' and 'Chashma Nuclear Power Project 4', each with gross capacity of 340 MW. Chashma Nuclear Power Plant 1 and 2, each with a gross capacity of 325 MW have been constructed, with the former operational since year 2000. The Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission would be the executing agency for the establishment of the two plants - which would be completed in eight years. Under the agreement, China Eximbank would provide 1578 million USD to Pakistan, which is 82 percent of the total contract. According to media reports, the financing will be in the form of a 20-year soft loan, with an eight-year grace period. Power plant number IV is being constructed as a joint venture between China National Nuclear Cooperation (CNNC) and Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission (PAEC). The Economic Affairs Division however has reported that the financing is in the form of mix credit, which implied that it may be a financial package combining export buyers' credit/export sellers' credit/concessional loan. Under the second preferential buyer credit agreement, Pakistan would get $1 billion with an annual interest rate of 2 percent, a management fee of 0.2 percent and a commitment fee of 0.2 percent The third, buyers credit, agreement would provide Pakistan $474 million with an annual interest rate of 6 percent, a management fee of 0.75 percent, a commitment fee of 0.5 percent and an insurance rate of 7 percent. According to the Economic Affairs Division's 2016-2017 Yearbook, as of 30th June 2017, 1513 Million USD have been disbursed. Chashm 4 (C-4) Nuclear Power Plant was reported completed and inaugurated September 8, 2017 connected to Pakistan's power grid. The report also indicated that the three predecessing Nuclear Power Plants in Chashm (Chasm 1,2, & 3) are operational and connected to Pakistan's national power grid. As the exact loan components are unclear, the project is coded as OOF.

title: China loan syndicate funds Phase II of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline (Additional Financing) (link to #39562)
description: The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline is a 1454 Kilometers long gas pipeline that will run through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. Construction of the pipeline was split into two stages. The first stage of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline, which comprises all sections of the Bozoi-Shymkent part, was completed in 2015, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 6 bcm per year. Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. In December 2016, a second stage of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline project, comprising a linear part of the pipeline with a total length of 311.0 km, was completed. In November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, which increased the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. ICA has announced that, by the end of 2019, it expects the construction of repair and maintenance sites, shift camps and the Beineu gas measuring station, as well as the telecommunications and the highway system will be completed. This project records additional financing from China Development Bank and Bank of China in the form of a 350 Million USD loan each. The additional financing will go to Phase II of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline. The financing represents a 700 Million USD upsizing of the existing 1.8 Billion USD loan recorded in project #39562. According to IJGlobal, the financial closure date for this additional financing was 17th September 2015, and as such the commitment year has been assumed to be 2015. Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP, a joint venture between JSC KazTransGas and China National Petroleum Corporation (each with 50% interest) was established on January 18, 2011 to construct and operate the gas pipeline. KTG is a transportation company, which owns a 100% interest in several domestic regional gas distribution companies and a 100% interest in ICA, which in turn operates the largest natural gas pipeline network in Kazakhstan. In December 2012, the joint venture entered into a $1.8 billion syndicated loan facility which was led by China Development Bank. The loan was to finance the development, construction and operation of the Bozoi-Shymkent part of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline. In February 2016, certain amendments to this facility were signed. Amounts due under this loan facility bear interest at a rate of three-month LIBOR plus 2.7% per annum for the duration of the guarantee period and, thereafter, at a rate of three-month LIBOR plus 3.2% per annum. The loan matures on 11 March 2028. The loan is secured by corporate guarantees from the Company and CNPC. As at 31 December 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.0 billion (KZT 341 billion). Construction of the Bozoi-Shymkent part started in September 2011. The construction of the Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent pipeline was first confirmed under the 'Agreement on cooperation in the construction and operation of the Kazakhstan-China gas pipeline', signed between the Governments of the Afghanistan and China on August 18, 2007. The agreement was then later amended on October 14, 2009. The Agreement on the Main Principles of Construction and Operation of the Kazakhstan-Chinese Gas Pipeline (AMP) was signed within the frame of the official visit of President Hu Jintao to Kazakhstan on June 12, 2010. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas deliveries to China pursuant to a contract concluded between KTG and PetroChina for the supply of 5 bcm of natural gas during the period from 15 October 2017 until 14 October 2018. The total estimated consideration under this agreement is U.S.$889.7 million. The price of gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement is linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. Negotiations are ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between KTG and PetroChina. BSGP and the Company expect the transportation of gas to China to increase in the coming years and, in order to facilitate such transportation, plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 (at an estimated cost of KZT 109.2 billion). See ‚ÄúManagement‚Äôs Discussion and Analysis of Results of Operations and Financial Performance‚ÄîCapital Expenditures‚Äù. In the year ended 31 December 2017, the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline transported 3.4 bcm of gas.

title: China opens Narandi China Friendship Center in Bangladesh
description: The Chinese government donated the Narandi China Friendship Center, a cultural center based in the Northern Bangladeshi village, Narandi. The center is designed to be a vocational center for children, complete with technology and reading resources. The cost of the center is unclear. The center includes a computer room, a library, an auditorium and an entertainment center. All of the 10 computers and some books at the center were also donated by China. On October 18, 2018, the site was visited by Chinese ambassador Zhang Zuo. A Xinhua report claims that the library will contain Chinese magazines and a collection of Chinese books including: Mao Zedong on Diplomacy, Islam in China, and China Sports. This center operates on 81 thousand square meters of land. Narandi village is 80 km north of Dhaka. STAFF_NOTE: This project is coded as having both representational and development intent, since the education programs also promote Chinese culture.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020070111e31200147&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://bd.chineseembassy.org/eng/xwdt/t347412.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://bd.china-embassy.org/eng/dshd/t1605430.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.amadershomoy.com/bn/2019/06/10/904241.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://archive1.ittefaq.com.bd/wholecountry/2018/10/18/175120.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China provides USD 50 million commercial credit for Pakistan Gwadar Port Project (Linked to #35124 and #38996)
description: During the visit of Chinese Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to Pakistan in May 2001, the Gwadar port was a key item of discussion. Pakistani Finance Minister Shaukat Aziz said China has agreed to help fund the construction of phase one of the $250 million Gwadar Port project. China provided $198 million for the project in various forms of funding. $50 million would be an outright grant (#35124), $50 million a commercial credit (#38995), and $98 million a state credit (#38996), repayable at generous terms over 15 years. The loan is guaranteed by the Export-Import Bank. The remaining $50 million in funds, is to be arranged by the government of Pakistan. Gwadar, located about 350 kilometers west of Karachi on the Arabian Sea coast, is considered the nearest warm water port for the Central Asian states for their trade with Europe, East Asia, and the Americas. Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz inaugurated the deep-sea port on March 20, 2007.

title: Chinese Banks loan 945 Million USD for 720 MW Karot hydropower project (Linked to project #54012, #53675, #54317) (BRI, CPEC, IPP)
description: Karot Power Company (KPCL) obtained a letter of interest early in May 2007 from the Private Power Infrastructure Board (PPIB) to develop the Karot Hydropower Project. In October 2009, the PPIB approved the Feasibility Study Report of the project and in November 2013, National Electric Power Regulatory Authority granted KPCL a generation license to develop a 720 MW hydro-based generation facility at Karot village, District Rawalpindi, in Punjab province. The project is located on Jhelum River, near Karot Bridge. It is the 4th among 5 Cascade HPPs to be developed along Jhelum River. KPCL is 93% owned by China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited, a subsidiary of China Three Gorges Corporation, and 7% owned by Pakistan's Associated Technologies. KPCL completed a EPC Tender evaluation on January 9th 2015, and awarded the EPC contract to Yangtze Three Gorges Technology & Economy Development Co., Ltd (TGDC) and China Machinery Engineering Corporation Consortium. The project will be undertaken on a build-own-operate-transfer basis. Construction began in 2015 and is expected to be completed in 2021. The project is designated a priority project under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor, and a flagship project under Belt and Road Initiative. Project is part of the $2 billion Karot power projects, focusing on hydro and wind power, under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor reported to be completed by 2018. The project will feature a single power generation complex with an installed capacity will be 720-megawatts with four units of 180-megawatts each. The power structure layout will include a roc-filled dam, spillway, powerhouse, diversion tunnels, head-race power tunnels and a tail-race tunnel end. The project itself is denominated as 80% in Punjab (powerhouse) and 20% in Azad Jammu and Kashmir (reservoirs). According to an interview with the chief accountant from China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited, the total cost of the project is 1.75 billion USD, with a debt-equity ratio of 80:20. The project achieved financial closure on February 22, 2017. According to IJGlobal, the 80% debt component was financed by loans from China Development Bank, China Exim Bank, China Silk Road Fund and International Finance Corporation (IFC), each one worth 315 Million USD, along with an additional 100 Million USD loan from IFC. This project records the loans from the Chinese banks. For the equity component, China Three Gorges Corporation invested 316.20 Million USD, while Associated technologies invested 23.90 Million USD. The IMF puts the loan interest rate at 5.11%, with a maturity period of 12 years and a grace period of 5 years. It was additionally reported that there is a 30-year concession period. On April 20 2015, China's $40 Billion Silk Road Fund signed a memorandum of understanding with China Three Gorges Corporation and the PPIB on the development of Pakistan's hydropower project, pledging to finance the project through equity investment in China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited, and participating in a loan syndicate made up of Chinese banks. As of 2017, the Silk Road Fund has disbursed 1.65 Billion USD. The Silk Road Fund also owns 15% of China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Company as of 2017. On March 14 2017, IFC announced that it will invest $100 million in the Karot Hydropower Project, and reported that it acquired a 15% stake in China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited in 2015. IFC stated that this investment is its first major collaboration with the China Export Import Bank, China Development Bank, and Silk Road Fund. The first unit is projected to begin power generation in 2020, coming online prior to its deadline. The Chinese firm in charge of the project will hand over this project to Pakistani government after the 30-year concession period has ended. STAFF_NOTES:Unsure which Chinese company is in charge of the project, article did not specify which firm will hand over the project to the Pakistani government

title: Chinese bank syndicate loans 1.5 billion for 2 x 660 MW imported coal-fired power plant at Hub, Baluchistan (Linked to project #53971) (CPEC, IPP)
description: The 2 X 660.00 MW imported coal based power project at Hub, Mouza Kund, Tehsil Gadani, District Lasbella, in the Province of Balochistan is a joint venture of the Hub Power Company Limited (reportedly the largest Independent Power Producer (IPP) in Pakistan with a combined power generation capacity of over 1600 MW) and China Power International Holding Limited-CPIHL (a wholly owned subsidiary of China's State Power Investment Corporation). Pakistan's Private Power Infrastructure Board issued a letter of intent to the Hub Power Company Limited on June 29, 2015 for setting up a the imported coal based power project. A special purpose vehicle under the name China Power Hub Generation Company (Pvt.) Limited (CPHGCPL) was created for the project. The expected Commercial Operation Date of the Generation facility is 31 August 2018. Once in operation, the project is estimated to provide 9 billion kWh electricity to the National Grid every year, that will meet the electricity needs of 4 million households in Pakistan. On January 25, 2017, the Implementation Agreement (IA) and Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) of the project were signed. On October 24, 2017, CPHGCL signed a 1.5 billion USD loan agreement with a consortium of banks led by China Development Bank. Other banks in the consortium include: The Export-Import Bank of China, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, China Construction Bank Corporation, and Bank of Communications Co. Limited. According to the World Bank, each bank loaned 300 million USD. The debt-equity ratio for this project is 75-25, and the 1.5 billion loan makes up the debt component of this project. For the purpose of this project, only the debt component has been recorded, the equity component is recorded in Project #53971. According to a February 2016 National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA) document on tariff determination, for the determination of upfront tariff, a loan tenure of 10 years plus grace period equivalent to construction period of 48 months were used. A LIBOR rate of 0.45% plus 450 basis points were also used in the document. These loan information were used for this project.

title: Chinese loan syndicate finances 1124 MW Kohala hydropower project debt component (Linked to project #54014) [CPEC]
description: The 1124 MW Kohala Hydropower Project is located in Muzafarabad District, in the State of Azad Jammu & Kashmir (AJK). The Project was initially being developed by the Pakistan Water & Power Development Authority (the ‚ÄúWAPDA‚Äù), and was offered to Chinese investors/companies during President of Pakistan‚Äôs visit to China in October 2008, and an MOU was signed between China Three Gorges Corporation (CTG) and GoP in 2008. Kohala Hydro Company Limited, an ultimate subsidiary of CTG was issued a Letter of Intent in January 2009, and was tasked to set up the project under BOOT basis. In August 2014 the Project was included in the ‚ÄúActively Promoted Project‚Äù in the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) and is the only CPEC project in AJK. The Project is being developed downstream of Chakothi-Hattian Hydropower Project and upstream of the Mahl Hydropower Project. It will consist of a Dam on River Jhelum, with twin 17.4 km long headrace tunnels which will end in the power house downstream on the River Jhelum. The curved concrete gravity dam with a crest elevation of 910 m, will have a maximum height of 69 m and a top length of 270 m. The main power station will be equipped with 4 vertical Francis turbine generator units, each with a capacity of 275 MW. An additional 24 MW will run on the ecological flow of the River downstream of the Dam. The dam site is Siran Village, and the power plant is located in Barsala in District Muzafarabad. A consortium of Yangtze Three Gorges Technology & Economy Development Co. Ltd, & China Three Gorges Project Development Co. Ltd have been selected as the EPC Contractor (the ‚ÄúEPC Contractor‚Äù), with EPC Contract value of USD 1,793 million. Due to the complexities involved, construction period will be 6.5 years as approved by Panel of Experts. The hydropower project has a total project cost of 2760.17 million USD, and will be financed with a debt-equity structure of 70:30. In 2014, the Kohala hydro power project was listed as part of the China‚ÄìPakistan Economic Corridor initiative. As of June 23, 2017, a document from NEPRA confirmed that a foreign loan syndicate led by China Development Bank will be contributing a loan amounting to $1642.30 USD million. It is not clear which other Chinese banks are involved. Equity will require a financing of 828.05 million USD, and an amount of 31.03 million USD has already been injected in KHCL by Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited (Linked to project #54014) The interest rate for the foreign loan is calculated using the 0.6% 6 Month LIBOR rate as decided by NEPRA in January 2017 + 4.60% = 5.2%. The maturity period is 18.5 years, with a 6.5 year grace period. STAFF_NOTE: The commitment year has been coded as 2017 as the involvement of CDB is confirmed in a EPC Stage Tariff Proposal submitted to NEPRA on June 23 2017.

title: Chinese loan syndicate funds Sahiwal 2x660MW Coal-Fired Power Plant project in Pakistan (Linked to Project #54134) (CPEC, IPP)
description: In March 2014, the government of Punjab, Pakistan issued invitation for bids for six 2x660MW coal-fired power development projects. By May 2014, the consortium of Huaneng Shandong Power Generation Co., Ltd., its subsidiary in Hong Kong, and Shandong Ruyi Technology Group Co., Ltd., officially obtained the right of development of Sahiwal 2x660MW coal-fired power project, located in Qadirabad, Sahiwal, Punjab. The groundbreaking ceremony was held on May 30 2014, with Nawaz Sharif, Prime Minister of Pakistan and Shahbaz Sharif, Chief Minister of Punjab Province attending the event. Coal was procured from Indonesia and South Africa for the project. The project spans 690 hectares, which was given by the Pakistani government free of charge. According to CPEC website, the project achieved Commercial Operation Date (COD) on Oct 28, 2017, and has been connected to the national grid. According to a March 2015 document from the National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA) as well as an announcement from ICBC, the total investment is estimated to be 1.808 billion USD. The project's debt-equity ratio is 80:20. The debt component is covered by a Chinese loan syndicate led by ICBC. In February 2015, ICBC had submitted a letter of interest to act as financial advisor and arranger for the borrower. On April 20, 2015, ICBC Chairman Jiang Jianqing signed power project financing agreements for four energy power projects in the presence of Chinese President Xi Jinping and Pakistani Prime Minister Sharif. The four energy power projects include Sukhi Kinari hydropower project, Dawood wind power project, Sahiwal coal-fired power plant, and Thar coal-power integrated project. Sinosure reported in 2018 that that the loan syndicate had in fact covered up to 85% of the total cost, providing 1.8 billion USD worth of export buyer credits. According to the ICBC website, ICBC alone provided 1.44 billion USD worth of export buyer credit. Other Chinese banks in the syndicate include Bank of China, China Construction Bank, Agricultural Bank of China. Huaneng Shandong Power Generation Co., Ltd and Shandong Ruyi Technology Group Co., Ltd provided the equity funding. Sinosure has earlier committed to reduce the premium rate from 9% to 7%, increasing the business insurance coverage for overseas projects from 50% to 65%. For the purpose of this project, only the funding from ICBC has been recorded. For details on the equity portion, please see the linked project #54134. According to a March 2015 NEPRA document, the interest rate of the loan is 4.95%. For determination of the upfront tariff, the repayment period was assumed to be 10 years, and the grace period was assumed to be the same as the construction period, which is 4 years. This project has thus recorded the loan details as such. Project's first 660-MW capacity plant unit was reported a success with completion in a short 22 months and inaugurated May 2017 by the Prime Minister of Pakistan and has been linked to the national grid. Project also received a No Objection Certificate (NoC) from Pakistan's Environment Protection Department. Project's second 660-MW capacity plant is projected to begin electric generation in June 2017 at the reported available rate of 8.11 rupees per unit.

title: Colombo-Katunayake Expressway
description: On 6 August 2009, China Exim Bank signed a 248.2 million USD loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway Project. The estimated total cost of the project was 350 million USD, so the Chinese financing accounts for about 70% of the total funding (see Government of Sri Lanka 2017 Bond Prospectus). The loan has an interest rate of 6.3% and a maturity of 16 years, including a 4 year grace period (see 'Global Partnership' document from Sri Lanka Department of External Resources). On 18 August 2009, the construction of the 25.8-kilometre-long Colombo - Katunayake Expressway (E03) started. In October 2013, the expressway was officially opened and ready for use. The highway links the capital Colombo with Negombo City, one of the major commercial hubs and major tourist destination in the country. The contract for the project was awarded in August 2008 to the China Metallurgical Group Corporation.

title: EXIM Bank loan for Muthurajawela Oil Tank Storage Project
description: On 17 January 2001, EXIM Bank of China and Sri Lanka signed a 'Mixed Credit Loan Agreement' under which China EXIM Bank will provide US$72 million; the loan covers the 90% of the cost of the project. The other 10% is funded by Ceylon Petroleum Corporation. The loan is used to award the US$79.52 million contract to China Huanqiu Chemical Engineering Corporation to develop the Muthurajawela Oil Tank Storage Project in Colombo,Sri Lanka. The turnkey project, which cost about US$79.528 million includes design, procurement, construction and commissioning. The project will be constructed 14 km to the north of Colombo. The offshore section of the project will have a one-point mooring system and a 5.6 km submarine oil transmission pipeline. The onshore section of the project will have 29 diesel and kerosene storage tanks and all the matching facilities. The total construction period is 36 months. The Muthurajawela oil tank storage was declared open on 27 May 2004. .

title: Eximbank export credits for construction of a 2nd nuclear plant in Chashma, Pakistan (linked to #35262)
description: In March 2003 China and Pakistan signed a memorandum of understanding for the construction of a second nuclear power plant (Chashma II) with a 300 MW capacity at Chashma, Pakistan, where a nuclear plant (Chashma I) was already installed. The two sides signed an agreement for the utilisation of 150 million dollars of the 'preferential export credit' provided by China through the EXIM Bank of China. The sum is part of an overall contribution of 350m dollars that China committed to provide for the construction of Chashma II. The construction started on April 8, 2005. Chashma II was inaugurated in May 2011.

title: Export credits for Jinnah Hydropower station, Pakistan
description: In November 2003, WAPDA (Water and Power Development Authority) signed a 128 million USD contract agreement with Dongfang Electric Corporation for the construction of Jinnah Hydropower Project of engineering, procuring and constructing basis at Wapda House. Tan Zhengmin, Manager Hydropower Division of the Chinese firm and Ghulam Abbas, General Manager (Hydro Development) of WAPDA signed the contract agreement on behalf of their organizations in the presence of Chairman Wapda, Lt Gen (r) Zulfiqar Ali Khan, according to a press release issued here. Member (Water) Muhammad Amin, Member (Power) Habibullah Khan, Member (Finance) Javed Nazim and other senior Wapda managers were also present on the occasion. Chairman Wapda, Zulfiqar Ali Khan said that Memorandum of Understanding for this project was signed two years ago during President Gen Pervez Musharraf's earlier visit to China. 85 percent of the contract price will be arranged by Dongfang Electric Corporation under export seller's credit provided by China EXIM Bank and the remaining 15 percent will be arranged by Wapda as advance payment. Construction started on 18th February 2006 under the direction of Nisar Ahmed Memon. All the 8 units started operating by Septemebr 2013.

title: Hambantota Port Development Project - Phase I (link to project ID #33409)
description: On 30 December 2007, China EXIM Bank signed a 306.7 million USD loan agreement with Sri Lanka for the Hambantota Port Development Project - Phase I (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization'). The interest rate is 6.3%, with a four-year grace period and fifteen-year maturity. Construction began on 15 January 2008, and the project was finished on October 30, 2011 (opened ceremonially early -November 2010 -to coincide with the president's birthday; phase two also began on this day). The scope of the project involved the construction of two nos of breakwaters(312m long eastern b/w and 988m long western b/w), a 17m deep harbor basin, a 210m wide entrance channel, a service berth, 100,000DWT general purpose berth, 100,000 DWT oil berth, and various roads and buildings-Admin Building, Public Service Building and Utility Buildings. The contractors for this project were China Harbor Engineering Co. and Sinohydro. The total cost of the project was about 507 million USD, so the China Eximbank loan accounted for about 60% of the total project cost (see Government of Sri Lanka 2017 Bond Prospectus). In 2013, China Exim Bank provided an additional CNY 960 million concessional loan for Hambantota Port Development Phase I for Ancillary Works and Supply of Equipment (see project ID #33409). EXIM Bank had also provided a US$65 million loan for the bunkering terminal (See Project ID#33329) and US$809.35 million for Hambantota Port Develoment Project Phase II (See Project ID#33481).

title: Hambantota Port Development Project - Phase II: 51 million USD Buyer's Credit (link to projects ID #33481, #39023 and #39024)
description: Based on Sri Lanka's Department of External Resources (ERD) 2012 Performance Report, EXIM Bank of China, on 17 September 2012, has signed an agreement to provide a total loan of $809.35 million to the government of Sri Lanka for phase II of the port construction in Hambantota (umbrella project #33481). The $809.35 million loan was provided in 3 segments, one of them is the Buyer‚Äôs Credit Loan (BCL) - US$51 million, with an interest rate of LIBOR 06 Months for US$ + 4% margin, 0.9% management fee, 0.7% commitment fee and a repayment period of 15 years including 4 years of grace period. The interest rate is coded based on the 6 Month LIBOR at time of signing of the agreement. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in September 2012 was 0.672%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.672% + 4%, or 4.672%. For the other two segments of the loan see #39023 and #39024. Based on ERD Disbursements of Foreign Funded Loan/Grant 2014, EXIM Bank had disbursed a loan amount of US$ 299,817,176.39 in the period of May to December 2014. According to the Department of External Resources (Sri Lanka) these funds have not yet been utilized (see 'Resource Mobilization'). China Communications Construction Company has been assigned as the contractor for the second phase of Hambantota port. ERD also reported that China Harbour Engineering Com. Ltd. would also be involved in the project. The project was commenced in 2012, and will include the construction of a quay wall (2140 m long) to accommodate 6 container berths, oil terminal (300 meters long), yard & roads, a flyover bridge, deepening of entrance channel (450 m wide, 840 m long, 18 meter deep), 2 feeder berths, construction of artificial island (50 Ha) & handling facilities, and excavating a new basin area. An extension has been granted to the project up through May 2018, despite the original completion date being planned for November 2015. As of December 31st, 2017, the project was at 96% physical completion. The port in Hambantota, deeper than the one at Colombo, is to be used as a refueling and docking station for the Sri Lankan Navy.

title: Hambantota Port Development Project - Phase II: 600 million USD Preferential Buyer's Credit (link to projects ID #33481, #39024 and #39025)
description: Based on Sri Lanka's Department of External Resources (ERD) 2012 Performance Report, EXIM Bank of China, on 17 September 2012, has signed an agreement to provide a total loan of $809.35 million to the government of Sri Lanka for phase II of the port construction in Hambantota. The $809.35 million loan was provided in 3 segments (umbrella project #33481); one of the segment is the Preferential Buyer‚Äôs Credit(PBC)- US$600 million, with 2% interest rate, 0.5% management fee, 0.5% commitment fee and a repayment period of 19 years including 6 years of grace period. For the other two segments of the loan see #39025 and #39024. Based on ERD Disbursements of Foreign Funded Loan/Grant 2014, EXIM Bank had disbursed a loan amount of US$ 299,817,176.39 in the period of May to December 2014. According to the Department of External Resources (Sri Lanka), the funds from this exchange have now been fully utilized (see 'Resource Mobilization'). China Communications Construction Company has been assigned as the contractor for the second phase of Hambantota port. ERD also reported that China Harbour Engineering Com. Ltd. would also be involved in the project. The project was commenced in 2012, and will include the construction of a quay wall (2140 m long) to accommodate 6 container berths, oil terminal (300 meters long), yard & roads, a flyover bridge, deepening of entrance channel (450 m wide, 840 m long, 18 meter deep), 2 feeder berths, construction of artificial island (50 Ha) & handling facilities, and excavating a new basin area. An extension has been granted to the project up through May 2018, despite the original completion date being planned for November 2015. As of December 31st, 2017, the project was at 96% physical completion.

title: ICBC finances Hydro China Dawood Power Ltd 49.5 MW Wind Farm Project in Gharo, Pakistan (CPEC, IPP)
description: The Hydro-China Dawood Wind Power Project is a 49.5 MW project located at Bhanbore, Gharo, Sind. It was put into commercial use on 5th April, 2017 and is currently operational. According to the 2016 Government of Pakistan Bond Prospectus, the project has an estimated cost of 125 million USD. The project was constructed by HydroChina International Engineering Co., Ltd, a subsidiary of the Power Construction Corporation of China. The project was also designated as a priority infrastructure project for the Belt and Road Initiative. The State-Owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council (SASAC) announced on March 11 2015 that a project loan agreement was signed, with ICBC providing a loan of 78.82 million USD. On April 20, 2015, ICBC Chairman Jiang Jianqing signed the Dawood Power Project financing agreement, which stated that ICBC will provide financing support for the design, equipment purchase and site construction. The signing was witnessed by Chinese President Xi Jinping and Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif. On January 4 2016, ICBC announced that it recently disbursed the first loan of 25 Million USD to the Dawood project. On April 20, 2018, Hong Kong Trade Development Council reported that the project was backed by a $78.8 million USD credit line from ICBC, affirming the amount announced by SASAC. The turbines used by the project were from Guangdong's China Ming Yang Wind Power Group in association with Aerodyn Energiesysteme, a German wind-power specialist. According to the IMF, the debt-equity ratio of the project is 80:20, though no up-to-date information could be found regarding the equity portion of the project. The IMF puts the interest rate of the loan at 8.4%, with a repayment period of 10 years and grace period of 1 year.

title: Line A and B of Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, Kazakhstan section (linked to #39997, #40833, #39955)
description: The Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, otherwise known as the China - Central Asia Gas Pipeline, a 1,873-km gas pipeline that connect Turkmenistan to China via Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan currently consists of 4 lines (A/B/C/D), with A,B,C parallel to each other. The pipeline starts at Gedaim on the border of Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, runs through central Uzbekistan and southern Kazakhstan, and ends at Horgos in China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region. The line A (#40833) of this pipeline became operational in 2009 while the other two lines (B (#40834) and C (#39997)) started their operation in 2010 and 2014 respectively. Line A and B will be connected to the Second West-East Gas Pipeline, while Line C will be connected to the Third West-East Gas Pipeline. Line D (#39955) runs through Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan to Wuqia County in China, where it will be connected to the Fifth West-East Gas Pipeline. Line A, B, and C are providing 55 billion cubic meters of gas to China per annum, while Line D is still under construction. There are segments of each line constructed within Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, and Kyrgyzstan. Kazakhstan-China pipeline construction started in July 9 2008. This project records the financing of the Kazakhstan segment of Lines A and B. Project 39997 records the financing of the Kazakhstan segment of Line C. Line A and B starts on right bank of the Amu Darya River, near Turkmenistan/Uzbekistan border, and passes through the central region of Uzbekistan and southern region of Kazakhstan. Line A became operational in December 2009 (with a throughput capacity of 10 bcm per year), and Line B became operational in October 2010 (with a throughput capacity of 30 bcm per year). Line A and B's capacity has since been increased to 30 billion cubic meters of gas per year. (NOTE: In the 2018 base prospectus, the operational date of Line B was reported to be December 2012). JSC KazTransGas formed a joint venture with CNPC (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) called Asia Gas Pipeline LLP (AGP) to construct and operate the Kazakhstan-China Gas Pipeline. JSC KazTransGas and CNPC each holds 50% of AGP. In October 2008, AGP entered into a U.S.$7.5 billion syndicated loan facility with China Development Bank and Bank of China for the purposes of financing the development, construction and operation of lines A and B of the 'Kazakhstan-China' pipeline (NOTE: In the 2018 base prospectus, Line A and Line B were also referred to as the 'first and second phases of the construction of the Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline'). The loan bears interest at a rate of three-month LIBOR increased by 2.15 per cent. per annum during the guarantee period and three-month LIBOR increased by 2.9 per cent. per annum thereafter. The loan must be repaid in several installments from March 2013 until October 2023. The amounts due under this loan are secured by account charges, a pledge over deposit certificate agreement, an insurance assignment and are guaranteed by CNPC. As at 30 June 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under this loan was U.S.$4.5 million. According to these information, interest rate is recorded as 3M LIBOR in October 2008 (4.059%) + 2.15%; grace period = 4.5 years; repayment period = 10.5 years, maturity period = 15 years.
sources: https://kase.kz/files/emitters/KZTG/kztgf9e1_2017.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://center.cnpc.com.cn/bk/system/2017/12/07/001671340.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency; Bank of China (BOC), State-Owned Company

title: Line C of Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, Kazakhstan section (linked to #40833, #39955, #54489)
description: The Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, otherwise known as the China - Central Asia Gas Pipeline, a 1,873-km gas pipeline that connect Turkmenistan to China via Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan currently consists of 4 lines (A/B/C/D), with A,B,C parallel to each other. The pipeline starts at Gedaim on the border of Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, runs through central Uzbekistan and southern Kazakhstan, and ends at Horgos in China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region. The line A of this pipeline became operational in 2009 while the other two lines (B (#40834) and C (#39997)) started their operation in 2010 and 2014 respectively. Line A and B will be connected to the Second West-East Gas Pipeline, while Line C will be connected to the Third West-East Gas Pipeline. Line D (#39955) runs through Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan to Wuqia County in China, where it will be connected to the Fifth West-East Gas Pipeline. Line A, B, and C are providing 55 billion cubic meters of gas to China per annum, while Line D is still under construction. There are segments of each line constructed within Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, and Kyrgyzstan. Kazakhstan-China pipeline construction started in July 9 2008. This project records the financing of the Kazakhstan segment of Line C. Construction of Line C was started in September 2012. With a designed capacity of 25 billion cubic meters per annum, Line C‚Äôs pipe diameter is 1,219mm, 152mm larger than Line A/B. The overall welding work of the pipeline was completed at the end of 2013. Upon completion of all supporting facilities of Line C by the end of 2015, the overall delivery capacity of the Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline will hit 55 billion cubic meters per annum. This equals to approximately 20% of China‚Äôs annual natural gas consumption, and would substitute 73 million tons of standard coal, cutting carbon dioxide and sulfur dioxide emissions by 78 million tons and 1.21 million tons every year, respectively. JSC KazTransGas formed a joint venture with CNPC (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) called Asia Gas Pipeline LLP (AGP) to construct and operate the Kazakhstan-China Gas Pipeline. JSC KazTransGas and CNPC both holds 50% of AGP. In December 2012, AGP entered into a U.S.$4.7 billion syndicated loan facility with China Development Bank and Bank of China for the purposes of financing the construction of line C of the 'Kazakhstan-China' pipeline. Amounts borrowed under the facility accrue interest at a rate of three-month LIBOR increased by 2.35 per cent. per annum during the guarantee period and three-month LIBOR increased by 3.45 per cent. per annum thereafter. The borrowed amounts must be repaid starting from June 2017 until 27 December 2027. The loan is secured by a 'ship or pay' transportation agreement pledge, account charges, insurance and reinsurance policies assignments and guaranteed by CNPC. As at 30 June 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was U.S.$3.3 million. According to these information, interest rate is recorded as 3M LIBOR in December 2012 (0.309%) + 2.35%; grace period = 4.5 years; repayment period = 10.5 years, maturity period = 15 years. According to CNPC, Line C successfully transmitted gas to Khorgas on June 15, 2017.

title: Moragahakanda Development Project
description: On 28 June 2012, China Development Bank Corporation (CDB) signed an agreement with the Sri Lankan government to provide a loan of US$214.2 million for the 'Construction of Head Work of Moragahakanda Reservoir' (Moragahakanda Development Project) with the goal to provide water for irrigation and drinking purposes for those living in northern region of Sri Lanka, and generate electricity for domestic and industrial use. Construction will be carried out by Sinohydro Corporation of China. Work began on June 28th, 2012, and the project was completed on June 28th, 2017. The total estimated cost of the project was US$252.3 million according to the Government of Sri Lanka 2017 Bond Prospectus, but it is unclear what organization provided the remaining funding. No other external donors for this project are listed in Sri Lanka Government documents, so it seems any additional funding would have been provided by Sri Lanka. This USD 214.2 million loan from CDB has a variable interest rate of LIBOR 06 Months for US$ + 2.90% margin, a grace period of 4 years, and a 15 year maturity (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2012 & 2017 Annual Performance Reports). The interest rate is coded based on the 6 Month LIBOR at time of signing of the agreement. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in June 2012 was 0.736%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.736% + 2.90%, or 3.636%. The objective of the project was to provide irrigation facilities for 82,000 ha, increase the cropping intensity up to 1.81, a d issue 90 MCM of water for domestic/industrial purposes and construction of 25 MW hydro power plants. To do this, a main dam (61 m high and 465m long) was constructed. Sinohydro Corporation of China has undertaken the construction work of Moragahakanda reservoir Main Dam and Saddle Dam 1 (with a height of 50.5m and length of 365m) including 25MW Hydro Power generating unit. The Saddle Dam 2 (with a height of 21.5m and length of 275m) of the reservoir was completed using local funds. The saddle dams retain 570 MCM of water. The contractor has completed preliminary works such as contactor‚Äôs office complex, workshop, Baylay Bridge over Amban Ganga, concrete batching plant, quarry production plant and necessary equipment and machines. The Moragahakanda reservoir was estimated to hold 570 million cubic metres (MCM) of water covering an extent of 2,950 ha. This project is the 5th and last of the major water projects conceptualized under the Accelerated Mahaweli Scheme. It will benefit the populations of districts Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Mathale, and Trincomalee.

title: Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project (Phase I): Buyer's Credit Facility (linked to #33244 and #33452)
description: On 9 September 2006, China Eximbank signed a USD 455 million financing agreement with Sri Lanka for Phase I of the Norochcholai Coal Power Project in Puttalam, which is also referred to as the Puttalam Coal Power Project (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization' for the commitment date). This financing agreement consists of two components, a USD 155 million buyer's credit facility (not preferential) and a USD 300 million preferential buyer's credit facility (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2009 Annual Performance Report). For the purpose of this project, only details related to the USD 155 million non-preferential buyer's credit facility have been recorded. For details regarding the USD 300 million preferential buyer's credit facility, see project ID #33244. According to the 2017 Government of Sri Lanka Bond Prospectus, the USD 455 million of Chinese financing covered the total cost of the project. The main components of this project include the installation of a 300MW coal power plant, a jetty for coal handling, and transmission lines from Norochcholai to Veyangoda and substation at Veyangoda. The power plant constructed under the scope of this project is known as the Lakvijaya Power Station or the Norochcholai Power Station (see Sri Lanka Ministry of Power, Energy and Business Development). According to the Sri Lanka Ministry of Power, Energy and Business Development, the USD 155 million buyer's credit facility has an interest rate of 6%. Phase I construction began on 23 July 2007 and was completed in March 2010. The contractor for this project was China Machinery Engineering Corporation. For information on Phase II, see project ID #33452.

title: Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project (Phase II) (link to projects ID #33244 and #33463)
description: In 2009, EXIM Bank of China committed a US$891 million preferential buyer's credit facility to Sri Lanka's CEB (Ceylon Electricity Board) for Phase II of the Norochcholai Coal Power Project in Puttalam, which is also referred to as the Puttalam Coal Power Project. This loan is a 20 year soft loan with a 5 year grace period and 2% interest. This second phase was implemented in 2010 and completed in 2014. The main components of this project include the establishment of two power plants with a capacity of 300MW each, a transmission line from Norochcholai to Anuradhapura, new substations at Chilaw and Anuradhapura and the construction of the expansion of coal handling port facilities and employees' housing. The project was implemented by China Machinery Engineering Corporation under the supervision of the Ceylon Electricity Board and was to be completed in three phases. Construction of the first phase began in 2007 and was opened on 22 March 2011 (see projects ID#33244 and #33463). The final phase of the project was officially opened on 16 September 2014. According to the 2009 Performance Report from the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources, Phases II & III were implemented together as Phase II due to the urgency of developing low cost power. This plant is sometimes referred to as the Lakvijaya Power Plant. China merchants group owns an 85% stake in this power plant as of 2012.

title: Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 1 (PRP1)
description: China Development Bank provided Sri Lanka a loan of $152.8 million for the Priority Road Project-1, which began on December 16, 2010, and ended December 16, 2016. The total project cost was US$169.8 million, it is unclear which organization provided the remaining funding. This project was for the purpose of providing an efficient national road network that would improve the integration of the country. The following excerpt from Sri Lanka's Department of External Resources describes the extent of the project: C1A (I) - Beliatta Tangalle Road - 7.47 km C1A (II) - Bopale - Kiribbanara - Uadamauara Road - 8.5 km C1A (III) - Flyover at Siribopura Junction C2A - Pelawatta Kankotiyawatta Thiniyawala Morawaka Road - 47 km C3 - Thiruwanaketiya Agalawatta Road (0 - 033.45km ) C6A - Kandy - Mahiyangana- Padiyathalawa Road - 20.5 km C8 - Kalkudah Road - 5.63 km C8 - Kalkudah Valachchenai Road - 4.42 km C11 - Paranthan Mullaitivu Road - 52 km: This segment of the road will benefit up to 800,000 people who live along the road, and will cut transport costs in half for the region. The priority road project had three sections. See projects #39001 (PRP2), #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1), and #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details. STAFF_NOTE: Other project sources (some official) indicate that the loan was for US$153 million, but another official source reports a loan of $152.8 million. Since these are similar, the lowest (and potentially most current) amount was recorded.

title: Thambuttegama Water Supply Project
description: The China Development Bank provided a loan of US$102.5 million for the Thambuttegama Water Supply Project, as signed on August 21, 2017. The goal of this project is to provide safe drinking water via pipes to all 45 Grama Niladdhari divisions in Katana Divisional Seretariat covering 50% of the population in the area (similar to project #53566). To do this, the project will, over 3 years, construct a water intake structure with a capacity of 42,000 m3/day, a water treatment plant of 18,000m3/day, a ground reservoir of 1,500 m3 capacity, a raw water and treated water transmission mains totaling up to an approximate length of 50 Km, elevated towers of 1,500 m3 capacity, a distribution network of 135 KM, and facilities to operate and maintain the water supply scheme. The project is expected to commence operations in 2021 and is in the tender evaluation stage as of March 2018. The project is being implemented by the Sri Lanka National Water Supply & Drainage Board. According to a March 2018 Sri Lanka news source, the Sri Lanka National Water Supply & Drainage Board Assistant General Manager for the North Central Province Sudath Ratnayake indicated that the Chinese loan for this project carries an interest rate of 1-1.5 per cent plus London Inter Bank Offered Rate (LIBOR) and is payable over 15 years. The interest rate is coded based on the 6 Month LIBOR at time of signing of the agreement. The average 6 month LIBOR (USD) for August 2017 was 1.454%. The least concessional base interest rate from the 1-1.5 per cent range will be used for calculating the total interest rate. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 1.5% + 1.454%, or 2.954%. The total project is expected to cost US$120.5 million; the remaining $18 million will be provided by the Bank of Ceylon (state-owned, commercial, Sri Lankan bank). This project is one of the four water supply projects under implementation in Sri Lanka funded by the China Development Bank. The other three projects are: 54435 (Gampaha, Attanagalla and Minuwangoda Integrated Water Supply Scheme), 53566 (Katana water supply), 53568 (Valachchenai Water Supply Project and Banadarawela, Diyathalawa and Haputhale Water Supply Project).

title: China Development Bank loans $3 Billion for Galkynysh (South Yolotan‚ÄìOsman) Gas Field Phase I (Linked to Project #41905)
description: In June 2009, visiting Chinese vice-premier Li Keqiang and Turkmen President Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov signed an agreement stating that China Development Bank would provide Turkmenistan with a long-term preferential loan of 3 billion USD. This loan was given to help develop the Galkynysh Gas Field (also known as South Yolotan‚ÄìOsman Field) while Turkmenistan will supply China with up to 40 billion cubic meters/year of gas for 30 years under deals signed June 24 in Ashgabat. They include a supplementary agreement covering CNPC's exploration and production activities at Bagitiyarlik, where the company has a license to produce up to 30 Bcm/year, and a separate contract under which state-owned Turkmengaz will deliver 10 Bcm/year to CNPC. In April 2011, China signed an additional 4.1 billion USD loan agreement with Turkmenistan for Phase II of the project. The loan will be dispensed in the course of 3 years, and in return Turkmenistan will supply natural gas to China for 10 years. (See project ID #41905) The project officially started in August 2010, and was completed on September 4, 2013. This project is part of the umbrella project captured in project #43168.

title: EXIM Bank loans 309,592,800 USD for North-South power transmission line
description: In 2006, China Eximbank provided a 309,592,800 USD export credit facility to Tajkistan for the construction of the North-South Electricity Transmission line to connect the northern Sughd region to the national grid. This is a 500kV OHL power transmission project to bring electricity to rural villages by connected their northern and southern power grids. The loan has a 2 percent annual interest rate, grace period of five years, and maturity of 20 years. On June 14, 2006, TBEA signed a contracting agreement for implementation of this project. On September 16, 2006, State Council Premier Wen Jiabao and President Rahmonov of Tajikistan cut the ribbon for the start of construction of this project. The total cost of the project was 334.5 million USD, with Tajikistan contributing about 14 million USD. The North-South transmission line has been operational since November 2009. China Exim bank also provided loans to Tajikistan for the Lolazor-Khatlon 220kV transmission line (see project ID #39984) and the Khujand-Ayni power transmission line (see project ID ##40051). STAFF_NOTE: China Eximbank indicates that this project was financed by preferential export buyer's credit in the attached 'ÈáçÂ§ßÈ°πÁõÆ Major Projects' document. Several sources refer to the Chinese financing for this project as 267.2 million USD and the total cost of the project as 281.4 million USD. The Tajikistan AIMS indicates that the commitment from China Eximbank was 309,592,800 USD for this project, and a case study from the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific indicates that the total cost of the project was 334.5 million USD.

title: CDB loans 200 million USD for Moynak Hydropower Plant
description: In 2006, alongside a host of other agreements, the Chinese Development Bank granted a $200 million USD loan to the Kazakh government for the construction of the Moynak Hydropower Plant. Construction on the plant had started in 1985 but stopped after the collapse of the Soviet Union; thanks to the Chinese loan, in 2006, construction on the power plant started anew. It is located approximately 200km from Almati, along the Charyn River in Almaty Province, and was scheduled for completion in 2009 - it was ultimately commissioned in December 2011, with it being scheduled to operate at full capacity in Spring of 2012. According to the 2012 Bond Prospectus from the Development Bank of Kazakhstan, DBK's participation in the Moynak hydroelectric power plant project was 68.3 million USD. A joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called JSC Moynak HES was set up to manage the loan and the project. This JSC was jointly established by China Water Resources and Electric Power Corporation (CWE), China Geological Engineering Corporation (CGC) and China Hydropower Consulting Group Chengdu Survey and Design Institute (CHIDI) (see attached resource from China's Ministry of Commerce).

title: China Gave 70 Million USD Export Credit to Kyrgyzstan for the Construction of a Cement Factory
description: In 2006 China Exim Bank provided 70 million USD in preferential export buyer's credit for the construction of the South Kyrgyz Cement Factory in Kyzyl-Kiya city. This project is the first Chinese government preferential credit provided within the framework of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation. The loan is guaranteed by Kazakhstan Turan-Alem Bank. This project officially broke ground on 25 March 2006, with China CAMC Engineering Co Ltd implementing the project in partnership with South Kyrgyz Cement CJSC. The plant is expected to have an output of 2500 tons of cement per day and was slated for completion in 2008. The production line was successfully put into operation in September 2009. Although there was turmoil in the country including riots near the factory, a technical team successfully completed the performance evaluation of the production line and handed over the factory to the owner for management. STAFF_NOTE: Some sources indicate that the transaction amount is 77.8 million. We decided to use the data from BTA Bank, which is the guarantor of the loan.
