title: Winter fuel donation
description: In November 2010, China delivered winter fuel worth 8.1 million RMB to civilians in Honza, Pakistan. The donation included 2998.66 tons of coal, 74.86 tons of diesel, and 15.12 tons of gasoline.
sources: http://yws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/b/d/201012/20101207278562.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.56.com/u53/v_NTY2MjYwMTg.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China grants food, tents and sheets to Tajikistan for Harsh Winter Relief (linked to #57839)
description: In April 2012, the government of China sent Tajikistan a humanitarian aid package consisting of 220 tons of rice, 120 tons of vegetable oil, tents, and sheets. It is unclear which part of the Chinese government provided the funding, and the financial value of the project is unclear. This project should not be confused with project #57839, the 2011 natural disaster response from China to Tajikistan. The 2012 aid package primarily seeks to address the impact of an unusually cold winter, while the 2011 aid package primarily seeks to address a flood.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020120416e84g000m9&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=CEASEN0020120417e84h000b7&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0, Other
funding_agency: Chinese Government, Government Agency

title: China grants 732,386 USD for response to natural disasters
description: In June 2010, Chinese President Hu Jintao announced 5 million RMB of assistance to Tajikistan to eliminate consequences of natural disasters. This project corresponds to TJK/102178 in the Tajikistan AIMS, which details a grant of 732,386 USD for 'assistance in natural disaster'. At the same time, the President also announced 80 million RMB to support the country's economy, which is captured in project ID #40409.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASIPLU0020100611e66b00030&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China grants 764,526 to Tajikistan for Flood Relief (linked to #40441)
description: In 2011, the government of China granted 764,526 USD to Tajikistan in the form of humanitarian aid for flooding and other natural disasters. It is unclear which part of the Chinese government provided the funding. A May 2018 Flat Export of the Tajikistan AMP reports 'Humanitarian aid for flood and other disasters' in project TJK/112260. The first two digits indicate the year, leading to the assumption that this project. Though the Flat Export does not tie this project to a specific disaster, it is possible that the referenced flooding is the series of June 2011 floods and mudslides in Sughd province. This project should not be confused with project #40441, the 2012 natural disaster response from China to Tajikistan. The 2012 aid package primarily seeks to address the impact of an unusually cold winter, while the 2011 aid package primarily seeks to address a flood.
sources: https://reliefweb.int/disaster/ff-2011-000066-tjk, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Other
funding_agency: Chinese Government, Government Agency

title: Dushanbe CHP-2 (Phase I) (linked to project #46211)
description: In 2009, the Ministry of Energy and Industries and Tebian Electric Apparatus (TBEA) signed a memorandum of understanding for the construction of a 200 MW coal fired power station. Construction did not begin until 2012 due to funding negotiations, with the plant being downsized to a 100 MW capacity. It was agreed that TBEA would front the construction costs of $178 million by borrowing from China EXIM Bank, and Tajikistan in return would grant TBEA rights to explore and develop gold deposits in the Eastern Duoba and Upper Kumarg mines. Tajikistan aimed to borrow money through concessional loans through EXIM Bank themselves, but Tajik Minister of Energy and Water Resources, Usmonali Usmonov stated: 'It has practically been impossible to attract funds from international financial institutions for construction of the Dushanbe-2 CHP plant‚Ä¶..When the project is not designed for the year-round operation, it cannot be efficient, and therefore, nobody wants to finance such projects.‚Äù The power plant, Dushanbe 2, is a combined heat and power plant (CHP) which will provide heat and electricity to Dushanbe, and will only operate in the winter. There were two distinct phases. Phase 1 installed a capacity of 100 MW, and Phase 2 installed an additional capacity of 300 MW. Phase 1 was completed in 2014. The project is paid back by the Tajik Government on a model of 'resource for energy,' meaning that along with the power plant contract, a nearby goldmine is also awarded to the Chinese side, and the gains from the mining company's gold mining would be used to offset the construction cost of the power station of 178 million US dollars (equivalent to about 1.12 billion yuan), and the net profit can be 1.464 billion yuan. No transaction has been recorded for this project as the 178 million USD reportedly loaned to this project was recorded by the Tajikistan State Committee of Investments as one of 2 loans from China Eximbank that went to the 'Project of construction of second in succession construction of ‚ÄúTPS -2 in Dushanbe', which makes up the 331 million USD captured in project #46211. One loan amount was 178969,22 (believed to be in thousands USD), and another was 152455,27 (believed to be in thousands USD). The China Eximbank 2014 and 2016 annual reports also only listed 'Dushanbe No. 2 Thermal Power Station Phase II in Tajikistan' as a project financed by the bank, and not Phase I.
sources: https://thediplomat.com/2018/04/the-full-story-behind-chinas-gold-mine-power-plant-swap-in-tajikistan/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://news.tj/en/news/tajikistan/economic/20180501/tbea-can-get-license-for-further-mining-deposit-if-profit-from-the-gold-deposits-doesnt-cover-the-cost-of-chp-plant, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/power/china-completes-350-million-power-plant-in-tajikistan/55886095, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.cec.org.cn/guojidianli/2012-09-29/91744.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/aboutExim/annals/2016/201807/P020180712402151419837.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://investcom.tj/en/investments/foreign-aid/184-current-projects.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: China Export-Import Bank, State-Owned Company
implementing_agency: Tebian Electric Apparatus, Private Sector
contacts: Usmonali Usmonov, Tajik Minister of Energy and Water Resources

title: $20 million grant for budgetary support
description: On January 14, 2012, China announced a one-time grant of US$20 million (over Rs 1.65 billion) to the government to support the peace process, in particular this grant is a budgetary support which will be used for financing rehabilitation of former Maoist combatants. This was announced when Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China paid a short visit to Nepal (lasting four and a half hours), stopping over on his way to the Persian Gulf. According to the Nepal government, the agreement was signed in 2012 but not implemented yet as of 2018.
sources: http://www.idsa.in/idsacomments/ChinesePMinNepalAshortvisitbutalongtrail_NiharNayak_180112.html, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-international/wen-jiabao-makes-brief-nepal-visit-offers-aid/article2802669.ece, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://archives.myrepublica.com/2012/portal/?action=news_details&news_id=40812, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=HTREPB0020120114e81e000ma&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KATMPO0020120115e81f00008&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ekantipur.com/the-kathmandu-post/2012/01/14/top-story/wens-visit-took-bilateral-relations-to-a-new-height/230403.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.nepalnews.com/mobile/view_article.php?id=15989, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.travelbiznews.com/news/item/254-chinese-premier-wen-jiabao-visits-nepal, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.c3sindia.org/nepal/2709, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://www.dropbox.com/sh/xwgtc3dxlm2elu9/AAAZaPuBCh_NR4A5mOMp_W7-a?dl=0&preview=December+2018+Nepal+AMP+--+Budgetary+Support+(China)+.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: Bank of China fulfills $300 million Loan to Pakistan in Facility Agreement (Linked to project #50486, #54158)
description: On May 24 2017, Bank of China signed a facility agreement of 300 million USD with Pakistan in order for Pakistan to continue to improve its foreign reserves holdings and other banking and macroeconomic conditions. The loan has an interest rate of LIBOR 3 Months + 2.93%, no grace period and a 3-year maturity period. Two other loans have been made by Chinese banks as facility agreement to help Pakistan balance its payment account. Linked to project #50486, #54158.
sources: http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/Trainings/2017/Monthly%20Disbursement%20Report%20July-June%202016-17%20final.xls, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/survey/chapters_18/Economic_Survey_2017_18.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: Bank of China (BOC), State-Owned Company

title: Bank of China provides US$500 million to Pakistan for balance of payment obligations
description: In the 2001 fiscal year, the Pakistani government needed to generate US$3.58 billion to plug the resource gap in the external finance sector. According to an official in the Ministry of Finance, the resource gap would mainly be bridged by rolling over different existing loans and credits currently deposited with the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP). A sum of US$500 million had been received by the Bank of China as a rollover facility to be utilised for balance of payment obligations. Additionally, US$250 million has been provided by the government of Kuwait, US$300 million by the government of United Arab Emirates.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=paprin0020010726dx7n000ij&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.imf.org/external/np/loi/2000/pak/01/, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)
funding_agency: Bank of China (BOC), State-Owned Company

title: China Development Bank Loans $700 million USD to Pakistan for Balance of Payment support
description: According to the 2016-2017 status report from Economic Affairs Division, on 20 September 2016, the Chinese Development Bank signed an agreement to provide a $700 million USD loan to Pakistan in order to prevent Pakistan's banking system from experiencing a balance of payments crisis. The loan was provided to improve other macroeconomic conditions in Pakistan as well. This loan was part of the $1.9 billion (USD) in monetary aid that China sent to Pakistan from late 2016 to early 2017. According to IMF, the interest rate is LIBOR 6 Months + 302 bps. The repayment period is 3 years. STAFF_NOTE: at this time it is unknown when other loans that were a part of the $1.9 billion were distributed
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PAFAGEN020170304ed34000p4&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASETRI0020170303ed3200004&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.finance.gov.pk/survey/chapters_18/Economic_Survey_2017_18.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/Trainings/2017/Monthly%20Disbursement%20Report%20July-June%202016-17%20final.xls, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency

title: China Development Bank signs $300 million Facility Agreement with Pakistan (Linked to project #50486, #54159)
description: According to a Monthly Disbursement Report from the Economic Affairs Division, on May 15 2017, China Development Bank signed an agreement for a project titled 'US $1 Billion Term Facility' . However, only 300 million USD was eventually committed. The agreement was intended for Pakistan to continue to improve its foreign reserves holdings and other banking and macroeconomic conditions. According to the IMF, the loan has an interest rate of LIBOR rate (6 months) plus 3.02%, no grace period and a 3-year maturity period. Two other facility agreements have been signed by Chinese banks to help Pakistan with its balance of payments. Linked to project #50486, #54159.
sources: http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/Trainings/2017/Monthly%20Disbursement%20Report%20July-June%202016-17%20final.xls, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/survey/chapters_18/Economic_Survey_2017_18.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency

title: China provides $1 million in cash assistance to Afghanistan government budget (Linked to Project ID#34498, #53537)
description: On 27 May 2003, Chinese Vice President Zeng Qinghong and Afghan Vice President Nimartullah Shaharani signed an agreement, under which China would provide $1 million in cash to Afghanistan. The report published by China Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Chinese media articles reported that the US$1 million was to support Afghanistan's national budget. The agreement was first signed together with #53537, in 2002 January, where 30 million Chinese Yuan aid package was delivered to Afghanistan. STAFF_NOTE: This project is part of umbrella project #34498. The transaction amount is accounted for here and is taken out of the umbrella project amount.

title: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China signs $300 million Facility Agreement with Pakistan (linked to project #54158, #54159)
description: In January 2017, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) signed an agreement to give Pakistan a $300 million (USD) loan in order for Pakistan to continue to improve its foreign reserves holdings and other banking and macroeconomic conditions. The loan has an interest rate of LIBOR rate (3 months) plus 2.75%, no grace period and a 2-year maturity period. Two other loans have been made by Chinese banks as facility agreement to help Pakistan balance its payment account. Linked to project #54158, #54159.

title: CDB signs $650 million loan agreement with Kazakhstan Development Bank (year 2015) - drawn down amount (Linked to #53574)
description: On 17 March 2015, the Development Bank of Kazakhstan (DBK) signed a $650.0 million loan agreement with China Development Bank. Each loan under this loan agreement matures on 15 June 2025. As at 30 June 2017, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under this loan agreement was U.S.$200.0 million. The funds will finance projects in energy, transport, infrastructure, manufacturing, information technologies, agriculture and other areas. This loan was identified by the DBK Annual Report 2015 as a credit line. This project captures the drawn down amount, the full amounts is captured in umbrella project #53574. STAFF_NOTE: Not a duplicate of 53575 - 53575 was signed in June 2017 for the same amount. This project was signed in 2015.
sources: https://uc920c267d56e444011c45cae5bc.previews.dropboxusercontent.com/nativeprint?file=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dropbox.com%2Fs%2Fb8pbob8b1n7pwr1%2FDevelopment%2520Bank%2520of%2520Kazakhstan%25202017%2520Bond%2520Prospectus.pdf%3Fdisable_range%3D1%26from_native_print%3D1%26preview%3D1, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://nationalbank.kz/cont/BoP_2016_eng.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.dbk.kz/upload/iblock/ed6/ed6ac0af95e1030652f131a159ff8b7a.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: CDB signs $650 million loan agreement with Kazakhstan Development Bank (year 2017) - drawn down amount (linked to project #53575)
description: In March 2017, China Development Bank provided a $650 million loan to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan, for joint Kazakh-Chinese projects in the transportation, infrastructure, and communication sectors. China and Kazakhstan agreed on the line of credit in 2015 and the facility agreement was amended in July 2016. As at 30 June 2017, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under the agreement was $170 million. The loan matures in June 2025 and has an interest rate of 2.7% per annum plus LIBOR. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in March 2017 is used in the calculation of interest rate - 1.426% + 2.7% = 4.126% This project captures the drawn down amount of 480 million USD. The full amount is captured in umbrella project #53575. STAFF_NOTE: Not a duplicate of 53574 - 53574 was signed in March 2015 for the same amount. This project was signed in 2017.
sources: http://nationalbank.kz/cont/BoP_2016_eng.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0289Y_-2017-11-30.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.kdb.kz/upload/iblock/71d/AR2017_KDB_eng_site.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
implementing_agency: Kazakhstan Development Bank, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Kazakhstan Development Bank, Government Agency

title: China Exim Bank to finance the construction of an integrated petrochemical project near Atyrau (linked to project #53547)
description: The Construction of the first integrated petrochemical complex in Atyrau region was developed in the framework of the 'Program of development of petrochemical industry of the Republic of Kazakhstan for 2008-2013', approved by the Government of the Republic of Kazakhstan dated December 29, 2007, in order to use existing large volumes of gas from Tengiz and Kashagan feedstock for chemical complex producing expensive petrochemical products for subsequent sale in the domestic and export markets. The Atyrau petrochemical project is being developed by Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries (KPI) who will own and operate the complex. Integrated petrochemical complex consists of two process units - the dehydrogenation of propane to propylene production and installation of the polymerization of propylene to produce an end product of polypropylene. In the framework of the project is expected to develop existing and construction of new infrastructure - gas turbine power plant, water treatment plants, fuel gas and water pipelines, road and rail interchanges, etc. According to various reports, in 2009 KPI signed an Engineering, Procurement, and Construction (EPC) contract with Sinopec for the first stage of construction. On 22 February 2011, the Development Bank of Kazakhstan (DBK) entered into an individual credit agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China for the amount of U.S.$1.4 billion to finance the construction of the integrated petrochemical project. However, as of 2017, no amounts had been drawn down under this individual credit agreement due the termination of the engineering, procurement and construction contract between KPI and Sinopec in 2014. It is highly likely that this project was funded through the 1.5 billion USD unrestricted portion of a China Eximbank Master Loan Facility to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan, captured in #53547.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=CDENGY0020100405e63p00034&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.kpi.kz/en/news/view?id=19, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.plasticsnewseurope.com/article/20160201/PNE/160209985/lg-chem-scraps-plan-for-3-84bn-polyethylene-complex-in-kazakhstan, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://azh.kz/en/news/view/5049, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://en.tengrinews.kz/markets/China-allocates-over-1-billion-for-construction-of-advanced-10624/, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://www.gasandoil.com/news/2012/06/china-invests-in-construction-of-advanced-oil-processing-center-in-atyrau, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://etheses.lse.ac.uk/3126/1/Bohnenberger-Rich_Kazakhstan_and_China.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://etheses.lse.ac.uk/3126/1/Bohnenberger-Rich_Kazakhstan_and_China.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://uc920c267d56e444011c45cae5bc.previews.dropboxusercontent.com/nativeprint?file=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dropbox.com%2Fs%2Fb8pbob8b1n7pwr1%2FDevelopment%2520Bank%2520of%2520Kazakhstan%25202017%2520Bond%2520Prospectus.pdf%3Fdisable_range%3D1%26from_native_print%3D1%26preview%3D1, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://uc920c267d56e444011c45cae5bc.previews.dropboxusercontent.com/nativeprint?file=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dropbox.com%2Fs%2Fb8pbob8b1n7pwr1%2FDevelopment%2520Bank%2520of%2520Kazakhstan%25202017%2520Bond%2520Prospectus.pdf%3Fdisable_range%3D1%26from_native_print%3D1%26preview%3D1, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/ztdy/201210/20121008374197.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.kpi.kz/en/about/view?id=3, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.chemicals-technology.com/projects/kazakhstan_petrochem/, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy

implementing_agency: Sinopec International Petroleum Service Corporation (SINOPEC); Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries, Private Sector
recipient_agencies: Kazakhstan Development Bank, Government Agency; Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries, Private Sector

title: China Eximbank funds construction of a complex for the production of aromatic hydrocarbons at the Atyrau oil refinery (linked to project #54797)
description: On July 30 2010, Development Bank of Kazakhstan and Atyrau Oil Refinery (100% KazMunaiGas Exploration and Marketing subsidiary) signed an agreement for the 'Construction of a complex on aromatic hydrocarbons production at Atyrau Oil Refinery in the size of USD1,063,660,000 for 13 years. It is known that on October 29, 2009 under the project Atyrau Oil Refinery signed an agreement with Chinese Sinopec Engineering for construction of the aromatic hydrocarbons production complex. At this, 85% of an agreement cost is funded through the loan of Development Bank of Kazakhstan and Chinese Export-Import Bank. It is highly likely that this project was funded through the 3 billion USD restricted portion of a China Eximbank Master Loan Facility to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan, captured in #54797.
